      \begin{equation*} \begin{alignedat}{5} a \amp \amp \amp \amp \amp \amp \amp {}={} \amp 2 \\ a \amp {}+{} \amp b \amp {}+{} \amp c \amp {}+{} \amp d \amp {}={} \amp 3 \\ a \amp {}+{} \amp 2b \amp {}+{} \amp 4c \amp {}+{} \amp 8d \amp {}={} \amp 0 \\ a \amp {}+{} \amp 3b \amp {}+{} \amp 9c \amp {}+{} \amp 27d \amp {}={} \amp 1\text{.} \\ \end{alignedat} \end{equation*}
    2. The coefficients are \(a=2\text{,}\) \(b=\frac{17}{3}\text{,}\) \(c=-6\text{,}\) and \(d=\frac43\text{.}\)
    3. The polynomial is
      \begin{equation*} p(x) = 2 + \frac{17}{3}x -6x^2 + \frac43 x^3\text{.} \end{equation*}
    4. The linear system is inconsistent.
    5. The linear system is consistent with infinitely many solutions.
    6. Nine.
    Solution.
    1. The four equations we find are
      \begin{equation*} \begin{alignedat}{5} a \amp \amp \amp \amp \amp \amp \amp {}={} \amp 2 \\ a \amp {}+{} \amp b \amp {}+{} \amp c \amp {}+{} \amp d \amp {}={} \amp 3 \\ a \amp {}+{} \amp 2b \amp {}+{} \amp 4c \amp {}+{} \amp 8d \amp {}={} \amp 0 \\ a \amp {}+{} \amp 3b \amp {}+{} \amp 9c \amp {}+{} \amp 27d \amp {}={} \amp 1\text{.} \\ \end{alignedat} \end{equation*}
    2. This leads to the augmented matrix
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rrrr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp 3 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp 4 \amp 8 \amp 0 \\ 1 \amp 3 \amp 9 \amp 27 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrrr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp \frac{17}{3} \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp -6 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp \frac43 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{equation*}
      This gives the coefficients \(a=2\text{,}\) \(b=\frac{17}{3}\text{,}\) \(c=-6\text{,}\) and \(d=\frac43\text{.}\)
    3. The polynomial
      \begin{equation*} p(x) = 2 + \frac{17}{3}x -6x^2 + \frac43 x^3 \end{equation*}
      passes through the four given points.
    4. We have the augmented matrix
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp 3 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp 4 \amp 0 \\ 1 \amp 3 \amp 9 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{equation*}
      This system is therefore inconsistent, which means there is no degree 2 polynomial passing through the four points.
    5. The augmented matrix we find is
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rrrrr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp 3 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp 4 \amp 8 \amp 16 \amp 0 \\ 1 \amp 3 \amp 9 \amp 27 \amp 81 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrrrr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 6 \amp \frac{17}{3} \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp -11 \amp -6 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 6 \amp \frac43 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{equation*}
      This shows that there are infinitely many polynomials whose degree is four and that pass through the four points.
    6. If there are 10 points, we should find a polynomial having 10 coefficients. This means that the degree of the polynomial should be 9.

    18 Vectors, matrices, and linear combinations
    18.1 Vectors and linear combinations
    18.1.1 Vectors

    Preview Activity 18.1.1. Scalar Multiplication and Vector Addition.

    Solution.
    Solutions to this preview activity are given in the text below.

    18.1.2 Linear combinations

    Activity 18.1.2.

    Answer.
    1. The linear combinations lie on the line defined by \(\vvec\text{.}\)
    2. \(\twovec{0}{-3}\text{.}\)
    3. They lie on the line through \(\wvec\) parallel to \(\vvec\text{.}\)
    4. Yes, with weights \(c=d=0\text{.}\)
    5. Yes, with weights \(c=2\) and \(d=-1\text{.}\)
    6. This can be done by writing the appropriate linear system for the weights.
    7. No, any two-dimensional vector can be expressed as a linear combination of \(\vvec\) and \(\wvec\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. When we vary \(c\) with \(d=0\text{,}\) the linear combination moves along the line defined by \(\vvec\text{.}\)
    2. When \(c=1\) and \(d=-2\text{,}\) we find
      \begin{equation*} 1\vvec -2 \wvec = \twovec{0}{-3}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    3. When \(d=1\) and \(c\) is allowed to vary, the linear combinations lie on the line through \(\wvec\) parallel to \(\vvec\text{.}\)
    4. If the weights \(c=0\) and \(d=0\text{,}\) then the linear combination is the vector \(\twovec{0}{0}\text{.}\)
    5. If the weights \(c=2\) and \(d=-1\text{,}\) then the linear combination is the vector \(\twovec{3}{0}\text{.}\)
    6. We find the linear system for the weights:
      \begin{equation*} \begin{alignedat}{3} 2c \amp {}+{} \amp 1d \amp {}={} \amp 3 \\ 1c \amp {}+{} \amp 2d \amp {}={} \amp 0 \\ \end{alignedat} \end{equation*}
      If we construct the corresponding augmented matrix and determine its reduced row echelon matrix, we find the weights \(c=2\) and \(d=-1\text{.}\)
    7. In the same way, we construct a linear system for the weights whose augmented matrix is
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rr|r} 2 \amp 1 \amp 1.3 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp -1.7 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 1.43 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -1.57 \\ \end{array}\right] \text{,} \end{equation*}
      which shows that there are weights that produce the desired linear combination. The same will happen for any vector \(\bvec\) that we ask to write as a linear combination of \(\vvec\) and \(\wvec\text{.}\)
    8. Every two-dimensional vector can be written as a linear combination of \(\vvec\) and \(\wvec\) because the coefficient matrix of the linear system remains the same. Since that coefficient matrix has a pivot position in every row, the augmented matrix can never have a pivot position in the rightmost column.

    Activity 18.1.3. Linear combinations and linear systems.

    Answer.
    1. The vector \(\bvec\) cannot be expressed as a linear combination of \(\vvec_1\text{,}\) \(\vvec_2\text{,}\) and \(\vvec_3\text{.}\)
    2. We find vectors
      \begin{equation*} \vvec_1=\threevec{3}{1}{-1}, \vvec_2=\threevec{2}{0}{-1}, \vvec_3=\threevec{-1}{2}{3}, \bvec=\threevec{4}{0}{1}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    3. Yes, \(\bvec\) can be expressed as a linear combination of \(\vvec_1\text{,}\) \(\vvec_2\text{,}\) and \(\vvec_3\) in infinitely many ways.
    4. No.
    5. Yes, \(\bvec\) can be expressed as a linear combination of \(\vvec_1\text{,}\) \(\vvec_2\text{,}\) and \(\vvec_3\) in exactly one way.
    6. Any vector \(\bvec\) can be expressed as a linear combination of \(\vvec_1\text{,}\) \(\vvec_2\text{,}\) and \(\vvec_3\) in exactly one way.
    Solution.
    1. We find the linear system
      \begin{equation*} \begin{alignedat}{4} 4c_1 \amp {}+{} \amp c_2 \amp {}-{} \amp 2c_3 \amp {}={} \amp 0 \\ \amp \amp -3c_2 \amp {}+{} \amp c_3 \amp {}={} \amp 1 \\ 2c_1 \amp {}+{} \amp 3c_2 \amp {}+{} \amp c_3 \amp {}={} \amp 2 \\ c_1 \amp {}+{} \amp c_2 \amp \amp \amp {}={} \amp -2 \\ \end{alignedat} \end{equation*}
      with corresponding augmented matrix
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 4 \amp 1 \amp -2 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -3 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ 2 \amp 3 \amp 1 \amp 2 \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp -2 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{equation*}
      This shows that the linear system is inconsistent so there are no such weights \(c_1\text{,}\) \(c_2\text{,}\) and \(c_3\text{.}\) This means that \(\bvec\) is not a linear combination of \(\vvec_1\text{,}\) \(\vvec_2\text{,}\) and \(\vvec_3\text{.}\)
    2. We find vectors
      \begin{equation*} \vvec_1=\threevec{3}{1}{-1}, \vvec_2=\threevec{2}{0}{-1}, \vvec_3=\threevec{-1}{2}{3}, \bvec=\threevec{4}{0}{1}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    3. This is the same as asking if the linear system corresponding to the following augmented matrix is consistent:
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 0 \amp 1 \amp 2 \amp -1 \\ -2 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 3 \\ 1 \amp -1 \amp -1 \amp -1 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 2 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{equation*}
      From the reduced row echelon form, we see that the system is consistent, which means that \(\bvec\) can be expressed as a linear combination of \(\vvec_1\text{,}\) \(\vvec_2\text{,}\) and \(\vvec_3\text{.}\) Moreover, there are infinitely many ways in which we can do so.
    4. No, it is not possible to write every three-dimensional \(\bvec\) as a linear combination of \(\vvec_1\text{,}\) \(\vvec_2\text{,}\) and \(\vvec_3\) because the matrix \(\left[\begin{array}{rrr} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \vvec_3 \end{array}\right]\) does not have a pivot position in every row. This means that, with some choice of vector \(\bvec\text{,}\) we will obtain an inconsistent system.
    5. We find the augmented matrix
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ -2 \amp 1 \amp -1 \amp 8 \\ 1 \amp -1 \amp -2 \amp -4 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp -4 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{equation*}
      This shows that \(\bvec\) can be expressed as a linear combination of \(\vvec_1\text{,}\) \(\vvec_2\text{,}\) and \(\vvec_3\) in exactly one way.
    6. Every vector \(\bvec\) can be expressed as a linear combination of \(\vvec_1\text{,}\) \(\vvec_2\text{,}\) and \(\vvec_3\) in exactly one way because \(\left[\begin{array}{rrr} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \vvec_3 \end{array}\right]\) has a pivot position in every row and every column.

    18.1.4 Exercises

    18.1.4.1.

    Answer.
    3. This forms the line passing through \(2\vvec\) parallel to \(\wvec\text{.}\)
    4. There are many possibilities. One is \(\vvec=\twovec{0}{-2}\) and \(\wvec=\twovec{1}{3}\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    3. This forms the line passing through \(2\vvec\) parallel to \(\wvec\text{.}\)
    4. There are many possibilities. One is \(\vvec=\twovec{0}{-2}\) and \(\wvec=\twovec{1}{3}\text{.}\)

    18.1.4.2.

    Answer.
    1. We have
      \begin{equation*} \begin{array}{lll} p = -\vvec, \amp q = 3\wvec, \amp r=2\vvec+3\wvec, \\ s = 2\vvec-3\wvec, \amp t=-3\vvec-2\wvec, \amp u=-2\vvec+0.5\wvec, \\ v = 3.5\vvec+1.5\wvec\text{.} \end{array} \end{equation*}
    2. This is the line passing through \(-2\vvec\) parallel to \(\wvec\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. We have
      \begin{equation*} \begin{array}{lll} p = -\vvec, \amp q = 3\wvec, \amp r=2\vvec+3\wvec, \\ s = 2\vvec-3\wvec, \amp t=-3\vvec-2\wvec, \amp u=-2\vvec+0.5\wvec, \\ v = 3.5\vvec+1.5\wvec\text{.} \end{array} \end{equation*}
    2. This is the line passing through \(-2\vvec\) parallel to \(\wvec\text{.}\)

    18.1.4.3.

    Answer.
    1. The linear combination
      \begin{equation*} 2\vvec_1-3\vvec_2+\vvec_3 = \twovec{5}{-1}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    2. \(c_1 = \frac23 c_3\) and \(c_2 = -\frac23 c_3\text{.}\)
    3. \(c_1=c_2=0\text{.}\)
    4. \(\vvec_3=-\frac23\vvec_1 + \frac23\vvec_2\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. The linear combination
      \begin{equation*} 2\vvec_1-3\vvec_2+\vvec_3 = \twovec{5}{-1}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    2. The appropriate linear system corresponds to the augmented matrix
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 2 \amp -1 \amp -2 \amp 0 \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp -\frac{2}{3} \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp \frac{2}{3} \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{equation*}
      This shows we obtain \({\mathbf 0}\) when the weights are chosen so that
      \begin{equation*} \begin{alignedat}{2} c_1 \amp {}={} \frac23 c_3 \\ c_2 \amp {}={} -\frac23 c_3\text{.} \\ \end{alignedat} \end{equation*}
    3. In this case, we want \(c_3=0\text{,}\) which means that \(c_1=c_2=0\text{.}\)
    4. We see that \(\vvec_3=-\frac23\vvec_1 + \frac23\vvec_2\text{.}\)

    18.1.4.4.

    Answer.
    1. \(\threevec{120}{105}{1.0}\text{.}\)
    2. The totals consumed are expressed by the vector
      \begin{equation*} c\threevec{111}{140}{1.2} + d\threevec{120}{105}{1.0}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    3. You had two servings of Frosted Flakes and one serving of Cocoa Puffs.
    4. Your sister must have eaten something else.
    Solution.
    1. \(\threevec{120}{105}{1.0}\text{.}\)
    2. The totals consumed are expressed by the vector
      \begin{equation*} c\threevec{111}{140}{1.2} + d\threevec{120}{105}{1.0}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    3. We ask to write the vector \(\threevec{342}{385}{3.4}\) as a linear combination of the two cereal vectors. This leads to the augmented matrix
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rr|r} 111 \amp 120 \amp 342 \\ 140 \amp 105 \amp 385 \\ 1.2 \amp 1.0 \amp 3.4 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{equation*}
      This means that you had two servings of Frosted Flakes and one serving of Cocoa Puffs.
    4. Now the augmented matrix is
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rr|r} 111 \amp 120 \amp 250 \\ 140 \amp 105 \amp 200 \\ 1.2 \amp 1.0 \amp 4.0 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{,} \end{equation*}
      which represents an inconsistent system. This means that your sister must have eaten something else.

    18.1.4.5.

    Answer.
    1. The vector \(\bvec\) may be expressed as a linear combination of \(\vvec_1\text{,}\) \(\vvec_2\text{,}\) and \(\vvec_3\) provided that the weights are related by \(c_1=5-2c_3\) and \(c_2=2-2c_3\text{.}\)
    2. The vector \(\bvec\) cannot be written as a linear combination of \(\vvec_1\text{,}\) \(\vvec_2\text{,}\) and \(\vvec_3\text{.}\)
    3. \(\vvec_3=2\vvec_1+2\vvec_2\text{.}\)
    4. \(a\vvec_1+b\vvec_2+c\vvec_3= (a+2c)\vvec_1+(b+2c)\vvec_2\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. We have the system corresponding to the augmented matrix
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 2 \amp 0 \amp 4 \amp 10 \\ -1 \amp 3 \amp 4 \amp 1 \\ -2 \amp 1 \amp -2 \amp -8 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 2 \amp 5 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 2 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] \end{equation*}
      from which we conclude that \(\bvec\) may be expressed as a linear combination of \(\vvec_1\text{,}\) \(\vvec_2\text{,}\) and \(\vvec_3\) provided that the weights are related by \(c_1=5-2c_3\) and \(c_2=2-2c_3\text{.}\)
    2. Here we have
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 2 \amp 0 \amp 4 \amp 3 \\ -1 \amp 3 \amp 4 \amp 7 \\ -2 \amp 1 \amp -2 \amp 1 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \end{array}\right]\text{,} \end{equation*}
      which represents an inconsistent system and shows that \(\bvec\) cannot be written as a linear combination of \(\vvec_1\text{,}\) \(\vvec_2\text{,}\) and \(\vvec_3\text{.}\)
    3. The augmented matrix is
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rr|r} 2 \amp 0 \amp 4 \\ -1 \amp 3 \amp 4 \\ -2 \amp 1 \amp -2 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{,} \end{equation*}
      which shows that \(\vvec_3=2\vvec_1+2\vvec_2\text{.}\)
    4. \(a\vvec_1+b\vvec_2+c\vvec_3=a\vvec_1+b\vvec_2 + c(2\vvec_1+2\vvec_2) = (a+2c)\vvec_1+(b+2c)\vvec_2\text{.}\)

    18.1.4.6.

    Answer.
    \(k=10\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    We form the augmented matrix and find a triangular matrix that is row equivalent:
    \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rr|r} 3 \amp 1 \amp k \\ -1 \amp 1 \amp -2 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp 5 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rr|r} -1 \amp 1 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp k-10 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{equation*}
    This represents a consistent system when \(k=10\text{.}\)

    18.1.4.7.

    Answer.
    1. True
    2. True
    3. True
    4. False
    Solution.
    1. True, because we can choose the weights \(c=2\) and \(d=0\text{.}\)
    2. True, because the augmented matrix \(\left[\begin{array}{rrrr|r} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \ldots \amp \vvec_n \amp \bvec \end{array}\right]\) can never have a pivot position in the rightmost column.
    3. True, because the augmented matrix \(\left[\begin{array}{rrrr|r} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \ldots \amp \vvec_n \amp \bvec \end{array}\right]\) can never have a pivot position in the rightmost column and the corresponding linear system cannot have a free variable.
    4. False, because it is possible to choose a vector \(\bvec\) such that the augmented matrix \(\left[\begin{array}{rr|r} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \bvec \end{array}\right]\) has a pivot in the rightmost column.

    18.1.4.8.

    Answer.
    1. \((1,-4) = \{2,-3\}\text{.}\)
    2. \(\{7/3, -8/3\} = (2,-3)\text{.}\)
    3. \begin{equation*} \begin{alignedat}{2} x \amp {}={} \amp 2c+d \\ y \amp {}={} \amp c+2d\text{.} \\ \end{alignedat} \end{equation*}
    4. Solve the linear system corresponding to the augmented matrix
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rr|r} 2 \amp 1 \amp x \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp y \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{equation*}
    Solution.
    1. We have
      \begin{equation*} \twovec{x}{y} = 2\vvec_1 -3\vvec_2 = \twovec{1}{-4}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    2. We have \(\twovec{2}{-3} = c\vvec_1 + d\vvec_2 \text{.}\) Solving this equation, we find \(c=7/3\) and \(d=-8/3\text{,}\) which means that \((c,d) = \{7/3, -8/3\}\text{.}\)
    3. As in the first part of this problem, we write
      \begin{equation*} \begin{alignedat}{2} x \amp {}={} \amp 2c+d \\ y \amp {}={} \amp c+2d\text{.} \\ \end{alignedat} \end{equation*}
    4. We want to solve \(\twovec{x}{y} = c\vvec_1 + d\vvec_2\) by constructing the augmented matrix and finding its reduced row echelon form.
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rr|r} 2 \amp 1 \amp x \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp y \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{equation*}

    18.2 Matrix multiplication and linear combinations
    18.2.1 Scalar multiplication and addition of matrices

    Preview Activity 18.2.1. Matrix operations.

    Answer.
    1. \(\displaystyle \left[\begin{array}{rrr} -9 \amp -3 \amp 0 \\ 12 \amp -9 \amp 3 \\ \end{array}\right]\)
    2. \(\displaystyle \left[\begin{array}{rr} 4 \amp -4 \\ -1 \amp 0 \\ 4 \amp 5 \\ \end{array}\right]\)
    3. The shapes must be the same.
    4. The shape of \(A\) must be \(n\times n\text{.}\)
    5. \(\displaystyle A-2I_3 = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} -1 \amp 2 \amp -2 \\ 2 \amp -5 \amp 3 \\ -2 \amp 3 \amp 2 \\ \end{array}\right]\)
    Solution.
    1. \(\displaystyle \left[\begin{array}{rrr} -9 \amp -3 \amp 0 \\ 12 \amp -9 \amp 3 \\ \end{array}\right]\)
    2. \(\displaystyle \left[\begin{array}{rr} 4 \amp -4 \\ -1 \amp 0 \\ 4 \amp 5 \\ \end{array}\right]\)
    3. The shapes must be the same.
    4. The shape of \(A\) must be \(n\times n\text{.}\)
    5. \(\displaystyle A-2I_3 = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} -1 \amp 2 \amp -2 \\ 2 \amp -5 \amp 3 \\ -2 \amp 3 \amp 2 \\ \end{array}\right]\)

    18.2.2 Matrix-vector multiplication and linear combinations

    Activity 18.2.2. Matrix-vector multiplication.

    Answer.
    1. \(\displaystyle \threevec{4}{11}{9}\text{.}\)
    2. The dimension of \(\xvec\) must three, and the dimension of \(A\xvec\) must be four.
    3. \(A\zerovec = \zerovec\text{.}\)
    4. \(I\xvec = \xvec\text{.}\)
    5. \(A\evec_1 = 1\vvec_1+0\vvec_2+\ldots+0\vvec_n = \vvec_1\text{.}\)
    6. \(\xvec=\twovec{2}{2}\) is the unique solution.
    Solution.
    1. We have
      \begin{equation*} \begin{alignedat}{2} \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 1 \amp 2 \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ 2 \amp 4 \amp -3 \amp -2 \\ -1 \amp -2 \amp 6 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] \amp \fourvec{3}{1}{-1}{1} \\ \amp = \threevec{3(1)+1(2)-1(0)+1(-1)} {3(2)+1(4)-1(-3)+1(-2)} {3(-1)+1(-2)-1(6)+1(1)} \\ \amp =\threevec{4}{11}{10}\text{.} \end{alignedat} \end{equation*}
    2. The dimension of \(\xvec\) must be the same as the number of columns of \(A\) so \(\xvec\) is three-dimensional. The dimension of \(A\xvec\) equals the number of rows of \(A\) so \(A\xvec\) is four-dimensional.
    3. We have \(A\zerovec = \zerovec\text{.}\)
    4. We have \(I\xvec=\xvec\text{;}\) that is, multiplying a vector by \(I\) produces the same vector.
    5. The product \(A\evec_1 = 1\vvec_1+0\vvec_2+\ldots+0\vvec_n = \vvec_1\text{.}\)
    6. If \(A\xvec=\bvec\text{,}\) then we have
      \begin{equation*} \begin{alignedat}{3} x_1 \amp {}+{} \amp 2x_2 \amp {}={} \amp 6 \\ -x_1 \amp {}+{} \amp x_2 \amp {}={} \amp 0\text{.} \\ \end{alignedat} \end{equation*}
      with corresponding augmented matrix
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rr|r} 1 \amp 2 \amp 6 \\ -1 \amp 1 \amp 0 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 2 \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{equation*}
      This means that \(\xvec=\twovec{2}{2}\) is the unique solution to the equation \(A\xvec=\bvec\text{.}\)

    Activity 18.2.3.

    Answer.
    1. We define
      A = matrix(3, 4, [1, 2, 0, -1,
                  2, 4, -3, -2,
                  -1, -2, 6, 1])
v = vector([3, 1, -1, 1])
A*v
    2. We define
      A = matrix(2, 3, [-2, 0, 3, 1, 4, 2])
zero = vector([0, 0])
v = vector([-2, 3])
w = vector([1, 2])
    3. \(A\zerovec = \zerovec\text{.}\)
    4. \(A(3\vvec) = 3(A\vvec)\text{.}\)
    5. \(\displaystyle A(\vvec+\wvec) = A\vvec + A\wvec\)
    Solution.
    1. We define
      A = matrix(3, 4, [1, 2, 0, -1,
                  2, 4, -3, -2,
                  -1, -2, 6, 1])
v = vector([3, 1, -1, 1])
A*v
    2. We define
      A = matrix(2, 3, [-2, 0, 3, 1, 4, 2])
zero = vector([0, 0])
v = vector([-2, 3])
w = vector([1, 2])
    3. \(A\zerovec = \zerovec\text{.}\)
    4. \(A(3\vvec) = 3(A\vvec)\text{.}\)
    5. \(\displaystyle A(\vvec+\wvec) = A\vvec + A\wvec\)

    18.2.3 Matrix-vector multiplication and linear systems

    Activity 18.2.4. The equation \(A\xvec = \bvec\).

    Answer.
    1. \(A = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 2 \amp 1 \amp -3 \\ -1 \amp 2 \amp 1 \\ 3 \amp -1 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right]\) and \(\bvec=\threevec{4}{3}{-4}\text{.}\)
    2. \(\displaystyle \xvec = \threevec{x_1}{x_2}{x_3} = \threevec{-1}{3}{0}+x_3\threevec{3}{9}{1}\text{.}\)
    3. There are no solutions.
    4. There is at least one solution, namely, \(\xvec=\zerovec\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. \(A = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 2 \amp 1 \amp -3 \\ -1 \amp 2 \amp 1 \\ 3 \amp -1 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right]\) and \(\bvec=\threevec{4}{3}{-4}\text{.}\)
    2. Form the augmented matrix
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 3 \amp -1 \amp 0 \amp -6 \\ -2 \amp 0 \amp 6 \amp 2 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp -3 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -9 \amp 3 \end{array}\right] \end{equation*}
      so that
      \begin{equation*} \xvec = \threevec{x_1}{x_2}{x_3} = \threevec{-1+3x_3}{3+9x_3}{x_3} = \threevec{-1}{3}{0}+x_3\threevec{3}{9}{1}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    3. We have the augmented matrix
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rrrrr} 1 \amp 2 \amp 0 \amp -1 \amp -1 \\ 2 \amp 4 \amp -3 \amp -2 \amp 1 \\ -1 \amp -2 \amp 6 \amp 1 \amp 5 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrrrr} 1 \amp 2 \amp 0 \amp -1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{equation*}
      Since this system is inconsistent, there are no solutions to the matrix equation.
    4. We know that there is at least one solution, namely, \(\xvec=\zerovec\text{.}\)

    18.2.4 Matrix-matrix products

    Activity 18.2.5.

    Answer.
    1. The product \(AB\) exists because the number of columns of \(A\) equals the number of rows of \(B\text{.}\) The dimensions of \(AB\) are \(2\times 2\text{.}\)
    2. We have \(AB = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 2 \amp 4 \\ -3 \amp 9 \end{array}\right] \text{.}\)
    3. Define
      A = matrix(2, 3, [1, 3, 2, -3, 4, -1])
B = matrix(3, 2, [3, 0, 1, 2, -2, -1])
A*B
    4. It is not generally true that \(AB=BA\text{.}\)
    5. We find that \(A(B+C)=AB + AC\text{.}\)
    6. We find that \(A(BC) = (AB)C\text{.}\)
    7. It is not generally true that \(B=C\) if \(AB=AC\text{.}\)
    8. It is not generally true that \(A=0\) or \(B=0\) if \(AB=0\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. The product \(AB\) exists because the number of columns of \(A\) equals the number of rows of \(B\text{.}\) The dimensions of \(AB\) are \(2\times 2\text{.}\)
    2. We have \(AB = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 2 \amp 4 \\ -3 \amp 9 \end{array}\right] \text{.}\)
    3. Define
      A = matrix(2, 3, [1, 3, 2, -3, 4, -1])
B = matrix(3, 2, [3, 0, 1, 2, -2, -1])
A*B
    4. Yes, we can form the product \(BA\) because the number of columns of \(B\) equals the number of rows of \(A\text{.}\) This product \(AB\) will be \(3\times3\text{,}\) however, so it must be true that \(AB\neq BA\text{.}\)
    5. We find that \(A(B+C)=AB + AC\text{.}\)
    6. We find that \(A(BC) = (AB)C\text{.}\)
    7. It is not generally true that \(B=C\) if \(AB=AC\text{,}\) as illustrated by this example.
    8. It is not generally true that \(A=0\) or \(B=0\) if \(AB=0\text{,}\) as illustrated by this example.

    18.2.6 Exercises

    18.2.6.1.

    Answer.
    1. \(A = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 2 \amp -1 \\ 3 \amp 2 \amp 2 \\ -1 \amp 0 \amp 4 \\ \end{array}\right]\) and \(\bvec=\threevec{1}{7}{-3}\text{.}\)
    2. There is a unique solution \(\xvec=\threevec{3}{-1}{0}\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. \(A = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 2 \amp -1 \\ 3 \amp 2 \amp 2 \\ -1 \amp 0 \amp 4 \\ \end{array}\right]\) and \(\bvec=\threevec{1}{7}{-3}\text{.}\)
    2. We have
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 2 \amp -1 \amp 1 \\ 3 \amp 2 \amp 2 \amp 7 \\ -1 \amp 0 \amp 4 \amp -3 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 3 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \end{array}\right] \end{equation*}
      so there is a unique solution \(\xvec=\threevec{3}{-1}{0}\text{.}\)

    18.2.6.2.

    Answer.
    \(\xvec\in\real^{2201}\) and \(A\xvec\in\real^{135}\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    If \(A\xvec\) is defined, then \(\xvec\in\real^{2201}\) and \(A\xvec\in\real^{135}\text{.}\)

    18.2.6.3.

    Answer.
    1. Both \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2\) are three-dimensional.
    2. \(A\twovec{1}{0} = \vvec_1\) and \(A\twovec{0}{1} = \vvec_2\text{.}\) Also, \(A\twovec{2}{3} = 2\vvec_1+3\vvec_3\text{.}\)
    3. \(\displaystyle A = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 3 \amp 0 \\ -2 \amp 3 \\ 1 \amp 2 \\ \end{array}\right]\)
    Solution.
    1. Both \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2\) are three-dimensional.
    2. \(A\twovec{1}{0} = \vvec_1\) and \(A\twovec{0}{1} = \vvec_2\text{.}\) Also, \(A\twovec{2}{3} = 2\vvec_1+3\vvec_3\text{.}\)
    3. \(\displaystyle A = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 3 \amp 0 \\ -2 \amp 3 \\ 1 \amp 2 \\ \end{array}\right]\)

    18.2.6.4.

    Answer.
    1. \(A\) is a \(2\times2\) matrix.
    2. We have
    3. There is a unique vector \(\xvec=\twovec{-3}{-3}\text{.}\)
    4. There is a unique vector \(\xvec=\twovec{0}{0}\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. \(A\) is a \(2\times2\) matrix.
    2. We have
    3. There is a unique vector \(\xvec=\twovec{-3}{-3}\text{.}\)
    4. There is a unique vector \(\xvec=\twovec{0}{0}\text{.}\)

    18.2.6.5.

    Answer.
    1. \(\displaystyle \xvec=\threevec{-2x_3}{x_3}{x_3} = x_3\threevec{-2}{1}{1}\text{.}\)
    2. There are many possibilities. For instance, \(B = \left[\begin{array}{rr} -2 \amp 2 \\ 1 \amp -1 \\ 1 \amp -1 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. We construct the augmented matrix
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ 2 \amp 2 \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ -1 \amp -3 \amp 1 \amp 0 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \end{array}\right]\text{,} \end{equation*}
      which shows that
      \begin{equation*} \xvec=\threevec{-2x_3}{x_3}{x_3} = x_3\threevec{-2}{1}{1}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    2. We form \(B\) by choosing two vectors in the solution space to \(A\xvec=\zerovec\text{.}\) For instance, \(B = \left[\begin{array}{rr} -2 \amp 2 \\ 1 \amp -1 \\ 1 \amp -1 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.}\)

    18.2.6.6.

    Answer.
    1. \(A\xvec = \threevec{-11}{-2}{13}\text{.}\)
    2. \(\xvec=\fourvec{9-2x_4}{-1+x_4}{2-x_4}{x_4} =\fourvec{9}{-1}{2}{0}+x_4\fourvec{-2}{1}{-1}{1}\text{.}\)
    3. We see that \(A \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} {\mathbf 1} \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp {\mathbf 1} \amp 0 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp {\mathbf 1} \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.}\)
    4. No
    5. The solution space will form a line in \(\real^4\text{,}\) as in part b.
    Solution.
    1. \(A\xvec = \threevec{-11}{-2}{13}\text{.}\)
    2. We consider the augmented matrix
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rrrr|r} 1 \amp 2 \amp -4 \amp -4 \amp -1 \\ 2 \amp 3 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 15 \\ 1 \amp 0 \amp 4 \amp 6 \amp 17 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrrr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 2 \amp 9 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp -1 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp 2 \end{array}\right] \end{equation*}
      so that \(\xvec=\fourvec{9-2x_4}{-1+x_4}{2-x_4}{x_4} =\fourvec{9}{-1}{2}{0}+x_4\fourvec{-2}{1}{-1}{1}\text{.}\)
    3. We see that \(A \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} {\mathbf 1} \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp {\mathbf 1} \amp 0 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp {\mathbf 1} \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.}\)
    4. There is no vector \(\bvec\) such that \(A\xvec=\bvec\) is inconsistent because the augmented matrix \(\left[\begin{array}{r|r} A \amp \bvec \end{array}\right]\) cannot have a pivot position in the rightmost column.
    5. The coefficient matrix \(\left[\begin{array}{r|r} A \amp \bvec \end{array}\right]\) will have exactly one column without a pivot position. Therefore, the solution space will form a line in \(\real^4\text{,}\) as in part b.

    18.2.6.7.

    Answer.
    1. To scale the third row by \(-3\text{,}\) we would use the matrix \(S= \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp -3 \\ \end{array}\right] \text{.}\)
    2. To interchange the first and third rows, we would use \(P= \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] \text{.}\)
    3. To multiply the first row by 3 and add to the third row, we would use \(L_2= \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 3 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] \text{.}\)
    4. \(L= \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ -2 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ -1 \amp 2 \amp 1 \end{array}\right] \text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. We compute that
      \begin{equation*} SA = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 7 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 2 \amp -1 \\ 2 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ -3 \amp 2 \amp 3 \\ \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 2 \amp -1 \\ 14 \amp 0 \amp 14 \\ -3 \amp 2 \amp 3 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{equation*}
      To scale the third row by \(-3\text{,}\) we would use the matrix \(S= \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp -3 \\ \end{array}\right] \text{.}\)
    2. We compute that
      \begin{equation*} PA = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 2 \amp -1 \\ 2 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ -3 \amp 2 \amp 3 \\ \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 2 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp -1 \\ -3 \amp 2 \amp 3 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{equation*}
      To interchange the first and third rows, we would use \(P= \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] \text{.}\)
    3. We compute that
      \begin{equation*} L_1A = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ -2 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 2 \amp -1 \\ 2 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ -3 \amp 2 \amp 3 \\ \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 2 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp -4 \amp 4 \\ -3 \amp 2 \amp 3 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{equation*}
      To multiply the first row by 3 and add to the third row, we would use \(L_2= \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 3 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] \text{.}\)
    4. Keeping track of the operations we perform in Gaussian elimination, we define
      \begin{equation*} \begin{array}{cc} L_1= \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ -2 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right], \amp L_2= \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 3 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right], \\ L_3 = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 2 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{array} \end{equation*}
      Then \(L_3L_2L_1A = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 2 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp -4 \amp 4 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 8 \\ \end{array}\right] \text{.}\) So \(L=L_3L_2L_1 = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ -2 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ -1 \amp 2 \amp 1 \end{array}\right] \text{.}\)

    18.2.6.8.

    Answer.
    1. \(\displaystyle B = \left[ \begin{array}{rr} -1 \amp -2 \\ -2 \amp -3 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.}\)
    2. It is true, in this case, that \(AB=BA=I\text{.}\)
    3. \(I\xvec = \xvec\text{.}\)
    4. \(\xvec=B\bvec=\twovec{-1}{-4}\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. We find \(\bvec_1\) and \(\bvec_2\) by solving the equations
      \begin{equation*} A\bvec_1=\twovec{1}{0}, A\bvec_2=\twovec{0}{1}\text{.} \end{equation*}
      This gives
      \begin{equation*} B = \left[ \begin{array}{rr} -1 \amp -2 \\ -2 \amp -3 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{equation*}
    2. It is true, in this case, that \(AB=BA=I\text{.}\)
    3. We have seen that \(I\xvec = \xvec\text{.}\)
    4. If \(\bvec=\twovec{5}{-2}\text{,}\) then \(\xvec=B\bvec=\twovec{-1}{-4}\) is the solution to the equation \(A\xvec=\bvec\text{.}\)

    18.2.6.9.

    Answer.
    1. False
    2. True
    3. False
    4. True
    5. True
    Solution.
    1. False, the number of components of \(\xvec\) equals the number of columns of \(A\text{.}\)
    2. True. This is a result of Proposition18.2.4.
    3. False. The shape of \(A\) is \(8\times5\text{.}\)
    4. True, because the augmented matrix \(\left[\begin{array}{r|r} A \amp \bvec \end{array}\right]\) cannot have a pivot position in the rightmost column.
    5. True. Because there is not a pivot position in every row of \(A\text{,}\) the augmented matrix \(\left[\begin{array}{r|r} A \amp \bvec \end{array}\right]\) will have a pivot position in the rightmost column for some vectors \(\bvec\text{.}\)

    18.2.6.10.

    Answer.
    1. \(A \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] \text{.}\)
    2. No
    3. \(\xvec=\zerovec\text{.}\)
    4. Every equation \(A\xvec=\bvec\) has exactly one solution.
    Solution.
    1. Since the solution is unique, there must be a pivot position in every column of \(A\text{.}\) This means that there are four pivot positions so there is a pivot position in every row. In other words, \(A \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] \text{.}\)
    2. No, because \(A\) has a pivot in every row.
    3. There is only one solution, which is \(\xvec=\zerovec\text{.}\)
    4. If \(\bvec\) is a four-dimensional vector, then \(A\xvec=\bvec\) has a unique solution since \(A\) has a pivot position in every row and every column. This means that \(\bvec\) can be written as a linear combination of the columns of \(A\) in exactly one way.

    18.2.6.11.

    Answer.
    1. \(\xvec = x_3\threevec{-2}{-1}{1}\text{.}\)
    2. \(\xvec=\threevec{1}{-2}{0}+x_3\threevec{-2}{-1}{1}\text{.}\)
    3. Notice that \(A(\xvec_h + \xvec_p) = A\xvec_h + A\xvec_p = \zerovec + \bvec = \bvec\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. We have the augmented matrix
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 2 \amp 4 \amp 0 \\ -2 \amp 1 \amp -3 \amp 0 \\ 3 \amp 1 \amp 7 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] \end{equation*}
      so that \(\xvec = x_3\threevec{-2}{-1}{1}\text{.}\) The solution space is a line that passes through the origin.
    2. Now we have
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 2 \amp 4 \amp -3 \\ -2 \amp 1 \amp -3 \amp -4 \\ 3 \amp 1 \amp 7 \amp 1 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 2 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \end{array}\right] \end{equation*}
      so that \(\xvec=\threevec{1}{-2}{0}+x_3\threevec{-2}{-1}{1}\text{.}\) This is a line through \(\threevec{1}{-2}{0}\) parallel to \(\threevec{-2}{-1}{1}\text{.}\) Notice that this line is parallel to the line in part a.
    3. Notice that \(A(\xvec_h + \xvec_p) = A\xvec_h + A\xvec_p = \zerovec + \bvec = \bvec\text{.}\) This shows that if we add a vector from the solution space to \(A\xvec=\zerovec\) to a vector from the solution space to \(A\xvec=\bvec\text{,}\) we obtain a vector in the solution space to \(A\xvec=\bvec\text{.}\)

    18.2.6.12.

    Answer.
    1. We see that
      1. \(x_2 = \twovec{800}{200}\text{.}\)
      2. \(x_2 = \twovec{500}{500}\text{.}\)
    2. \(\xvec = \twovec{1000}{500}\text{.}\)
    3. \(\twovec{650}{350}\) represents the distribution of bicycles on Tuesday, \(\twovec{695}{305}\) represents the distribution of bicycles on Wednesday, and \(\twovec{708.5}{291.5}\) on Thursday.
    Solution.
    1. We see that
      1. \(x_2 = \twovec{800}{200}\text{.}\)
      2. \(x_2 = \twovec{500}{500}\text{.}\)
    2. We solve the equation \(A\xvec = \twovec{1050}{450}\) to obtain \(\xvec = \twovec{1000}{500}\text{.}\)
    3. If \(\xvec_1 = \twovec{500}{500}\) represents the distribution of bicycles on Monday, then \(\xvec_2=A\xvec_1 = \twovec{650}{350}\) represents the distribution of bicycles on Tuesday, \(\xvec_3=A\xvec_2=\twovec{695}{305}\) represents the distribution of bicycles on Wednesday, and \(\xvec_4=A\xvec_3=\twovec{708.5}{291.5}\) on Thursday.

    18.2.6.13.

    Answer.
    1. \(A\vvec_1 = \twovec{5}{2} = \vvec_1\) and \(A\vvec_2 = \twovec{-0.3}{0.3} = 0.3\vvec_2\text{.}\)
    2. We have
      \begin{equation*} \begin{array}{rl} \xvec_2=A\xvec_1 = \amp A(c_1\vvec_1+c_2\vvec_2) \\ =\amp c_1A\vvec_1 + c_2A\vvec_2 = c_1\vvec_1 +0.3c_2\vvec_2\text{.} \end{array} \end{equation*}
    3. \begin{equation*} \begin{array}{rl} \xvec_3=A\xvec_2=\amp A(c_1\vvec_1+0.3c_2\vvec_2) \\ = \amp c_1A\vvec_1 +0.3c_2A\vvec_2 = c_1\vvec_1 +0.3^2c_2\vvec_2\text{.} \end{array} \end{equation*}
      and so on.
    4. We find that
      \begin{equation*} \xvec_1=\twovec{500}{500} = \frac{1000}{7}\vvec_1 + \frac{1500}{7}\vvec_2\text{.} \end{equation*}
    5. Then
      \begin{equation*} \begin{array}{l} \xvec_2=\frac{1000}{7}\vvec_1 + 0.3\frac{1500}{7}\vvec{2}, \\ \xvec_3=\frac{1000}{7}\vvec_1 + 0.3^2\frac{1500}{7}\vvec{2}, \\ \xvec_4=\frac{1000}{7}\vvec_1 + 0.3^3\frac{1500}{7}\vvec{2}\text{.} \end{array} \end{equation*}
    6. After a very long time, the second term becomes increasingly close to zero and so
      \begin{equation*} \xvec\approx\frac{1000}{7}\vvec_1 = \twovec{5000/7}{2000/7} = \twovec{714.3}{285.7}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    Solution.
    1. \(A\vvec_1 = \twovec{5}{2} = \vvec_1\) and \(A\vvec_2 = \twovec{-0.3}{0.3} = 0.3\vvec_2\text{.}\)
    2. We have
      \begin{equation*} \begin{array}{rl} \xvec_2=A\xvec_1 = \amp A(c_1\vvec_1+c_2\vvec_2) \\ =\amp c_1A\vvec_1 + c_2A\vvec_2 = c_1\vvec_1 +0.3c_2\vvec_2\text{.} \end{array} \end{equation*}
    3. \begin{equation*} \begin{array}{rl} \xvec_3=A\xvec_2=\amp A(c_1\vvec_1+0.3c_2\vvec_2) \\ = \amp c_1A\vvec_1 -0.3c_2A\vvec_2 = c_1\vvec_1 +0.3^2c_2\vvec_2\text{.} \end{array} \end{equation*}
      and so on.
    4. We find that
      \begin{equation*} \xvec_1=\twovec{500}{500} = \frac{1000}{7}\vvec_1 + \frac{1500}{7}\vvec_2\text{.} \end{equation*}
    5. Then
      \begin{equation*} \begin{array}{l} \xvec_2=\frac{1000}{7}\vvec_1 + 0.3\frac{1500}{7}\vvec{2}, \\ \xvec_3=\frac{1000}{7}\vvec_1 + 0.3^2\frac{1500}{7}\vvec{2}, \\ \xvec_4=\frac{1000}{7}\vvec_1 + 0.3^3\frac{1500}{7}\vvec{2}\text{.} \end{array} \end{equation*}
    6. After a very long time, the second term becomes increasingly close to zero and so
      \begin{equation*} \xvec\approx\frac{1000}{7}\vvec_1 = \twovec{5000/7}{2000/7} = \twovec{714.3}{285.7}\text{.} \end{equation*}

    18.3 The span of a set of vectors
    18.3.1 The span of a set of vectors

    Activity 18.3.2.

    Solution.
    1. For the first set of vectors, we find:
      1. We can form the linear combinations:
        • When \(c = 2\) and \(d=0\text{,}\) the linear combination is \(\twovec{2}{4}\text{.}\)
        • When \(c = 1\) and \(d=1\text{,}\) the linear combination is \(\twovec{-1}{-2}\text{.}\)
        • When \(c = 0\) and \(d=-1\text{,}\) the linear combination is \(\twovec{2}{4}\text{.}\)
      2. Yes, we saw that there are at least two ways. For instance, when the weights are \(c=2\) and \(d=0\text{.}\) This means that \(\twovec24\) is in the span of \(\vvec\) and \(\wvec\text{.}\)
      3. No. No matter how we change the weights, the linear combination lies on the line through \(\vvec\) and \(\wvec\text{.}\) This means that \(\twovec{3}{0}\) is not in the span of \(\vvec\) and \(\wvec\text{.}\)
      4. The span of \(\vvec\) and \(\wvec\) is the set of all vectors on the line through \(\vvec\text{.}\)
      5. If the equation has a solution, \(\bvec\) must lie on the line defined by \(\vvec\text{.}\)
    2. For the second set of vectors, we have:
      1. We can form the linear combinations:
        • When \(c = 2\) and \(d=0\text{,}\) the linear combination is \(\twovec42\text{.}\)
        • When \(c = 1\) and \(d=1\text{,}\) the linear combination is \(\twovec{3}{3}\text{.}\)
        • When \(c = 0\) and \(d=-1\text{,}\) the linear combination is \(\twovec{-1}{-2}\text{.}\)
      2. Yes. Using the diagram, we see that \(\twovec{-2}{2}=-2\vvec + 2\wvec\text{.}\) This means that \(\twovec{-2}{2}\) is in the span of \(\vvec\) and \(\wvec\text{.}\)
      3. Yes. Using the diagram, we see that \(\twovec{3}{0}=2\vvec-1\wvec\text{.}\) This means that \(\twovec{3}{0}\) is in the span of \(\vvec\) and \(\wvec\text{.}\)
      4. Every two-dimensional vector is in the span of \(\vvec\) and \(\wvec\text{.}\)
      5. The equation has a solution for every \(\bvec\text{.}\)

    18.3.2 Pivot positions and span

    Activity 18.3.3.

    Solution.
    1. \(\laspan{\vvec}\) is the line defined by \(\vvec\text{.}\)
    2. \(\laspan{\evec_1,\evec_2}\) is the \(xy\)-plane.
    3. For the linear system to be consistent, we need \(b_3=0\text{,}\) which means that the third coordinate of the vector \(\bvec\) must be 0 for \(\bvec\) to be in \(\laspan{\evec_1,\evec_2}\text{.}\) In other words, \(\bvec\) must lie in the \(xy\)-plane.
    4. We consider the two cases.
      1. We have the augmented matrix
        \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp -2 \\ -1 \amp 1 \amp 4 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \end{array}\right]\text{,} \end{equation*}
        which shows that the system is inconsistent. Therefore, \(\bvec\) is not in \(\laspan{\vvec_1, \vvec_2}\text{.}\)
      2. We have the augmented matrix
        \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ -1 \amp 1 \amp 3 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \end{array}\right]\text{,} \end{equation*}
        which shows that the system is consistent. Therefore, \(\bvec\) is in \(\laspan{\vvec_1, \vvec_2}\text{.}\)
      3. The span is the plane in \(\real^3\) defined by \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2\text{.}\)
    5. We have the reduced row echelon form
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp -2 \\ -1 \amp 1 \amp 4 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{equation*}
      Since there is a pivot position in every row, this says that every equation \(A\xvec=\bvec\) is consistent. The \(\laspan{\vvec_1, \vvec_2, \vvec_3}\) is therefore \(\real^3\text{.}\)
    6. There must be a pivot position in every row.
    7. If a set of vectors spans \(\real^3\text{,}\) its corresponding matrix must have a pivot position in every row. Because there can be at most one pivot position in a column, there must be at least three columns. Therefore, the smallest number of vectors that span \(\real^3\) is three.

    18.3.4 Exercises

    18.3.4.1.

    Answer.
    1. \(\laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2} = \real^2\text{.}\)
    2. For the following vectors,
      1. \(\bvec\) is in \(\laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3}\text{.}\)
      2. \(\vvec_3\) is in \(\laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3}\text{.}\)
      3. \(\bvec\) is not in \(\laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3}\text{.}\)
      4. \(\laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3}\) is a plane in \(\real^3\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. The equation \(\left[\begin{array}{rr} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \end{array}\right] ~\xvec = \bvec\) is consistent so \(\bvec\) is in \(\laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2}\text{.}\) Since \(\left[\begin{array}{rr} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \end{array}\right]\) has a pivot position in every row, \(\laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2}\) is \(\real^2\text{.}\)
    2. Lets consider the following vectors.
      1. The equation \(\left[\begin{array}{rrr}\vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \vvec_3 \end{array}\right]~\xvec = \bvec\) is consistent so \(\bvec\) is in \(\laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3}\text{.}\)
      2. The vector \(\vvec_3\) is in \(\laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2}\) because \(\vvec_3 = \vvec_1-2\vvec_2\text{.}\)
      3. The equation \(\left[\begin{array}{rrr}\vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \vvec_3 \end{array}\right]~\xvec = \bvec\) is not consistent so \(\bvec\) is not in \(\laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3}\text{.}\)
      4. \(\laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3}\) is the plane defined by \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2\text{.}\)

    18.3.4.2.

    Answer.
    1. Yes
    2. Yes
    3. \(\laspan{\zerovec,\zerovec,\ldots,\zerovec}\) consists only of the vector \(\zerovec\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. Yes, because \(\zerovec = 0\vvec_1+0\vvec_2+\ldots+0\vvec_n\text{.}\)
    2. Yes, \(\xvec=\zerovec\) is a solution to the equation \(A\xvec=\zerovec\text{.}\)
    3. \(\laspan{\zerovec,\zerovec,\ldots,\zerovec}\) consists only of the vector \(\zerovec\text{.}\)

    18.3.4.3.

    Answer.
    1. \(\bvec\) must be a scalar multiple of \(\twovec{3}{-2}\text{.}\)
    2. \(\bvec\) can be any vector in \(\real^2\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. \(\left[\begin{array}{rr} 3 \amp -6 \\ -2 \amp 4 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right]\) so \(\bvec\) must be on the line defined by \(\twovec{3}{-2}\text{.}\)
    2. \(\left[\begin{array}{rr} 3 \amp -6 \\ -2 \amp 2 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right]\) so \(\bvec\) can be any vector in \(\real^2\text{.}\)

    18.3.4.4.

    Answer.
    The columns of \(A\) do not span \(\real^4\text{.}\) The columns of \(B\) do.
    Solution.
    1. The reduced row echelon form of \(A\) is
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 3 \amp 0 \amp -1 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp -1 \amp 3 \amp 7 \\ 3 \amp -2 \amp 1 \amp 5 \\ -1 \amp 2 \amp 2 \amp 3 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \end{array}\right] \end{equation*}
      so the columns of \(A\) do not span \(\real^4\text{.}\)
    2. The reduced row echelon form of \(B\) is
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 3 \amp 0 \amp -1 \amp 4 \\ 1 \amp -1 \amp 3 \amp -1 \\ 3 \amp -2 \amp 1 \amp 3 \\ -1 \amp 2 \amp 2 \amp 1 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \end{array}\right] \end{equation*}
      so the columns of \(B\) span \(\real^4\text{.}\)

    18.3.4.5.

    Answer.
    1. True
    2. True
    3. False
    4. True
    5. False
    Solution.
    1. True. If \(\xvec\) is a solution to \(A\xvec=\bvec\text{,}\) then the components of \(\xvec\) are weights whose linear combination is \(\bvec\text{.}\)
    2. True, because \(x=\fourvec{1}{0}{\vdots}{0}\) is a solution.
    3. False. The span could be a smaller set.
    4. True. This is the definition of the span.
    5. False. The span is a set of vectors in \(\real^{8032}\text{.}\)

    18.3.4.6.

    Answer.
    We will choose matrices in reduced row echelon form.
    1. \(\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] \text{.}\)
    2. \(\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] \text{.}\)
    3. \(\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 3 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] \text{.}\)
    Solution.
    We will choose matrices in reduced row echelon form.
    1. \(\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] \text{.}\)
    2. \(\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] \text{.}\)
    3. \(\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 3 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] \text{.}\)

    18.3.4.7.

    Answer.
    1. Yes
    2. No
    3. Yes
    4. \(\displaystyle n\geq 438\)
    5. No
    Solution.
    1. Yes. Because the span is \(\real^8\text{,}\) every vector in \(\real^8\) can be written as a linear combination of the vectors.
    2. No. The matrix \(A=\left[\begin{array}{rrrr} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \ldots \amp \vvec_{10} \end{array} \right]\) must have a column without a pivot position. Therefore, any equation \(A\xvec=\bvec\) has infinitely many solutions.
    3. Yes, because \(\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right]\) has a pivot position in every row.
    4. There must be at least 438 vectors so \(n\geq438\text{.}\)
    5. No, because we need at least 20 vectors to span \(\real^{20}\text{.}\)

    18.3.4.8.

    Answer.
    1. \(\displaystyle 3\times5\)
    2. No
    3. Yes
    Solution.
    1. \(AB\) is a \(3\times5\) matrix.
    2. No. Since the columns of \(A\) span \(\real^3\text{,}\) then the equation \(A\yvec=\bvec\) has a solution \(\yvec\) for every vector \(\bvec\text{.}\) However, we may not be able to solve the equation \(B\xvec=\yvec\) if the columns of \(B\) do not span \(\real^4\text{.}\)
    3. Yes. If we are given a vector \(\bvec\) in \(\real^3\text{,}\) we can find a vector \(\yvec\) such that \(A\yvec = \bvec\) since the columns of \(A\) span \(\real^3\text{.}\) Since the columns of \(B\) span \(\real^4\text{,}\) we can find a vector \(\xvec\) such that \(B\xvec=\yvec\text{.}\) Then \(AB\xvec = \bvec\text{,}\) which means that \(B\) is the span of the columns of \(AB\text{.}\)

    18.3.4.9.

    Answer.
    1. There is a pivot position in each row and each column.
    2. The span is \(\real^{12}\text{.}\)
    3. There is a unique solution.
    4. There is a unique solution \(\xvec=\zerovec.\)
    Solution.
    1. Since the solution is unique, each column of \(A\) must have a pivot position. Since there are also 12 rows, each row must have a pivot position as well. This means that the row reduced echelon form of \(A\) is the identity matrix.
    2. Since there is a pivot position in every row, the span of the columns of \(A\) is \(\real^{12}\text{.}\)
    3. There is a unique solution to the equation because \(A\) has a pivot position in every row and every column.
    4. There is a unique solution \(\xvec=\zerovec\text{.}\)

    18.3.4.10.

    Answer.
    1. Yes
    2. We have
      \begin{equation*} \begin{array}{rl} a\vvec_1+b\vvec_2+c\vvec_3 \amp = a\vvec_1 + b\vvec_2+c(-\vvec_1+2\vvec_2) \\ \amp = (a-c)\vvec_1+(b+2c)\vvec_2\text{.} \end{array} \end{equation*}
    3. As seen in the last part of this problem, every linear combination of \(\vvec_1\text{,}\) \(\vvec_2\text{,}\) and \(\vvec_3\) can be rewritten as a linear combination of \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. Yes, because \(\vvec_3=-\vvec_1+2\vvec_2\text{.}\)
    2. We have
      \begin{equation*} \begin{array}{rl} a\vvec_1+b\vvec_2+c\vvec_3 \amp = a\vvec_1 + b\vvec_2+c(-\vvec_1+2\vvec_2) \\ \amp = (a-c)\vvec_1+(b+2c)\vvec_2\text{.} \end{array} \end{equation*}
    3. As seen in the last part of this problem, every linear combination of \(\vvec_1\text{,}\) \(\vvec_2\text{,}\) and \(\vvec_3\) can be rewritten as a linear combination of \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2\text{.}\)

    18.3.4.11.

    Answer.
    1. \(\laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3}\) is the plane defined by \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2\text{.}\)
    2. \(2a-4b+c=0\text{.}\)
    3. There would be two equations involving the variables \(a\text{,}\) \(b\text{,}\) and \(c\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. Finding the reduced row echelon form
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 2 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ -2 \amp 0 \amp 2 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \end{array}\right] \end{equation*}
      shows that \(\vvec_3\) is a linear combination of \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2\text{.}\) Therefore, \(\laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3}\) is the plane defined by \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2\text{.}\)
    2. We see that
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 2 \amp 1 \amp a \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp b \\ -2 \amp 0 \amp 2 \amp c \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 2 \amp 1 \amp a \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp b \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 2a-4b+c \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{equation*}
      If the equation is consistent, we must have \(2a-4b+c=0\text{.}\) The solution space is the plane defined by \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2\text{.}\)
    3. In that case, there would be two equations involving the variables \(a\text{,}\) \(b\text{,}\) and \(c\text{,}\) and the solution space would be a line.

    18.4 Linear independence
    18.4.2 How to recognize linear dependence

    Activity 18.4.2.

    Solution.
    1. Lets focus on the first three vectors and view the matrix as an augmented one:
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rr|r} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \vvec_3 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{equation*}
      This shows that \(\vvec_3=-\vvec_1+2\vvec_2\) so it is possible to write one of the vectors as a linear combination of the others. Therefore, the set is linearly dependent.
    2. Applying the same reasoning as in the previous part, we see that we cannot write any of the vectors as a linear combination of the others. Therefore, the set is linearly independent.
    3. The columns of a matrix are linearly independent exactly when there is a pivot position in every column of the matrix.
    4. No, because we can write the zero vector \(\zerovec\) as a linear combination of the other vectors: \(\zerovec = 0\vvec_2 + \ldots + 0\vvec_n\text{.}\)
    5. No, because the matrix formed by the vectors would have 12 columns and only 10 rows. There can be at most 10 pivot positions so there are at least two columns without pivot positions.

    18.4.3 Homogeneous equations

    Activity 18.4.3. Linear independence and homogeneous equations.

    Solution.
    1. The vector \(\zerovec\) is always a solution.
    2. We have
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 3 \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ -1 \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ 2 \amp 1 \amp 1 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -3 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \end{array}\right]. \end{equation*}
      From the reduced row echelon form, we see that \(x_3\) is a free variable and that we have
      \begin{equation*} \begin{alignedat}{2} x_1 \amp {}={} -2x_3 \\ x_2 \amp {}={} 3x_3\text{.} \\ \end{alignedat} \end{equation*}
      The solution space is then written parametrically as
      \begin{equation*} \xvec=\threevec{x_1}{x_2}{x_3} = x_3\threevec{-2}{3}{1}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    3. If we set \(x_3=1\text{,}\) then we have the solution \(\xvec=\threevec{-2}{3}{1}\text{,}\) which says that
      \begin{equation*} -2\vvec_1+3\vvec_2+\vvec_3 = \zerovec\text{.} \end{equation*}
    4. We may rewrite this expression as \(\vvec_3=2\vvec_1-3\vvec_2\text{,}\) showing that \(\vvec_3\) is a linear combination of \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2\text{.}\)
    5. The vectors \(\vvec_1\text{,}\) \(\vvec_2\text{,}\) and \(\vvec_3\) are linearly dependent, and we know this in two ways. We have seen how to express one vector as a linear combination of the others. Also, we have seen that the associated matrix has a column without a pivot position.

    18.4.5 Exercises

    18.4.5.1.

    Answer.
    1. Four vectors in \(\real^3\) must always be linearly dependent.
    2. \(\vvec_3 = 2\vvec_1-\vvec_2\text{.}\)
    3. \(c_1=-2\text{,}\) \(c_2=1\text{,}\) \(c_3=1\text{,}\) and \(c_4=0\)
    4. \(\displaystyle \xvec = \fourvec{-2}{1}{1}{0}\)
    Solution.
    1. We view the vectors as the columns of a matrix so that
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 2 \amp -2 \\ 2 \amp 1 \amp 3 \amp 4 \\ 1 \amp 3 \amp -1 \amp -1 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{equation*}
      Since there is a column without a pivot position, the vectors must be linearly dependent. We also expect this because four vectors in \(\real^3\) must always be linearly dependent.
    2. If we view the first three columns as an augmented matrix, we have
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ 2 \amp 1 \amp 3 \\ 1 \amp 3 \amp -1 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{equation*}
      We see that \(\vvec_3 = 2\vvec_1-\vvec_2\text{.}\)
    3. From the solution to the previous part, we have \(-2\vvec_1+\vvec_2+\vvec_3 = \zerovec\text{,}\) which says that \(c_1=-2\text{,}\) \(c_2=1\text{,}\) \(c_3=1\text{,}\) and \(c_4=0\) is an appropriate choice of weights.
    4. From the solution to the previous part, we see that \(\xvec = \fourvec{-2}{1}{1}{0}\) is a solution of the homogeneous equation.

    18.4.5.2.

    Answer.
    1. Linearly independent.
    2. \(\laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3} = \real^3\text{.}\)
    3. Because \(\laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3} = \real^3\text{,}\) every vector in \(\real^3\) can be written as a linear combination of \(\vvec_1\text{,}\) \(\vvec_2\text{,}\) and \(\vvec_3\text{.}\)
    4. In exactly one way.
    Solution.
    1. Viewing the vectors as the columns of a matrix, we have
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 2 \amp 1 \amp 2 \\ -1 \amp 2 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 3 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{equation*}
      Since there is a pivot position in every column, the vectors are linearly independent.
    2. Since the matrix has a pivot position in every row, we see that \(\laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3} = \real^3\text{.}\)
    3. Because \(\laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3} = \real^3\text{,}\) every vector in \(\real^3\) can be written as a linear combination of \(\vvec_1\text{,}\) \(\vvec_2\text{,}\) and \(\vvec_3\text{.}\)
    4. In exactly one way. Because the matrix has a pivot position in every column, there cannot be a free variable.

    18.4.5.3.

    Answer.
    1. Yes
    2. Any subset is linearly independent.
    3. They form a linearly independent set.
    Solution.
    1. Yes. If \(c_1\vvec_1 + c_2\vvec_2 = \zerovec\) and one of the weights is not zero, we can rearrange this expression to solve for one of the vectors as a scalar multiple of the other. For instance, if \(2\vvec_1-3\vvec_2=\zerovec\text{,}\) then \(\vvec_1 = \frac32\vvec_2\text{.}\)
    2. Any subset of the vectors forms a linearly independent set. Because the original set is linearly independent, none of the vectors can be written as a linear combination of the others. This is still true when we look at a smaller set of the vectors.
    3. The set of vectors \(\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n,\bvec\) will also be linearly independent. Since \(A\xvec=\bvec\) is inconsistent, we know that \(\bvec\) cannot be written as a linear combination of the other vectors. We also know that each of the vectors \(\vvec_j\) cannot be written as a linear combination of the others because \(\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n\) is a linearly independent set.

    18.4.5.4.

    Answer.
    1. False
    2. True
    3. False
    4. True
    5. True
    Solution.
    1. False. We only know that one vector can be written as a linear combination of the others.
    2. True. If we put the vectors into a matrix, there are more columns than rows. Therefore, there must be a column without a pivot position so the vectors form a linearly dependent set.
    3. False. They could form a linearly independent set, but we cannot guarantee it. We would have to look at the location of the pivot positions in the associated \(10\times5\) matrix.
    4. True. In this case, \(\vvec_2\) can be written as a linear combination of the other vectors so the set is linearly dependent.
    5. True. Since the vectors are linearly independent, \(A\) has a pivot position in every column. Therefore, there is not a free variable in the description of the solution space to the equation \(A\xvec=\bvec\text{.}\) Therefore, the solution is unique.

    18.4.5.5.

    Answer.
    1. \(\displaystyle \xvec=\fourvec{2}{-1}{3}{1}\)
    2. There are infinitely many solutions to the homogeneous equation \(A\xvec=\zerovec\text{.}\)
    3. \(\vvec_4 = -2\vvec_1 + \vvec_2 - 3\vvec_3\text{.}\)
    4. One vector can be written as a linear combination of the others.
    Solution.
    1. The vector \(\xvec=\fourvec{2}{-1}{3}{1}\) is a solution.
    2. There is a nonzero solution to the homogeneous equation \(A\xvec=\zerovec\text{.}\) Since there is also the zero solution \(\xvec=\zerovec\text{,}\) there must be infinitely many solutions. This can only happen when there is a column of \(A\) that does not have a pivot position.
    3. \(\vvec_4 = -2\vvec_1 + \vvec_2 - 3\vvec_3\text{.}\)
    4. Because one of the vectors can be written as a linear combination of the others, the set of vectors is linearly dependent.

    18.4.5.6.

    Answer.
    1. There must be at least 27 vectors.
    2. There must be at most 27 vectors.
    3. There are exactly 27 vectors.
    4. There is exactly one solution.
    Solution.
    1. In this case, the matrix \(A\) must have a pivot position in evey row. There must be at least 27 vectors for this to be possible.
    2. In this case, the matrix \(A\) must have a pivot position in every column. There must be at most 27 vectors for this to be possible.
    3. There must be exactly 27 vectors.
    4. There is exactly one solution to the equation \(A\xvec=\bvec\) because the matrix \(A\) has a pivot position in every row and every column.

    18.4.5.7.

    Answer.
    1. \(\left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] \text{.}\)
    2. \(\left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] \text{.}\)
    3. This is not possible.
    4. This is not possible.
    5. \(\left[\begin{array}{rrrrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 4 \\ \end{array}\right] \text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. There must be a pivot position in every column: \(\left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] \text{.}\)
    2. There must be a pivot position in every row. \(\left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] \text{.}\)
    3. This is not possible. The matrix \(A\) has dimensions \(4\times 3\) so there cannot be a pivot position in every row.
    4. This is not possible. The matrix \(A\) has dimensions \(3\times5\) so there cannot be a pivot position in every column.
    5. There must be a pivot position in every row. \(\left[\begin{array}{rrrrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 4 \\ \end{array}\right] \text{.}\)

    18.4.5.8.

    Answer.
    1. They are linearly dependent.
    2. The columns of \(B\) and \(C\) are all equal.
    Solution.
    1. Since \(B\neq0\text{,}\) there is a column of \(B\text{,}\) which well call \(\xvec\text{,}\) that is not zero. Since \(AB = 0\text{,}\) we know that \(A\xvec = \zerovec\text{,}\) which means that \(\xvec\) is a nonzero solution to the homogenous equation \(A\xvec = \zerovec\text{.}\) Therefore, the columns of \(A\) are linearly dependent.
    2. Since the columns of \(A\) are linearly independent, the only solution to the homogeneous equation \(A\xvec=\zerovec\) is \(\xvec=\zerovec\text{.}\) Since that \(A(B-C) = 0\text{,}\) every column \(\xvec\) of \(B-C\) satisfies \(A\xvec = \zerovec\text{.}\) Therefore, every column of \(B-C\) is the zero vector, which implies that \(B=C\text{.}\)

    18.4.5.9.

    Answer.
    1. \(k=3\text{.}\)
    2. \(k\neq3\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. We construct the matrix
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 2 \amp 4 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -2 \amp 2 \\ 1 \amp -1 \amp k \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp k-3 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{equation*}
      If the vectors are linearly dependent, we cannot have a pivot position in the third column. This means that \(k=3\text{.}\)
    2. If the vectors span \(\real^3\text{,}\) there must be a pivot in the third row, which means that \(k\neq 3\text{.}\)

    18.4.5.10.

    Answer.
    1. Any linear combination of \(\vvec_1\text{,}\) \(\vvec_2\text{,}\) and \(\wvec\) can be rewritten as a linear combination of \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2\text{.}\)
    2. \(\laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3,\vvec_4} = \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_4}\text{.}\)
    3. \(\laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3,\vvec_4} = \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2}\text{.}\)
    4. It is a plane in \(\real^3\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. If \(\wvec\) is a linear combination of \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2\text{,}\) then we can write \(\wvec=a\vvec_1+b\vvec_2\text{.}\) Then any linear combination of \(\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\wvec\) can be rewritten as
      \begin{equation*} c_1\vvec_1+c_2\vvec_2+c_3\wvec=(c_1+c_3a)\vvec_1 + (c_2+c_3b)\vvec_2\text{.} \end{equation*}
    2. We have
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 2 \amp 1 \amp -2 \amp 7 \\ -1 \amp 2 \amp 6 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 2 \amp 1 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp -2 \amp 3 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 2 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{equation*}
      This shows that \(\vvec_3 = -2\vvec_1+2\vvec_2\) and so \(\laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3,\vvec_4} = \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_4}\text{.}\)
    3. The remaining three vectors are linearly dependent because \(\vvec_4 = 3\vvec_1+\vvec_2\text{.}\) We therefore have \(\laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3,\vvec_4} = \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2}\text{.}\)
    4. The vectors \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2\) are linearly independent so their span is a plane in \(\real^3\text{.}\)

    18.5 Matrix transformations
    18.5.1 Matrix transformations

    Activity 18.5.2.

    Solution.
    1. If \(A = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 2 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 2 \end{array}\right]\text{,}\) then
      1. \(T\left(\twovec{1}{-2}\right) = A\twovec{1}{-2} = \twovec{0}{-3}\text{.}\)
      2. \(T\left(\twovec{1}{0}\right) = A\twovec{1}{0} = \twovec{2}{1}\text{.}\)
      3. \(T\left(\twovec{0}{1}\right) = A\twovec{0}{1} = \twovec{1}{2}\text{.}\)
      4. \(T\left(\twovec xy\right) = \twovec{2x+y}{x+2y}\text{.}\)
      5. We seek a vector \(\xvec\) such that \(T(\xvec) = A\xvec=\twovec{3}{0}\text{.}\) We can solve this equation to find the unique solution \(\xvec=\twovec{2}{-1}\text{.}\)
    2. Now if
      \begin{equation*} A=\left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 3 \amp 3 \amp -2 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 2 \amp 1 \amp -3 \\ -2 \amp 1 \amp 4 \amp -4 \end{array}\right]\text{,} \end{equation*}
      the matrix has dimensions \(3\times4\text{.}\)
      1. \(\xvec\) must be a four-dimensional vector.
      2. \(A\xvec\) must be a three-dimensional vector.
      3. For this matrix, we have \(T:\real^4\to\real^3\text{.}\) In general, if \(A\) is an \(m\times n\) matrix, \(T:\real^n\to\real^m\text{.}\)
      4. If we solve the homogeneous equation \(A\xvec=\zerovec\text{,}\) we find that \(\xvec=x_4\fourvec{-3}{2}{-1}{1}\text{.}\)
    3. \(T\left(\twovec{1}{0}\right) = \vvec_1\text{,}\) the first column of the matrix. Similarly, \(T\left(\twovec{0}{1}\right)\) gives the second column of the matrix.
    4. The matrix is \(A=\left[ \begin{array}{rr} 3 \amp 2 \\ -1 \amp 2 \\ 1 \amp -1 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.}\)

    Activity 18.5.3.

    Solution.
      1. Since both the inputs and the outputs of \(T\) are two-dimensional, it follows that \(T:\real^2\to\real^2\) and that \(A\) is a \(2\times2\) matrix.
      2. Since
        \begin{equation*} T\left(\twovec10\right) = \twovec01,~~~ T\left(\twovec01\right) = \twovec{-1}0, \end{equation*}
        we have \(A=\begin{bmatrix} 0 \amp -1 \\ 1 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{.}\)
      3. Multiplying \(T(\vvec) = A\vvec = \twovec{1}{-2}\text{,}\) which agrees with the vector shown in the figure.
      4. \(T\left(\twovec xy\right) = \twovec{-y}{x}\text{.}\)
      1. The shape of matrix \(A\) is \(3\times 2\text{,}\) and \(T:\real^2\to\real^3\text{.}\)
      2. \(T\left(\twovec10\right) = \threevec{10}{50}{30}\text{.}\)
      3. \(A = \begin{bmatrix} 10 \amp 20 \\ 50 \amp 30 \\ 30 \amp 30 \\ \end{bmatrix} \text{.}\)
      4. \(T\left(\twovec{120}{180}\right) = \threevec{4800}{11400}{9000}\text{.}\)
      5. We solve the equation \(T(\xvec) = A\xvec = \threevec{5060}{14310}{10470}\) to obtain \(\xvec = \twovec{192}{157}.\)
      6. No, you cannot guarantee this because the two columns of \(A\) cannot span \(\real^3\text{.}\) If we view an order received as a three-dimensional vector \(\bvec\text{,}\) then a solution to the equation \(A\xvec = \bvec\) tells us how long to operate the two bakeries to produce this order. However, since \(A\) is a \(3\times 2\) matrix, it must have a row without a pivot position, which means that the equation \(A\xvec = \bvec\) will be inconsistent for some vectors \(\bvec\text{.}\)

    18.5.2 Composing matrix transformations

    Activity 18.5.4.

    Solution.
      1. The matrix is \(B=AA=A^2 = \begin{bmatrix} -1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -1 \\ \end{bmatrix} \text{.}\)
      2. \((T\circ T)(\vvec) = A^2\vvec = \twovec21\text{.}\)
      3. The matrix associated to \(R\) is also \(A^2\) since rotating by \(90^\circ\) twice is the same as rotating once by \(180^\circ\text{.}\)
      4. \((T\circ T)(\xvec) = R(\xvec) = -\xvec\text{,}\) which makes sense because multiplying a vector by \(-1\) simply changes its direction.
      1. \(B = \begin{bmatrix} 4 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ 2 \amp 1 \amp 2 \\ \end{bmatrix} \text{.}\)
      2. \(S\left(\threevec{1200}{2850}{2250}\right) = B\threevec{1200}{2850}{2250} = \twovec{9900}{9750}\text{.}\)
      3. \(T\left(\twovec{75}{53}\right) = \threevec{1810}{5340}{3840}\) and \(S\left(\threevec{1810}{5340}{3840}\right) = \twovec{16430}{16640}\text{.}\)
      4. \((S\circ T)\) takes as input a vector \(\xvec\) that records the number of hours both bakeries operate and outputs a vector \((S\circ T)(\xvec)\) that tells us the total number of cups of flour and sugar used. The associated matrix is \(BA=\begin{bmatrix} 120 \amp 140 \\ 130 \amp 130 \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{.}\)
      5. We want to find the vector \(\xvec\) for which \((S\circ T)(\xvec) = BA\xvec = \twovec{5800}{5980}\text{.}\) Solving this equation gives \(\xvec=\twovec{32}{14}\text{.}\)

    18.5.3 Discrete Dynamical Systems

    Activity 18.5.5.

    Solution.
    1. If 1000 trucks begin at \(P\text{,}\) that evening we find that 70% of them are at \(P\) with the remaining 30% at \(Q\text{.}\) Therefore, \(T\left(\ctwovec{1000}{0}\right) = \twovec{700}{300}\text{.}\) Since \(T\left(\ctwovec{1000}{0}\right) = 1000A\twovec{1}{0}\text{,}\) we see that \(T\left(\twovec{1}{0}\right) = \twovec{0.7}{0.3}\text{.}\)
    2. In the same way, we see that \(T\left(\ctwovec{0}{1000}\right) = \twovec{500}{500}\) so that \(T\left(\twovec{0}{1}\right) = \twovec{0.5}{0.5}\text{.}\)
    3. The columns of \(A\) are \(T\left(\twovec{1}{0}\right)\) and \(T\left(\twovec{0}{1}\right)\) so that \(A=\left[\begin{array}{rr} 0.7 \amp 0.5 \\ 0.3 \amp 0.5 \\ \end{array}\right] \text{.}\)
    4. Evaluate \(T\left(\twovec{100}{900}\right) = A\twovec{100}{900} = \twovec{520}{480}\text{.}\)
    5. We solve \(T(\xvec) = A\xvec = \twovec{550}{450}\) to find \(\xvec=\twovec{250}{750}\text{.}\)
    6. We denote the distribution of trucks Monday morning by \(\xvec_0 = \ctwovec{0}{1000}\text{.}\)
      1. Monday evening, we have \(\xvec_1=A\xvec_0 = \twovec{500}{500}\text{.}\)
      2. Tuesday evening, we have \(\xvec_2=A\xvec_1 = \twovec{600}{400}\text{.}\)
      3. Wednesday evening, we have \(\xvec_3=A\xvec_2 = \twovec{620}{380}\text{.}\)
    7. The matrix is \(A^7 = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 0.625 \amp 0.625 \\ 0.375 \amp 0.375 \\ \end{array}\right] \text{.}\)

    18.5.5 Exercises

    18.5.5.1.

    Answer.
    1. \(T:\real^3\to\real^3\) and \(S:\real^3\to\real^2\text{.}\)
    2. \(\threevec{6}{-1}{-6}\text{.}\)
    3. \(\twovec{-4}{0}\text{.}\)
    4. \(\twovec{7}{-1}\text{.}\)
    5. \(\left[ \begin{array}{rrr} 2 \amp -3 \amp -2 \\ 5 \amp 6 \amp 6 \\ \end{array}\right] \text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. Since \(A\) is a \(3\times3\) matrix, we have \(T:\real^3\to\real^3\text{.}\) Since \(B\) is a \(2\times3\) matrix, we have \(S:\real^3\to\real^2\text{.}\)
    2. \(T\left(\threevec{1}{-3}{2}\right) = A\threevec{1}{-3}{2} = \threevec{6}{-1}{-6}\text{.}\)
    3. \(S\left(\threevec{-2}{2}{1}\right) = A\threevec{-2}{2}{1}= \twovec{-4}{0}\text{.}\)
    4. \(S\circ T\left(\threevec{1}{-3}{2}\right) = BA\threevec{1}{-3}{2} = \twovec{7}{-1}\text{.}\)
    5. \(C = BA = \left[ \begin{array}{rrr} 2 \amp -3 \amp -2 \\ 5 \amp 6 \amp 6 \\ \end{array}\right] \text{.}\)

    18.5.5.2.

    Answer.
    1. \(A=\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 3 \amp -1 \amp 4 \\ 0 \amp 5 \amp -1 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.}\)
    2. Because the first component has the term \(3x_1^4\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. The matrix \(A=\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 3 \amp -1 \amp 4 \\ 0 \amp 5 \amp -1 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.}\)
    2. Because the first component has the term \(3x_1^4\text{,}\) there is no matrix such that \(T(\xvec) = A\xvec\text{.}\)

    18.5.5.3.

    Answer.
    1. \(\xvec= x_3\threevec{2}{-1}{1}\text{.}\)
    2. There are no such vectors.
    3. \(\xvec=\threevec{-2}{-2}{0} + x_3\threevec{2}{-1}{1}\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. We have \(T(\xvec) = A\xvec = \zerovec\text{.}\) The reduced row echelon form of \(A\) is \(A \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.}\) Therefore, the solutions have the form \(\xvec=x_3\threevec{2}{-1}{1}\text{.}\)
    2. We see that
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 3 \amp 1 \amp -8 \\ -2 \amp 1 \amp 5 \amp 9 \\ 0 \amp 2 \amp 2 \amp 2 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp -2 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{equation*}
      Since this is an inconsistent system, there are no vectors \(\xvec\) satisfying the equation.
    3. In the same way, we have
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 3 \amp 1 \amp -8 \\ -2 \amp 1 \amp 5 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp 2 \amp 2 \amp -4 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp -2 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{equation*}
      This shows that \(\xvec=\threevec{-2}{-2}{0} + x_3\threevec{2}{-1}{1}\text{.}\)

    18.5.5.4.

    Answer.
    1. \(\twovec{1}{-1}\text{.}\)
    2. \(\vvec_2\text{.}\)
    3. \(\xvec=x_3\threevec{1}{1}{1}\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. \(T\left(\threevec{2}{1}{2}\right) = 2\vvec_1+\vvec_2+2\vvec_3 = \twovec{1}{-1}\text{.}\)
    2. \(T\left(\threevec{0}{1}{0}\right) = \vvec_2\text{.}\)
    3. The matrix that defines \(T\) is
      \begin{equation*} A = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \vvec_3 \\ \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 2 \amp -1 \amp -1 \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp -2 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -1 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{equation*}
      This shows that the solutions to \(T(\xvec) = A\xvec = \zerovec\) are \(\xvec=x_3\threevec{1}{1}{1}\text{.}\)

    18.5.5.5.

    Answer.
      1. We have \(T(\xvec) = \threevec{10x_1+20x_2}{50x_1+20x_2}{30x_1+30x_2} \text{.}\)
      2. \(10x_1 + 20x_2\text{.}\)
      3. Bakery 1 makes 10 cakes per hour and Bakery 2 makes 20.
      1. \(0.6x_1 + 0.7x_2 \text{.}\)
      2. \(\displaystyle 0.4x_1 + 0.3x_2\)
      3. \(T(\xvec) = \twovec{0.6x_1+0.7x_2}{0.4x_1+0.3x_2} \text{.}\)
      4. \(A = \begin{bmatrix} 0.6 \amp 0.7 \\ 0.4 \amp 0.3 \\ \end{bmatrix} \text{.}\)
    Solution.
      1. We have
        \begin{equation*} T(\xvec) = \begin{bmatrix} 10 \amp 20 \\ 50 \amp 30 \\ 30 \amp 30 \\ \end{bmatrix} \twovec{x_1}{x_2} = \threevec{10x_1+20x_2}{50x_1+20x_2}{30x_1+30x_2}. \end{equation*}
      2. The number of cakes produced is \(10x_1 + 20x_2\text{.}\)
      3. This is consistent with the given information because Bakery 1 produces cakes at the rate of 10 cakes per hour so the number of cakes it produces is \(10x_1\text{.}\) In the same way, the number of cakes produced by Bakery 2 is \(20x_2\) giving a total of \(10x_1 + 20x_2\text{.}\)
      1. Of the bicycles that begin at \(P\text{,}\) 60% of them end up at \(P\text{.}\) Therefore \(0.6x_1\) is the number of bicycles that begin at \(P\) and end at \(P\text{.}\) Similarly, 70% of the bicycles that begin at \(Q\) end up at \(P\) so this number is \(0.7x_2\text{.}\) Therefore, the total number of bicycles that end up at \(P\) is
        \begin{equation*} 0.6x_1 + 0.7x_2. \end{equation*}
      2. In the same way, the number of bicycles that end up at \(Q\) is
        \begin{equation*} 0.4x_1 + 0.3x_2. \end{equation*}
      3. This gives the matrix
        \begin{equation*} T(\xvec) = \twovec{0.6x_1+0.7x_2}{0.4x_1+0.3x_2} = \begin{bmatrix} 0.6 \amp 0.7 \\ 0.4 \amp 0.3 \\ \end{bmatrix} \xvec. \end{equation*}
