      Putting these operations together, we see that \(\det(A) = 2\det(U) = 0\text{.}\) In this case, \(A\) is not invertible because \(U\text{,}\) which has a row without a pivot position, is not invertible.
    8. Performing one of the three row operations either leaves the determinant unchanged (row replacement), changes its sign (interchange), or multiplies it by a nonzero number (scaling). Therefore, if we begin with a matrix whose determinant is not zero, the determinant remains nonzero after any row operation is applied.
    9. If we apply a sequence of row operations to \(A\) to find a row equivalent matrix \(U\) that is upper triangular, we know that \(\det(A)\neq0\) if and only if \(\det(U) \neq 0\text{.}\) We also know that \(A\) is invertible if and only if \(U\) is invertible. Putting these facts together, we conclude that \(\det(A)\neq 0\) if and only if \(A\) is invertible.

    19.4.3 Cofactor expansions

    Activity 19.4.4.

    Solution.
    1. We will using a cofactor expanion along the first row so that
      \begin{equation*} \begin{array}{rl} \det\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 2 \amp 0 \amp -1 \\ 3 \amp 1 \amp 2 \\ -2 \amp 4 \amp -3 \\ \end{array}\right] = \amp (-1)^{1+1}\cdot 2 \det\left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp 2 \\ 4 \amp -3 \\ \end{array}\right] \\ \amp + (-1)^{1+3}\cdot (-1) \det\left[\begin{array}{rr} 3 \amp 1 \\ -2 \amp 4 \\ \end{array}\right] \\ = \amp 2(-11) - 14 = -36\text{.} \end{array} \end{equation*}
    2. Expanding along the first row gives
      \begin{equation*} \begin{array}{rl} \det \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} -3 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 4 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ -1 \amp 4 \amp -4 \amp 0\\ 0 \amp 3 \amp 2 \amp 3 \\ \end{array}\right] \amp = 3\det \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 4 \amp -4 \amp 0\\ 3 \amp 2 \amp 3 \\ \end{array}\right] \\ \amp =-3(1)\det \left[\begin{array}{rr} -4 \amp 0 \\ 2 \amp 3 \\ \end{array}\right] \\ \amp =-3(1)(-4)(3) = 36\text{.} \end{array} \end{equation*}
    3. We form the matrix \(A\) whose columns are the three given vectors. Expanding along either the second row or third column to take advantage of the zero in the \((2,3)\) entry, we see that \(\det(A) = 0\text{,}\) which means that \(A\) is not invertible. Therefore, the vectors do not form a basis for \(\real^3\text{.}\)
    4. Sage tells us that \(\det(A) = 72\text{.}\)

    19.4.5 Exercises

    19.4.5.1.

    Answer.
    \(\det(A) = 12\) and \(\det(B) = -24\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    We find that \(\det(A) = 12\) and \(\det(B) = -24\text{.}\)

    19.4.5.2.

    Answer.
    1. \(\det(A) = 1\text{.}\)
    2. \(\det(B) = -1\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. The vectors \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2\) that form the columns of \(A\) are found by rotating the standard basis vectors \(\evec_1\) and \(\evec_2\text{.}\) Consequently, they are positively oriented and form a \(1\times1\) square. This says that \(\det(A) = 1\text{.}\)
    2. The vectors \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2\) that form the columns of \(B\) are found by reflecting the standard basis vectors \(\evec_1\) and \(\evec_2\text{.}\) Consequently, they are negatively oriented and form a \(1\times1\) square. This says that \(\det(B) = -1\text{.}\)

    19.4.5.3.

    Answer.
    1. \(\det(A) = \det(B)\) because \(\det(P) \det(P^{-1}) = 1\text{.}\)
    2. \(\det(A) = 30\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. \(\det(A) = \det(P) \det(B) \det(P^{-1}) = \det(B)\text{.}\)
    2. \(\det(A) = (\det(P)) (2)(-5)(-3) (\det(P^{-1})) = 30\) since \(\det(P) \det(P^{-1}) = 1\text{.}\)

    19.4.5.4.

    Answer.
    1. \(\displaystyle \det(A) = k-16\)
    2. \(k\neq 16\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. We see that \(\det(A) = k-16\text{.}\)
    2. The vectors are linearly independent when the matrix \(A\) is invertible, which means that \(\det(A)\neq 0\text{.}\) Therefore, the vectors are linearly independent when \(k\neq 16\text{.}\)

    19.4.5.5.

    Answer.
    1. False
    2. False
    3. True
    4. True
    5. False
    Solution.
    1. False. This is a row replacement operation, which leaves the determinant unchanged.
    2. False. Applying an interchange operation changes the sign of the determinant.
    3. True. Scaling a row of \(A\) by \(r\) multiplies the determinant by \(r\text{.}\)
    4. True. Row operations either leave the determinant unchanged, change its sign, or multiply it by a nonzero number. Therefore, if \(\det(A')=0\) and \(A\) and \(A'\) are related through a sequence of row operations, then \(\det(A) = 0\text{.}\)
    5. False. It is true that \(\det(I) = 1\text{,}\) but a sequence of row operations that cause \(A\) and \(I\) to be row equivalent may multiply the determinant by a nonzero number or change its sign. We do know, however, that \(\det(A)\neq 0\) and so \(A\) is invertible.

    19.4.5.6.

    Answer.
    1. \(\det(2A) = -64\text{.}\)
    2. \(\det(A^3) = -8\text{.}\)
    3. \(\det(AB) = -10\text{.}\)
    4. \(\det(-A) = 2\text{.}\)
    5. \(\det (AB^{-1}) = -\frac 25\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. Multiplying the entire matrix by \(2\) scales each row by \(2\text{.}\) Therefore, \(\det(2A) = 2^5\det(A) = -64\text{.}\)
    2. We have \(\det(A^3) = (\det(A))^3 = -8\text{.}\)
    3. We know that \(\det(AB) = \det(A) \det(B) = -10\text{.}\)
    4. Multiplying the matrix by \(-1\) scales each row by \(-1\) so we have \(\det(-A) = (-1)^5\det(A) = 2\text{.}\)
    5. \(\det(AB^{-1}) = \det(A) \det(B^{-1}) = \det(A)/\det(B) = -\frac 25\text{.}\)

    19.4.5.7.

    Answer.
    1. If \(A\) and \(B\) are invertible, then \(\det(A) \neq 0\) and \(\det(B) \neq 0\text{.}\) Therefore, \(\det(AB) = \det(A)\det(B) \neq 0\text{,}\) which shows that \(AB\) is invertible.
    2. If \(AB\) is invertible, then \(\det (AB) = \det(A) \det(B) \neq 0\text{.}\) This implies that \(\det(A)\neq0\) and \(\det(B) \neq 0\text{,}\) from which we conclude that both \(A\) and \(B\) are invertible.
    Solution.
    1. If \(A\) and \(B\) are invertible, then \(\det(A) \neq 0\) and \(\det(B) \neq 0\text{.}\) Therefore, \(\det(AB) = \det(A)\det(B) \neq 0\text{,}\) which shows that \(AB\) is invertible.
    2. If \(AB\) is invertible, then \(\det (AB) = \det(A) \det(B) \neq 0\text{.}\) This implies that \(\det(A)\neq0\) and \(\det(B) \neq 0\text{,}\) from which we conclude that both \(A\) and \(B\) are invertible.

    19.4.5.8.

    Answer.
    In all four cases, the determinant must be zero.
    Solution.
    1. The determinant must be zero. This is because the matrix cannot be invertible since there is a row without a pivot. Also, applying a cofactor expansion along that row will produce zero for the determinant.
    2. The determinant is zero again. If we multiply one of the rows by \(-1\) and add it to the other row, we obtain a row whose entries are all zero. This operation does not change the determinant, but we know that the determinant of the new matrix is zero by the previous part of this problem.
    3. The determinant must be zero. This is because the columns are not linearly independent, which means that the matrix cannot be invertible. Hence, the determinant is zero.
    4. The determinant must be zero. This is because the columns are not linearly independent, which means that the matrix cannot be invertible. Hence, the determinant is zero.

    19.4.5.9.

    Answer.
    1. \(\det(A) = 2x-y-2z = 0\text{.}\)
    2. If we replace the third column by either \(\vvec_1\) or \(\vvec_2\text{,}\) we obtain a matrix whose columns are linearly dependent.
    3. If \(\det(A)=0\) for a vector \(\threevec xyz\text{,}\) then \(\threevec xyz\) is a linear combination of \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. Using a cofactor expansion, we have \(\det(A) = 2x-y-2z = 0\text{.}\)
    2. If we replace the third column by either \(\vvec_1\) or \(\vvec_2\text{,}\) we obtain a matrix whose columns are linearly dependent. Therefore, the determinant of the matrix must be zero.
    3. If \(\det(A) = 0\) for some vector \(\threevec xyz\text{,}\) then the columns of \(A\) must be linear dependent. Therefore, \(\threevec xyz\) is a linear combination of \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2\) and lies in the plane that is their span.

    19.4.5.10.

    Answer.
    1. Column replacements do not change the determinant because \(\det(R)=1\text{.}\)
    2. Scaling a column by \(r\) multiplies the determinant by \(r\) because \(\det(S)=r\text{.}\)
    3. Interchanges change the sign of the determinant because \(\det(P)=-1\text{.}\)
    4. \(\det(A) = -12\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. The columns of \(AR\) are found by multiplying the columns of \(R\) by \(A\text{.}\) If we remember that a vector multiplied by a matrix forms a linear combination of the columns of \(A\text{,}\) we see that the first column of \(AR\) is \(\vvec_1-3\vvec_2\) and that the other two columns are unchanged.
      Since \(\det(R) = 1\text{,}\) we have \(\det(AR) = \det(A)\text{,}\) which says that this operation does not change the determinant.
    2. Multiplying by \(S\) multiplies the determinant by \(3\) since \(\det(S)=3\text{.}\)
    3. Multiplying by \(P\) changes the sign of the determinant since \(\det(P) = -1\text{.}\)
    4. If we interchange the first and third columns of \(A\text{,}\) we have
      \begin{equation*} A_1=\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp -3 \amp 0 \\ 4 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] \end{equation*}
      and \(\det(A) = -\det(A_1)\text{.}\) Now we will multiply the first column by \(3\) and add to the second column to obtain
      \begin{equation*} A_2=\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 4 \amp 13 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] \end{equation*}
      and \(\det(A) = -\det(A_2)\text{.}\) Lets interchange the second and third columns so that
      \begin{equation*} A_3=\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 4 \amp 1 \amp 13 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] \end{equation*}
      so that \(\det(A) = \det(A_3)\) and then multiply the second column by \(-13\) and add to the third column so that
      \begin{equation*} A_4=\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 4 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -12 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{equation*}
      This gives \(\det(A) = \det(A_4) = -12\text{.}\)

    19.4.5.11.

    Answer.
    \(\det(A) = -1\text{,}\) \(\det(B) = 1\text{,}\) and \(\det(C) = abcd\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    It takes three interchanges to see that \(A\sim I\text{,}\) which implies that \(\det(A) = -1\text{.}\)
    Two interchanges show us that \(A\sim I\) and hence \(\det(B) = 1\text{.}\)
    Two interchanges produce a diagonal matrix so that \(\det(C) = abcd\text{.}\)

    19.4.5.12.

    Answer.
    1. \(\det(A) = -1\text{,}\) \(\det(B) = 0\text{,}\) \(\det(C) = 1\text{,}\) and \(\det(D) = 0\text{.}\)
    2. If \(E\) and \(F\) are the \(6\times6\) and \(7\times7\) matrices, respectively, we expect that \(\det(E) = -1\) and \(\det(F) = 0\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. \(\det(A) = -1\text{,}\) \(\det(B) = 0\text{,}\) \(\det(C) = 1\text{,}\) and \(\det(D) = 0\text{.}\)
    2. If \(E\) and \(F\) are the \(6\times6\) and \(7\times7\) matrices, respectively, we expect that \(\det(E) = -1\) and \(\det(F) = 0\text{.}\)

    19.4.5.13.

    Answer.
    1. Perform a sequence of row operations to form an upper triangular matrix.
    2. If \(a\text{,}\) \(b\text{,}\) and \(c\) are distinct, then \(\det(V) \neq 0\text{.}\)
    3. The determinant is \((d-a)(d-b)(d-c)(c-a)(c-b)(b-a)\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. If \(a\text{,}\) \(b\text{,}\) and \(c\) are not distinct, we see that \(\det(V)=0\) because two of the rows are identical. Therefore, we apply the following row operations, assuming \(a\text{,}\) \(b\text{,}\) and \(c\) are distinct:
      \begin{equation*} \begin{array}{rl} V = \amp \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp a \amp a^2 \\ 1 \amp b \amp b^2 \\ 1 \amp c \amp c^2 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp a \amp a^2 \\ 0 \amp b-a \amp b^2-a^2 \\ 0 \amp c-a \amp c^2-a^2 \\ \end{array}\right] \\ \sim \amp \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp a \amp a^2 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp b+a \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp c+a \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp a \amp a^2 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp b+a \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp c-b \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{array} \end{equation*}
      Because of the scalings by \(b-a\) and \(c-a\text{,}\) we have \(\det(V) = (b-a)(c-a)(c-b)\text{.}\)
    2. If \(a\text{,}\) \(b\text{,}\) and \(c\) are distinct, then \(\det(V) \neq 0\text{,}\) which implies that \(V\) is invertible.
    3. In the \(4\times4\) case, we have
      \begin{equation*} \det\left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 1 \amp a \amp a^2 \amp a^3 \\ 1 \amp b \amp b^2 \amp b^3 \\ 1 \amp c \amp c^2 \amp c^3 \\ 1 \amp d \amp d^2 \amp d^3 \\ \end{array}\right] = (d-a)(d-b)(d-c)(c-a)(c-b)(b-a)\text{.} \end{equation*}

    19.5 Subspaces
    19.5.1 Subspaces

    Activity 19.5.2.

    Solution.
    1. If we choose all the weights \(c_1=c_2=\ldots=c_n = 0\text{,}\) then the linear combination
      \begin{equation*} c_1\vvec_1 + c_2\vvec_2 + \cdots + c_n\vvec_n = \zerovec. \end{equation*}
      This means that \(\zerovec\) is the subspace \(S=\laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n}\text{.}\)
    2. The line on the left cannot be a subspace of \(\real^2\) since it does not contain the zero vector. The line on the right is a subspace because it can be represented as the span of any nonzero vector on the line.
    3. The matrix whose columns are the given vectors has a pivot in every row. Therefore, the span of these vectors is \(\real^3\) and so \(S=\laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3} = \real^3\text{.}\)
      1. We see that \(\wvec_3 = \wvec_1 + 2\wvec_2\text{.}\)
      2. Any linear combination
        \begin{equation*} c_1\wvec_1 + c_2\wvec_2 + c_2\wvec_3 = (c_1 + c_2)\wvec_1 + (c_2+2c_2)\wvec_2. \end{equation*}
      3. The subspace \(S=\laspan{\wvec_1,\wvec_2,\wvec_3} = \laspan{\wvec_1,\wvec_2}\) is a plane in \(\real^3\text{.}\)
    5. Since we can write \(\vvec_2 = 2\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_4 = -2\vvec_1 + \vvec_2\text{,}\) then
      \begin{equation*} S = \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3,\vvec_4} = \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_3}, \end{equation*}
      which is a plane in \(\real^3\text{.}\)

    19.5.2 The column space of \(A\)

    Activity 19.5.3.

    Solution.
    1. We have
      \begin{equation*} A=\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 3 \amp -1 \\ -2 \amp 0 \amp -4 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right]\sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{,} \end{equation*}
      which shows that the vectors are not linearly independent and, in fact, that \(\vvec_3 = 2\vvec_1 - \vvec_2\text{.}\) As weve seen several times, this means that any linear combination of \(\vvec_1\text{,}\) \(\vvec_2\text{,}\) and \(\vvec_3\) can be written as a linear combination of \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2\) alone and hence that
      \begin{equation*} \col(A)=\laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3} = \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2}. \end{equation*}
    2. The reduced row echelon form of \(A\) shows that \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2\) are linearly independent. We also know that the span of these two vectors is \(\col(A)\text{.}\) Therefore, they form a basis for \(\col(A)\text{.}\)
    3. Denoting the columns of \(B\) as \(\vvec_i\text{,}\) the reduced row echelon form shows that \(\vvec_2=2\vvec_1\text{,}\) \(\vvec_3=0\vvec_1\text{,}\) and \(\vvec_4 = -3\vvec_1\text{.}\) Therefore, any linear combination of \(\vvec_1\text{,}\) \(\vvec_2\text{,}\) \(\vvec_3\text{,}\) and \(\vvec_4\) can be written as a linear combination of \(\vvec_1\) alone. This means that \(\vvec_1\) forms a basis for \(\col(A)\text{,}\) which is then the line consisting of all scalar multiples of \(\vvec_1\text{.}\) p
    4. The number of vectors in a basis of \(\col(A)\) equals the number of pivot positions. Therefore, \(\dim~\col(A)\) equals the number of pivot positions in \(A\text{.}\)
    5. As the examples in this activity illustrate, the columns of \(A\) that contain pivot positions form a basis for \(\col(A)\text{.}\)
    6. If \(A\) is invertible, then it has a pivot position in every row, which means that the span of the columns is \(\real^9\text{.}\) Therefore, \(\col(A) = \real^9\text{.}\)
    7. Since \(\col(A)=\real^8\text{,}\) we know that every 8-dimensional vector \(\bvec\) is in \(\col(A)\text{.}\) This means that \(\bvec\) is in the span of the columns of \(A\) so the equation \(A\xvec = \bvec\) must be consistent.

    19.5.3 The null space of \(A\)

    Activity 19.5.4.

    Solution.
    1. We have
      \begin{equation*} A=\begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 3 \amp -1 \amp 2 \\ -2 \amp 0 \amp -4 \amp 2 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix}\sim \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \amp 2 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -1 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0\\ \end{bmatrix}, \end{equation*}
      which leads to the parametric description of the solution space to the homogeneous equation:
      \begin{equation*} \xvec=x_3\fourvec{-2}{1}{1}0 + x_4\fourvec{1}{-1}01. \end{equation*}
    2. The parametric description shows that every solution to the equation \(A\xvec=\zerovec\) is a linear combination of \(\wvec_1=\fourvec{-2}110\) and \(\wvec_2=\fourvec1{-1}01\text{.}\)
    3. The vectors \(\wvec_1\) and \(\wvec_2\) are linearly independent so they form a basis for \(\nul(A)\text{.}\) Therefore, \(\nul(A)\) is 2-dimensional.
    4. The vectors in \(\nul(A)\) are 4-dimensional so \(\nul(A)\) is a subspace of \(\real^4\text{.}\)
    5. A parametric description of the null space is \(\xvec=x_2\fourvec{-2}{1}{0}{0} + x_3\fourvec0010 + x_4\fourvec{3}{0}{-2}{1}\text{.}\) We can check that the vectors
      \begin{equation*} \fourvec{-2}100,~~~\fourvec0010,~~~\fourvec30{-2}1 \end{equation*}
      are linearly independent so they form a basis for \(\nul(A)\text{.}\) This means that \(\nul(A)\) is 3-dimensional.
    6. The number of vectors in a basis of the null space equals the number of free variables that appear in the equation \(A\xvec=\zerovec\text{,}\) which is the number of columns that do not have pivot positions. This says that \(\dim~\nul(A)\) equals the number of columns of \(A\) minus the number of pivot positions.
    7. If the columns are linearly independent, then the homogeneous equation \(A\xvec=\zerovec\) has only the zero solution \(\xvec=\zerovec\text{.}\) Therefore, \(\nul(A) = \{\zerovec\}\text{.}\)

    19.5.5 Exercises

    19.5.5.1.

    Answer.
    1. \(\nul(A)\) is a subspace of \(\real^6\) and \(\col(A)\) is a subspace of \(\real^4\text{.}\)
    2. \(\dim~\nul(A) = 3\) and \(\dim~\col(A)=3\text{.}\)
    3. \(\displaystyle \fourvec{2}{-4}{6}{4}, \fourvec{0}{-1}{0}{-1}, \fourvec{0}{0}{3}{0}\)
    4. \(\displaystyle \left[\begin{array}{r} 1 \\ 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \\ \end{array}\right], \left[\begin{array}{r} 0 \\ 2 \\ -1 \\ 1 \\ 0 \\ 0 \\ \end{array}\right], \left[\begin{array}{r} 0 \\ -3 \\ -4 \\ 0 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{array}\right]\)
    Solution.
    1. \(\nul(A)\) is a subspace of \(\real^6\) and \(\col(A)\) is a subspace of \(\real^4\text{.}\)
    2. Because there are three pivot positions, we see that \(\rank(A) = 3\text{.}\) Therefore, \(\dim~\nul(A) = 6-3=3\) and \(\dim~\col(A)=3\text{.}\)
    3. A basis for \(\col(A)\) is given by the columns of \(A\) that contain pivot positions. Therefore, a basis is
      \begin{equation*} \fourvec{2}{-4}{6}{4}, \fourvec{0}{-1}{0}{-1}, \fourvec{0}{0}{3}{0}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    4. We can write a parametric description for the solution space to the homogeneous equation as
      \begin{equation*} \xvec = \left[\begin{array}{r} x_1 \\ 2x_4 - 3x_6 \\ -x_4-4x_6 \\ x_4 \\ x_6 \\ x_6 \end{array}\right] = x_1 \left[\begin{array}{r} 1 \\ 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \\ \end{array}\right] +x_4 \left[\begin{array}{r} 0 \\ 2 \\ -1 \\ 1 \\ 0 \\ 0 \\ \end{array}\right] + x_6 \left[\begin{array}{r} 0 \\ -3 \\ -4 \\ 0 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{equation*}
      Therefore, a basis for \(\nul(A)\) is
      \begin{equation*} \left[\begin{array}{r} 1 \\ 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \\ \end{array}\right], \left[\begin{array}{r} 0 \\ 2 \\ -1 \\ 1 \\ 0 \\ 0 \\ \end{array}\right], \left[\begin{array}{r} 0 \\ -3 \\ -4 \\ 0 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{equation*}

    19.5.5.2.

    Answer.
    1. Yes
    2. No
    3. No
    4. Yes
    5. No
    Solution.
    1. Yes. This vector is a column of \(A\) so it may be written as a linear combination of the columns of \(A\text{.}\)
    2. No. Vectors in \(\col(A)\) must be three-dimensional.
    3. No. Vectors in \(\nul(A)\) must be four-dimensional.
    4. Yes, because this vector, when multiplied by \(A\text{,}\) gives \(\zerovec\text{.}\)
    5. No, because this vector, when multiplied by \(A\text{,}\) does not give \(\zerovec\text{.}\)

    19.5.5.3.

    Answer.
    1. False
    2. True
    3. False
    4. False
    5. True
    Solution.
    1. False. \(\nul(A)\) is a subspace of \(\real^{341}\text{.}\)
    2. True. In this case, the only solution to the homogeneous equation \(A\xvec=\zerovec\) is the zero solution \(\xvec=\zerovec\text{.}\) This means that every column has a pivot position so the columns are linearly independent.
    3. False. The matrix \(A\) is not necessarily a square matrix.
    4. False. If \(A\) has a pivot position in every column, then \(\nul(A) = \{\zerovec\}\text{.}\)
    5. True. Since \(\col(A)=\real^m\text{,}\) we know that \(A\) has a pivot position in every row. Since \(\nul(A)=\{\zerovec\}\text{,}\) we know that \(A\) has a pivot position in every column. Therefore, \(A\) must be a square matrix and invertible.

    19.5.5.4.

    Answer.
    1. If \(BA\xvec=\zerovec\text{,}\) then \(A\xvec=\zerovec\) if \(B\) is invertible.
    2. The column space consists of all the vectors \(\bvec\) for which \(A\xvec=\bvec\) is consistent. We can rewrite this condition as \(AB(B^{-1}\xvec)=\bvec\text{,}\) which means that \(A\xvec=\bvec\) is consistent exactly when \(AB\xvec=\bvec\) is.
    3. If \(A\sim A'\text{,}\) then \(A\) and \(A'\) have the same reduced row echelon form, which determines \(\nul(A)\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. If \(BA\xvec=\zerovec\text{,}\) then \(A\xvec=\zerovec\) if \(B\) is invertible.
    2. The column space consists of all the vectors \(\bvec\) for which \(A\xvec=\bvec\) is consistent. We can rewrite this condition as \(AB(B^{-1}\xvec)=\bvec\text{,}\) which means that \(A\xvec=\bvec\) is consistent exactly when \(AB\xvec=\bvec\) is.
    3. If \(A\sim A'\text{,}\) then \(A\) and \(A'\) have the same reduced row echelon form, which determines \(\nul(A)\text{.}\)

    19.5.5.5.

    Answer.
    1. \(\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] \text{.}\)
    2. \(\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] \text{.}\)
    3. \(\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 4 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] \text{.}\)
    4. \(\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] \text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. \(\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] \text{.}\)
    2. \(\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] \text{.}\)
    3. \(\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 4 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] \text{.}\)
    4. \(\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] \text{.}\)

    19.5.5.6.

    Answer.
    1. No
    2. \(\displaystyle \col(A) = \real^3\)
    3. \(\col(A)\) is a plane in \(\real^3\)
    4. \(\col(A)\) is a line in \(\real^3\)
    5. \(\col(A)=\{\zerovec\}\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. No. There are more columns than rows so there must be at least one column without a pivot position.
    2. Remember that we have \(\dim~\col(A) + \dim~\nul(A) = 4\text{.}\) Therefore, we have \(\dim~\col(A) = 3\) in this case, which implies that \(\col(A) = \real^3\text{.}\)
    3. Here, \(\dim~\col(A) = 2\) so \(\col(A)\) is a plane in \(\real^3\text{.}\)
    4. Here, \(\dim~\col(A) = 1\) so \(\col(A)\) is a line in \(\real^3\text{.}\)
    5. Here, \(\dim~\col(A) = 0\) so \(\col(A)=\{\zerovec\}\text{.}\)

    19.5.5.7.

    Answer.
    1. \(\displaystyle 3\times4\)
    2. \(\displaystyle A = \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 2 \amp -1 \amp -7 \amp 8 \\ 3 \amp 2 \amp -7 \amp -2 \\ -1 \amp 4 \amp 7 \amp -18 \\ \end{array}\right]\)
    Solution.
    1. Since \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2\) are three-dimensional vectors, \(A\) must have three rows. Since \(\wvec_1\) and \(\wvec_2\) are 4-dimensional, \(A\) must have four columns. Alternatively, we know that \(\dim~\nul(A) = 2\) and \(\dim~\col(A) = 2\text{.}\) Therefore, the number of columns is \(n=\dim~\nul(A) + \dim~\col(A) = 4\text{.}\) Hence, \(A\) is a \(3\times4\) matrix.
    2. We can use \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2\) as the first two columns of \(A\text{.}\) We also know that \(A\wvec_1=\zerovec\) and \(A\wvec_2=\zerovec\text{.}\) If we call the other two columns \(\vvec_3\) and \(\vvec_4\text{,}\) then \(A\wvec_1=\zerovec\) implies that \(3\vvec_1-\vvec_2+\vvec_3 = \zerovec\) so that \(\vvec_3 = \threevec{-7}{-7}{7}\text{.}\) Since \(A\wvec_2 = \zerovec\text{,}\) we have \(-2\vvec_1+4\vvec_2 + \vvec_4=\zerovec\text{,}\) which says that \(\vvec_4=\threevec{8}{-2}{-18}\text{.}\) This gives
      \begin{equation*} A = \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 2 \amp -1 \amp -7 \amp 8 \\ 3 \amp 2 \amp -7 \amp -2 \\ -1 \amp 4 \amp 7 \amp -18 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{equation*}

    19.5.5.8.

    Answer.
    \(\nul(A)=\{\zerovec\}\) and \(\col(A) = \real^8\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    We know that \(A\) is invertible so \(\nul(A)=\{\zerovec\}\) and \(\col(A) = \real^8\text{.}\)

    19.5.5.9.

    Answer.
    \(\nul(A)=\{\zerovec\}\) and \(\col(A)=\real^3\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    We know that \(\det A = -6\) so \(A\) is invertible. Therefore, \(\nul(A)=\{\zerovec\}\) and \(\col(A)=\real^3\text{.}\)

    19.5.5.10.

    Answer.
    1. \(\displaystyle \xvec=x_2\twovec{2}{1}\)
    2. The solution space forms a line through the origin.
    3. \(\displaystyle \xvec=\twovec{2}{0}+x_2\twovec{2}{1}\)
    4. No
    5. \(\xvec=\twovec{-4}{0}+x_2\twovec{2}{1}\text{.}\) The graph of the solution spaces is shown below.
    6. They are all parallel to the solution space to the homogeneous equation.
    7. \(\xvec=\zerovec\) must be in the solution space.
    Solution.
    1. We have
      \begin{equation*} A = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 2 \amp -4 \\ -1 \amp 2 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{,} \end{equation*}
      which shows that \(\xvec=x_2\twovec{2}{1}\) describes the solution space to the homogeneous equation.
    2. The solution space forms a line through the origin.
    3. The solution space has the parametric description \(\xvec=\twovec{2}{0}+x_2\twovec{2}{1}\text{,}\) which is a line parallel to the solution space to the homogeneous equation.
    4. This cannot form a subspace since it does not contain the vector \(\zerovec\text{.}\)
    5. The solution space has the parametric description \(\xvec=\twovec{-4}{0}+x_2\twovec{2}{1}\text{,}\) which is a line parallel to the solution space to the homogeneous equation. The graph of the solution spaces is shown below.
    6. They are all parallel to the solution space to the homogeneous equation.
    7. If the solution space is a subspace, then \(\xvec=\zerovec\) must be in the solution space. This means that \(A\xvec = A\zerovec = \zerovec = \bvec\text{.}\)

    20 Eigenvalues and eigenvectors
    20.1 An introduction to eigenvalues and eigenvectors
    20.1.1 A few examples

    Activity 20.1.2.

    Solution.
    1. The vectors \(\vvec\) and \(\lambda\vvec\) lie on the same line.
    2. The vectors \(\vvec\) and \(A\vvec\) lie on the same line.
    3. There are many possibilities, but we see that \(\twovec{1}{1}\) is an eigenvector with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda=3\text{.}\)
    4. If we perform the matrix multiplication, we see that \(A\twovec{1}{1} = \twovec{3}{3} = 3\twovec{1}{1}\text{.}\)
    5. Yes, \(\twovec{2}{2}\) is still an eigenvector with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda=3\text{.}\)
    6. We see that \(\twovec{1}{-1}\) is an eigenvector with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda=-1\text{.}\)
    7. The only eigenvectors that appear are scalar multiples of \(\twovec{1}{0}\) with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda=2\text{.}\)
    8. There are no eigenvectors. The matrix transformation rotates vectors by \(90^\circ\) so it is not possible for \(\vvec\) and \(A\vvec\) to lie on the same line.

    20.1.2 The usefulness of eigenvalues and eigenvectors

    Activity 20.1.3.

    Solution.
    The solution to this activity is given in the text below.

    20.1.4 Exercises

    20.1.4.1.

    Answer.
    1. We find that \(A\vvec_1 = 3\vvec_1\) and \(A\vvec_2=-2\vvec_2\) so the associated eigenvalues are \(\lambda_1 = 3\) and \(\lambda_2=-2\text{.}\)
    2. \(\xvec=\twovec{-4}{-1} = -3\vvec_1 + 2\vvec_2\text{.}\)
    3. We find
      \begin{equation*} \begin{alignedat}{3} A\xvec\amp{}={}\amp -9\vvec_1 \amp{}-{}\amp 4\vvec_2\\ A^2\xvec\amp{}={}\amp -27\vvec_1\amp{}+{}\amp8\vvec_2 \\ A^{-1}\xvec\amp{}={}\amp -\vvec_1 \amp{}-{}\amp \vvec_2\text{.} \\ \end{alignedat} \end{equation*}
    Solution.
    1. We find that \(A\vvec_1 = 3\vvec_1\) and \(A\vvec_2=-2\vvec_2\) so the associated eigenvalues are \(\lambda_1 = 3\) and \(\lambda_2=-2\text{.}\)
    2. Setting up an augmented matrix and row reducing shows us that \(\xvec=\twovec{-4}{-1} = -3\vvec_1 + 2\vvec_2\text{.}\)
    3. We then have
      \begin{equation*} \begin{alignedat}{3} A\xvec\amp{}={}\amp -9\vvec_1 \amp{}-{}\amp 4\vvec_2\\ A^2\xvec\amp{}={}\amp -27\vvec_1\amp{}+{}\amp8\vvec_2 \\ A^{-1}\xvec\amp{}={}\amp -\vvec_1 \amp{}-{}\amp \vvec_2\text{.} \\ \end{alignedat} \end{equation*}

    20.1.4.2.

    Answer.
    1. We see that \(A\vvec_1=-3\vvec_1\text{,}\) \(A\vvec_2 = -2\vvec_2\text{,}\) and \(A\vvec_3=4\vvec_3\text{.}\) The associated eigenvalues are \(\lambda_1 = -3\text{,}\) \(\lambda_2=-2\text{,}\) and \(\lambda_3=4\text{.}\)
    2. \(\xvec=2\vvec_1 -\vvec_2+2\vvec_3\text{.}\)
    3. We find
      \begin{equation*} \begin{alignedat}{4} A\xvec\amp{}={}\amp -6\vvec_1 \amp{}+{}\amp 2\vvec_2\amp{}+{} \amp 8\vvec_3\\ A^2\xvec\amp{}={}\amp 18\vvec_1\amp{}-{}\amp 4\vvec_2\amp{}+{}\amp 32\vvec_3\\ A^{-1}\xvec\amp{}={}\amp -\frac23\vvec_1\amp {}+{}\amp\frac12\vvec_2\amp{}+{}\amp\frac12\vvec_3\text{.} \\ \end{alignedat} \end{equation*}
    Solution.
    1. We see that \(A\vvec_1=-3\vvec_1\text{,}\) \(A\vvec_2 = -2\vvec_2\text{,}\) and \(A\vvec_3=4\vvec_3\text{.}\) The associated eigenvalues are \(\lambda_1 = -3\text{,}\) \(\lambda_2=-2\text{,}\) and \(\lambda_3=4\text{.}\)
    2. After forming an augmented matrix, we find \(\xvec=2\vvec_1 -\vvec_2+2\vvec_3\text{.}\)
    3. We then have
      \begin{equation*} \begin{alignedat}{4} A\xvec\amp{}={}\amp -6\vvec_1 \amp{}+{}\amp 2\vvec_2\amp{}+{} \amp 8\vvec_3\\ A^2\xvec\amp{}={}\amp 18\vvec_1\amp{}-{}\amp 4\vvec_2\amp{}+{}\amp 32\vvec_3\\ A^{-1}\xvec\amp{}={}\amp -\frac23\vvec_1\amp {}+{}\amp\frac12\vvec_2\amp{}+{}\amp\frac12\vvec_3\text{.} \\ \end{alignedat} \end{equation*}

    20.1.4.3.

    Answer.
    1. If \(\lambda=0\) is an eigenvalue, then there is a nonzero vector \(\vvec\) such that \(A\vvec=\lambda\vvec = \zerovec\text{.}\)
    2. If \(\lambda =0\) is an eigenvalue of \(A\text{,}\) then there is a nonzero solution to the homogeneous equation \(A\xvec=\zerovec\text{.}\)
    3. If \(A\vvec=\lambda\vvec\text{,}\) we can multiply both sides by \(A^{-1}\) and \(\frac1\lambda\) to obtain \(\frac1\lambda\vvec=A^{-1}\vvec\text{.}\)
    4. Notice that \(A^2\vvec = A(A\vvec) = \lambda A\vvec = \lambda^2\vvec\text{,}\) which means that \(\vvec\) is an eigenvector with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda^2\text{.}\)
    5. The vectors \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2\) are eigenvectors of \(A^5\) with associated eigenvalues \(\lambda_1^5 = 3^5=243\) and \(\lambda_2^5 = (-1)^5 = -1\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. If \(\lambda=0\) is an eigenvalue, then there is a nonzero vector \(\vvec\) such that \(A\vvec=\lambda\vvec = \zerovec\text{.}\) This means that an associated eigenvector is a nonzero solution to the homogeneous equation \(A\xvec=\zerovec\text{.}\)
    2. If \(\lambda =0\) is an eigenvalue of \(A\text{,}\) then there is a nonzero solution to the homogeneous equation \(A\xvec=\zerovec\text{,}\) which happens exactly when \(A\) is not invertible.
    3. If \(\vvec\) is an eigenvector of \(A\) with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda\text{,}\) then \(A\vvec=\lambda\vvec\text{.}\) Therefore, \(A^2\vvec = A(A\vvec) = \lambda A\vvec = \lambda^2\vvec\text{,}\) which means that \(\vvec\) is an eigenvector with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda^2\text{.}\)
    4. If \(A\vvec=\lambda\vvec\text{,}\) we can multiply both sides by \(A^{-1}\) and \(\frac1\lambda\) to obtain \(\frac1\lambda\vvec=A^{-1}\vvec\text{.}\) This shows that \(\vvec\) is an eigenvector of \(A^{-1}\) with associated eigenvalue \(\frac1\lambda\text{.}\)
    5. The vectors \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2\) are eigenvectors of \(A^5\) with associated eigenvalues \(\lambda_1^5 = 3^5=243\) and \(\lambda_2^5 = (-1)^5 = -1\text{.}\)

    20.1.4.4.

    Answer.
    Solution.

    20.1.4.5.

    Answer.
    1. Every two-dimensional vector is an eigenvector with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda=3\text{.}\)
    2. We have eigenvectors \(\vvec_1=\twovec{1}{0}\) with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda_1=-2\) and \(\vvec_2=\twovec{0}{1}\) with \(\lambda_2=4\text{.}\)
    3. Every vector is an eigenvector of the identity matrix with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda=1\text{.}\)
    4. The standard basis vectors \(\evec_j\) are eigenvectors and the associated eigenvalues are the corresponding diagonal entries.
    Solution.
    1. The corresponding matrix transformation stretches every two-dimensional vector by a factor of \(3\text{.}\) Therefore, every two-dimensional vector is an eigenvector with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda=3\text{.}\)
    2. The corresponding matrix transformation stretches vectors horizontally by a factor of \(2\) and reflects them while stretching by a factor of \(4\) vertically. We have eigenvectors \(\vvec_1=\twovec{1}{0}\) with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda_1=-2\) and \(\vvec_2=\twovec{0}{1}\) with \(\lambda_2=4\text{.}\)
    3. For any vector \(\vvec\text{,}\) we have \(I\vvec=\vvec\text{.}\) Therefore, every vector is an eigenvector of the identity matrix with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda=1\text{.}\)
    4. The standard basis vectors \(\evec_j\) are eigenvectors and the associated eigenvalues are the corresponding diagonal entries.

    20.1.4.6.

    Answer.
    1. \(\twovec{145}{-130}\text{.}\)
    2. \(A\twovec10 = \twovec12\) and \(A\twovec01 = \twovec2{-2}\text{.}\)
    3. \(A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 2 \\ 2 \amp -2 \\ \end{bmatrix} \text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. We have \(\xvec = 2\vvec_1-\vvec_2\text{.}\) Therefore, \(A^4\xvec = 2\lambda_1^4\vvec_1-\lambda_2^4\vvec_2 = 32\vvec_1-81\vvec_2=\twovec{145}{-130}\text{.}\)
    2. We have
      \begin{equation*} \twovec10 = \frac25 \vvec_1 - \frac15 \vvec2,~~~ \twovec01 = \frac15 \vvec_1 + \frac25 \vvec2, \end{equation*}
      and so
      \begin{equation*} A\twovec10 = \frac45 \vvec_1 + \frac35 \vvec2 = \twovec12,~~~ A\twovec01 = \frac25 \vvec_1 - \frac65 \vvec2 = \twovec2{-2}. \end{equation*}
    3. From the results of the previous part, we have \(A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 2 \\ 2 \amp -2 \\ \end{bmatrix} \text{.}\)

    20.1.4.7.

    Answer.
    1. True
    2. False
    3. True
    4. False
    5. False
    Solution.
    1. True. The associated eigenvectors are the standard basis vectors \(\evec_j\text{.}\)
    2. False. \(A^2\vvec=\lambda^2\vvec\text{.}\)
    3. True, because \(I\vvec = \vvec\text{.}\)
    4. False. If \(\lambda=0\) is an eigenvalue of \(A\text{,}\) then there is a nonzero solution to the homogeneous equation so \(A\) is not invertible.
    5. False. We saw the example \(\left[\begin{array}{rr} 0 \amp -1 \\ 1 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{,}\) which represents a \(90^\circ\) rotation and has no eigenvectors.

    20.1.4.8.

    Answer.
    1. Because \(A\vvec = \lambda\vvec\text{.}\)
    2. Because \(A\vvec = 0\vvec = \zerovec\text{.}\)
    3. For the matrix \(A\text{,}\) \(\vvec_1=\threevec{1}{1}{1}\) with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda_1=3\text{,}\) and \(\vvec_2=\threevec{-1}{1}{0}\) and \(\vvec_3=\threevec{-1}{0}{1}\) with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda_2=\lambda_3 = 0\text{.}\)
      For \(B\text{,}\) \(\vvec_1=\threevec{1}{2}{3}\) with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda_1=6\) and \(\vvec_2=\threevec{-1}{1}{0}\) and \(\vvec_3=\threevec{-1}{0}{1}\) with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda_2=\lambda_3=0\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. In this case, we have \(A\vvec = \lambda\vvec\) or \(A\left(\frac1\lambda\vvec\right) = \vvec\text{,}\) which says that the equation \(A\xvec = \vvec\) is consistent.
    2. With this assumption, \(A\vvec = 0\vvec = \zerovec\text{,}\) which means that \(\vvec\) is a solution to the homogeneous equation \(A\xvec = \zerovec\text{.}\)
    3. The column space of \(A\) is spanned by \(\vvec_1=\threevec{1}{1}{1}\) and we notice that \(A\vvec_1 = 3\vvec_1\text{.}\) Therefore, \(\vvec_1\) is an eigenvector with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda_1=3\text{.}\)
      We also know that that the rank of this matrix is 1 so \(\nul(A)\) is two-dimensional. A basis for the null space is \(\vvec_2=\threevec{-1}{1}{0}\) and \(\vvec_3=\threevec{-1}{0}{1}\) so these vectors are eigenvectors with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda_2=\lambda_3 = 0\text{.}\) In the same way, \(\vvec_1=\threevec{1}{2}{3}\) is an eigenvector of \(B\) with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda_1=6\) and \(\vvec_2=\threevec{-1}{1}{0}\) and \(\vvec_3=\threevec{-1}{0}{1}\) are eigenvectors with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda_2=\lambda_3=0\text{.}\)

    20.1.4.9.

    Answer.
    1. \(\twovec{1}{1}\) with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda = 1\) and \(\twovec{1}{-1}\) with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda=-1\text{.}\)
    2. Every two-dimensional vector is an eigenvector with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda=-1\text{.}\)
    3. \(\threevec{0}{1}{0}\) with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda=1\text{.}\) \(\threevec{1}{0}{0}\) and \(\threevec{0}{0}{1}\) with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda=-1\text{.}\)
    4. \(\threevec{1}{0}{0}\) with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda=1\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. A vector lying along the line of reflection is unchanged so \(A\twovec{1}{1} = \twovec{1}{1}\text{,}\) which shows that \(\twovec{1}{1}\) is an eigenvector with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda = 1\text{.}\) At the same time, \(A\twovec{1}{-1} = -\twovec{1}{-1}\) so \(\twovec{1}{-1}\) is an eigenvector with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda=-1\text{.}\)
    2. Every vector \(\vvec\) satisfies \(A\vvec=-\vvec\) so every two-dimensional vector is an eigenvector with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda=-1\text{.}\)
    3. Vectors along the \(y\)-axis are unchanged so \(\threevec{0}{1}{0}\) is an eigenvector with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda=1\text{.}\) Vectors in the \(xz\)-plane are multiplied by \(-1\) so \(\threevec{1}{0}{0}\) and \(\threevec{0}{0}{1}\) are eigenvectors with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda=-1\text{.}\)
    4. The vector \(\threevec{1}{0}{0}\) is an eigenvector with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda=1\text{.}\) There are no other eigenvectors that are not scalar multiples of this one.

    20.1.4.10.

    Answer.
    1. \(\vvec_1\) with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda_1=1.4\) and \(\vvec_2\) with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda_2=0.9\text{.}\)
    2. \(\xvec_0=10\vvec_1+14\vvec_2\text{.}\)
    3. We have
      \begin{equation*} \begin{alignedat}{4} \xvec_1\amp{}={}\amp A\xvec_0 \amp {}={} 10(1.4)\vvec_1 \amp {}+{} \amp 14(0.9)\vvec_2 \\ \xvec_2\amp{}={}\amp A\xvec_1 \amp {}={} 10(1.4)^2\vvec_1 \amp {}+{} \amp 14(0.9)^2\vvec_2 \\ \xvec_3\amp{}={}\amp A\xvec_2 \amp {}={} 10(1.4)^3\vvec_1 \amp {}+{} \amp 14(0.9)^3\vvec_2\text{.} \\ \end{alignedat} \end{equation*}
    4. In general, \(\xvec_k = 10(1.4)^k\vvec_1 + 14(0.9)^k\vvec_2\text{.}\)
    5. The ratio of \(P_k\) to \(Q_k\) is 1:3.
    Solution.
    1. We can compute \(A\vvec_1 = 1.4\vvec_1\) and \(A\vvec_2=0.9\vvec_2\text{.}\) This means that \(\vvec_1\) is an eigenvector with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda_1=1.4\) and \(\vvec_2\) is an eigenvector with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda_2=0.9\text{.}\)
    2. Setting up an augmented matrix and row reducing shows that \(\xvec_0=10\vvec_1+14\vvec_2\text{.}\)
    3. We have
      \begin{equation*} \begin{alignedat}{4} \xvec_1\amp{}={}\amp A\xvec_0 \amp {}={} 10(1.4)\vvec_1 \amp {}+{} \amp 14(0.9)\vvec_2 \\ \xvec_2\amp{}={}\amp A\xvec_1 \amp {}={} 10(1.4)^2\vvec_1 \amp {}+{} \amp 14(0.9)^2\vvec_2 \\ \xvec_3\amp{}={}\amp A\xvec_2 \amp {}={} 10(1.4)^3\vvec_1 \amp {}+{} \amp 14(0.9)^3\vvec_2\text{.} \\ \end{alignedat} \end{equation*}
    4. In general, \(\xvec_k = 10(1.4)^k\vvec_1 + 14(0.9)^k\vvec_2\text{.}\)
    5. After a long time, \(k\) becomes large so that \(0.9^k\) becomes very close to zero. This means that \(\xvec_k\approx 10(1.4)^k\vvec_1\text{.}\) So \(P_k\approx10(1.4)^k\) and \(Q_k\approx30(1.4)^k\text{.}\) This means the ratio of \(P_k\) to \(Q_k\) is 1:3.

    20.2 Finding eigenvalues and eigenvectors
    20.2.1 The characteristic polynomial

    Activity 20.2.2.

    Solution.
    1. The matrix \(A-\lambda I\) cannot be invertible.
    2. It must be the case that \(\det(A-\lambda I) = 0\text{.}\)
    3. We find that \(\det(A-\lambda I) = \lambda^2 - 2\lambda - 3 = 0\text{.}\)
    4. \(\lambda^2 - 2\lambda - 3= (\lambda-3)(\lambda+1) = 0\) so we find eigenvalues \(\lambda = 3\) and \(\lambda = -1\text{.}\)
    5. For this matrix, we have \(\det(A-\lambda I) = (\lambda-2)^2=0\) so there is one eigenvalue, \(\lambda = 2\text{.}\)
    6. \(\det(A-\lambda I) = \lambda^2 + 1 = 0\) so there are complex eigenvalues, \(\lambda = i\) and \(\lambda = -i\text{.}\)
    7. Because the determinant of a triangular matrix equals the product of its diagonal entries, The eigenvalues are equal to the entries on the diagonal.

    20.2.2 Finding eigenvectors

    Activity 20.2.3.

    Solution.
    1. We have
      \begin{equation*} A - 3I = \mattwo{-2}{2}{2}{-2} \sim \mattwo{1}{-1}{0}{0}\text{.} \end{equation*}
      The null space \(\nul(A-3I)\) is one-dimensional with basis \(\twovec{1}{1}\text{.}\)
    2. We have
      \begin{equation*} A - (-1)I = \mattwo{2}{2}{2}{2} \sim \mattwo{1}{1}{0}{0}\text{.} \end{equation*}
      The null space \(\nul(A+I)\) is one-dimensional with basis \(\twovec{-1}{1}\text{.}\)
    3. We can form a basis for \(\real^2\) consisting of eigenvectors of \(A\) by taking \(\left\{\twovec{1}{1}, \twovec{-1}{1}\right\}\text{.}\)
    4. The characteristic equation is \((3-\lambda)^2 = 0\text{,}\) which means that there is a single eigenvalue \(\lambda=3\text{.}\) This eigenspace is two-dimensional with basis \(\left\{\twovec{1}{0},\twovec{0}{1}\right\}\text{.}\) In this case, we can form a basis for \(\real^2\) consisting of eigenvectors of \(A\text{.}\)
    5. The characteristic equation is \((2-\lambda)^2 = 0\) so there is again a single eigenvalue \(\lambda=2\text{.}\) In this case, the eigenspace is one-dimensional with basis vector \(\twovec{1}{0}\text{.}\) It is not possible to form a basis for \(\real^2\) consisting of eigenvectors.
    6. We have eigenvectors \(\twovec10\) with associated eigenvector \(\lambda=4\) and \(\twovec01\) with associated eigenvector \(\lambda=-1\text{.}\)

    20.2.3 The characteristic polynomial and the dimension of eigenspaces

    Activity 20.2.4.

    Solution.
    1. There are three eigenvalues, \(\lambda=2\) has multiplicity \(3\text{,}\) \(\lambda=-3\) has multiplicity \(10\text{,}\) and \(\lambda=5\) has multiplicity \(1\text{.}\) We know that
      \begin{equation*} \begin{aligned} 1 \leq \dim E_2 \amp {}\leq{} 3 \\ 1 \leq \dim E_{-3} \amp {}\leq{} 10 \\ 1 \leq \dim E_5 \amp {}\leq{} 1\text{.} \\ \end{aligned} \end{equation*}
      We can guarantee that \(\dim E_{5} = 1\text{,}\) but we can say nothing further about the other two eigenspaces.
      The dimension of the matrix is \(14\times14\) since the degree of the characteristic polynomial is \(14\text{.}\) We cannot guarantee that we can form a basis for \(\real^{14}\) consisting of eigenvectors, however.
    2. There is one eigenvalue \(\lambda=-2\) having multiplicity two. Because the eigenspace \(E_{-2}\) is one-dimensional, however, we cannot find a basis for \(\real^2\) consisting of eigenvectors of \(A\text{.}\)
    3. For the \(3\times3\) matrix \(A\text{,}\)
      1. We have eigenvalues \(\lambda=-2\) with multiplicity \(2\) and \(\lambda=-1\) with multiplicity \(1\text{.}\)
      2. The eigenspace \(E_{-2}\) is two-dimensional with basis \(\left\{\threevec{-2}{0}{1},\threevec010\right\}\text{.}\) The eigenspace \(E_{-1}\) is one-dimensional with basis vector \(\threevec{-1}20\text{.}\)
      3. We are able to form a basis for \(\real^3\) consisting of eigenvectors of \(A\text{.}\)
    4. For the \(3\times3\) matrix \(A\text{,}\)
      1. We have eigenvalues \(\lambda=-2\) with multiplicity \(2\) and \(\lambda=-1\) with multiplicity \(1\text{.}\)
      2. The eigenspace \(E_{-2}\) is one-dimensional with basis vector \(\threevec{-2}01\text{.}\) The eigenspace \(E_{-1}\) is also one-dimensional with basis vector \(\threevec{-1}{2}{0}\text{.}\)
      3. It is not possible to form a basis for \(\real^3\) consisting of eigenvectors of \(A\text{.}\)
    5. For this matrix,
      1. There are three eigenvalues \(\lambda=-2\text{,}\) \(-1\text{,}\) and \(1\text{,}\) each having multiplicity \(1\text{.}\)
      2. A basis vector for the eigenspace \(E_{-2}\) is \(\threevec{-2}01\text{.}\) A basis vector for the eigenspace \(E_{-1}\) is \(\threevec{1}{-2}0\text{.}\) A basis vector for the eigenspace \(E_{1}\) is \(\threevec{-2}{3}{1}\text{.}\)
      3. We can form a basis for \(\real^3\) consisting of eigenvectors of \(A\text{.}\)

    20.2.4 Using Sage to find eigenvalues and eigenvectors

    Activity 20.2.5.

    Solution.
    1. The fcp command will return the factored characteristic polynomial lambda^2 - 2*lambda - 3.
    2. The eigenvalues command returns a list of eigenvalues [-3, -3].
    3. The eigenvectors_right command returns [(-3, [(1, 0)], 2)].
    4. If we begin with the matrix \(A\text{,}\) we find
      1. The eigenvalues are \(\lambda=1\) and \(\lambda=0.1\text{.}\)
      2. The reduced row echelon form is \(\mattwo{-2}{1}{0}{0}\text{,}\) which shows that \(A-I\) is not invertible, as expected.
      3. Sage returns \(\mattwo{1}{0}{0}{1}\text{,}\) which is not correct because \(A-I\) cannot be invertible if \(\lambda=1\) is an eigenvalue of \(A\text{.}\)
      4. Here we find the correct eigenvalues, \(\lambda=1\) with basis vector \(\twovec{1}{2}\) for \(E_1\) and \(\lambda=0.1\) with basis vector \(\twovec{1}{-1}\) for \(E_{0.1}\text{.}\)

    20.2.6 Exercises

    20.2.6.1.

    Answer.
    1. \((2-\lambda)^2\text{.}\) There is a single eigenvalue \(\lambda=2\) having multiplicity \(2\text{.}\)
    2. \((3-\lambda)(4-\lambda)(-6-\lambda)\text{.}\) There are three eigenvalues \(\lambda=3, 4, -6\text{,}\) each of multiplicity \(1\text{.}\)
    3. \((-2-\lambda)^2\text{.}\) There is one eigenvalue \(\lambda=-2\) having multiplicity \(2\text{.}\)
    4. \((3-\lambda)(-2-\lambda)\text{.}\) There are two eigenvalues \(\lambda=3\) and \(\lambda=-2\text{,}\) each having multiplicity \(1\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. The characteristic polynomial is \(\det(A-\lambda I) = (2-\lambda)^2\text{.}\) There is a single eigenvalue \(\lambda=2\) having multiplicity \(2\text{.}\)
    2. The characteristic polynomial is \(\det(A-\lambda I) = (3-\lambda)(4-\lambda)(-6-\lambda)\text{.}\) There are three eigenvalues \(\lambda=3, 4, -6\text{,}\) each of multiplicity \(1\text{.}\)
    3. The characteristic polynomial is \(\det(A-\lambda I) = (-2-\lambda)^2\text{,}\) showing that there is one eigenvalue \(\lambda=-2\) having multiplicity \(2\text{.}\)
    4. The characteristic polynomial is \(\det(A-\lambda I) = (3-\lambda)(-2-\lambda)\text{.}\) There are two eigenvalues \(\lambda=3\) and \(\lambda=-2\text{,}\) each having multiplicity \(1\text{.}\)

    20.2.6.2.

    Answer.
    1. It is not possible.
    2. \(\left\{ \threevec100, \threevec{-1}{1}0, \threevec10{-3} \right\} \text{.}\)
    3. \(\displaystyle \left\{\twovec10, \twovec01\right\}\)
    4. \(\displaystyle \left\{\twovec12,\twovec{-2}1\right\}\)
    Solution.
    1. There is a single eigenvalue \(\lambda=2\) and \(\dim E_2=1\) so it is not possible to find a basis for \(\real^2\) consisting of eigenvectors of \(A\text{.}\)
    2. The three eigenvalues each have multiplicity one so we know that their eigenspaces are one-dimensional. We find a basis vector for \(E_3\) is \(\threevec100\text{,}\) for \(E_4\) is \(\threevec{-1}10\text{,}\) and for \(E_{-6}\) is \(\threevec10{-3}\text{.}\) A basis for \(\real^3\) consisting of eigenvectors of \(A\) is therefore
      \begin{equation*} \left\{ \threevec100, \threevec{-1}{1}0, \threevec10{-3} \right\}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    3. Since \(A-(-2)I\) is the zero matrix, every vector is an eigenvector of \(A\text{.}\) This means that \(\left\{\twovec10, \twovec01\right\}\) is a basis of \(\real^2\) consisting of eigenvectors.
    4. The multiplicity of each eigenvalue is one so there will be a basis of \(\real^2\) consisting of eigenvectors. In particular, a basis vector for \(E_3\) is \(\twovec12\) and a basis vector for \(E_{-2}\) is \(\twovec{-2}1\text{.}\) This means that \(\left\{\twovec12,\twovec{-2}1\right\}\) is a basis for \(\real^2\) consisting of eigenvectors of \(A\text{.}\)

    20.2.6.3.

    Answer.
    1. False
    2. True
    3. True
    4. False
    5. True
    Solution.
    1. False. This is true for a diagonal matrix, but it is not generally true as we see by considering the matrix \(\mattwo{1}{2}{2}{1}\) whose eigenvalues are \(\lambda = 3\) and \(\lambda=-1\text{.}\)
    2. True. If \(m\) is the multiplicity, we have \(1\leq\dim E_\lambda \leq m=1\) so we must have \(\dim E_\lambda = 1\text{.}\)
    3. True. If \(\lambda=0\) is an eigenvalue, then an associated eigenvector \(\vvec\) is a nonzero solution to the homogeneous equation \(A\xvec=\zerovec\text{.}\) This would say that \(A\) is not invertible.
    4. False. The degree of the characteristic polynomial equals the number of rows and columns of the square matrix.
    5. True. An eigenvector \(\vvec\) associated to the eigenvalue \(\lambda\) satisfies \((A-\lambda I)\vvec=\zerovec\text{.}\) This is the same equation that characterizes the null space \(\nul(A-\lambda I)\text{.}\)

    20.2.6.4.

    Answer.
    1. \(\lambda=-6,6,-10\text{.}\)
    2. The standard basis vectors \(\evec_j\) are eigenvectors associated to the diagonal entries.
    3. Yes.
    4. \(\lambda=0,2,-2\text{.}\) The matrix \(A\) is not invertible, but there is a basis for \(\real^3\) consisting of eigenvectors of \(A\text{.}\)
    5. \(\det(A^2-\lambda I) = (16-\lambda)(4-\lambda)(1-\lambda)\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. If \(A\vvec=\lambda\vvec\text{,}\) then \(2A\vvec = 2\lambda\vvec\text{.}\) This says that the eigenvalues of \(2A\) are \(\lambda=-6,6,-10\text{.}\)
    2. The standard basis vectors \(\evec_j\) are eigenvectors associated to the diagonal entries.
    3. Yes. Since there are three distinct eigenvalues, the multiplicity of each eigenvalue must be one. Therefore, the dimension of each eigenspace is one. If we choose a basis vector for each of the eigenspaces, we will obtain a basis for \(\real^3\text{.}\)
    4. The eigenvalues are determined by \(\det(A-\lambda I) = -\lambda^3+4\lambda = -\lambda(2-\lambda)(-2-\lambda)\text{,}\) which shows that the eigenvalues are \(\lambda=0,2,-2\text{.}\) This shows that \(A\) is not invertible since \(\lambda=0\) is an eigenvalue. There is, however, a basis for \(\real^3\) consisting of eigenvectors of \(A\) since the three eigenvalues are distinct.
    5. If \(\lambda\) is an eigenvalue of \(A\text{,}\) then \(\lambda^2\) is an eigenvalue of \(A^2\text{.}\) Therefore, the characteristic polynomial of \(A^2\) is \(\det(A^2-\lambda I) = (16-\lambda)(4-\lambda)(1-\lambda)\text{.}\)

    20.2.6.5.

    Answer.
    1. A basis of eigenvectors is
      \begin{equation*} \left\{\threevec012, \threevec10{-1}, \threevec{-2}{1}{3}\right\}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    2. It is not possible to find a basis of eigenvectors.
    3. A basis of eigenvectors is
      \begin{equation*} \left\{\threevec{-2}32, \threevec10{-1}, \threevec012\right\}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    Solution.
    1. Sage tells us there are three distinct eigenvalues \(\lambda=3,2,-1\text{,}\) each having multiplicity one. A basis of eigenvectors is
      \begin{equation*} \left\{\threevec012, \threevec10{-1}, \threevec{-2}{1}{3}\right\}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    2. It is not possible to find a basis of eigenvectors because the eigenvalue \(\lambda=-1\) has multiplicity two but its eigenspace is one-dimensional.
    3. It is possible to find a basis for \(\real^3\) consisting of eignevectors because one eigenvalue \(\lambda=1\) has multiplicity one while the other \(\lambda=-1\) has multiplicity two and a two-dimensional eigenspace. A basis is
      \begin{equation*} \left\{\threevec{-2}32, \threevec10{-1}, \threevec012\right\}\text{.} \end{equation*}

    20.2.6.6.

    Answer.
    1. Both equal \(-3\text{.}\)
    2. Both equal \(12\text{.}\)
    3. \(\det A\) equals the product of the eigenvalues.
    4. We see that \(\det A = \lambda_1\lambda_2\ldots\lambda_n\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. We have \(\det A = -3\text{,}\) and the product of the eigenvalues is \(-3\text{.}\)
    2. We have \(\det A = 12\text{,}\) and the product of the eigenvalues is \(12\)
    3. We suspect that \(\det A\) equals the product of the eigenvalues.
    4. Setting \(\lambda=0\text{,}\) we have
      \begin{equation*} \begin{aligned} \det(A-0I) \amp {}={} (\lambda_1-0)(\lambda_2-0)\ldots(\lambda_m-0) \\ \det A \amp {}={}\lambda_1\lambda_2\ldots\lambda_n\text{.} \end{aligned} \end{equation*}
      Notice that we mean the product of the eigenvalues, including their multiplicities.

    20.2.6.7.

    Answer.
    1. \(\lambda_1=1.1\) with associated eigenvector \(\vvec_1=\twovec11\) and \(\lambda_2=0.8\) with associated eigenvector \(\vvec_2=\twovec21\text{.}\)
    2. \(\xvec_0=\vvec_1+5\vvec_2\text{.}\)
    3. We have
      \begin{equation*} \begin{aligned} \xvec_1 \amp {}={} 1.1\vvec_1+0.8\cdot5\vvec_2 \\ \xvec_2 \amp {}={} 1.1^2\vvec_1+0.8^2\cdot5\vvec_2 \\ \xvec_3 \amp {}={} 1.1^3\vvec_1+0.8^3\cdot5\vvec_2 \\ \end{aligned}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    4. \(\xvec_k \approx \twovec{1.1^k}{1.1^k}\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. We find the eigenvalues \(\lambda_1=1.1\) with associated eigenvector \(\vvec_1=\twovec11\) and \(\lambda_2=0.8\) with associated eigenvector \(\vvec_2=\twovec21\text{.}\)
    2. After constructing an augmented matrix, we find that \(\xvec_0=\vvec_1+5\vvec_2 \text{.}\)
    3. Since \(A(c_1\vvec_1+c_2\vvec_2) = 1.1c_1\vvec_1 + 0.8c_2\vvec_2\text{,}\) we have
      \begin{equation*} \begin{aligned} \xvec_1 \amp {}={} 1.1\vvec_1+0.8\cdot5\vvec_2 \\ \xvec_2 \amp {}={} 1.1^2\vvec_1+0.8^2\cdot5\vvec_2 \\ \xvec_3 \amp {}={} 1.1^3\vvec_1+0.8^3\cdot5\vvec_2 \\ \end{aligned}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    4. We have \(\xvec_k = 1.1^k\vvec_1+0.8^k\cdot5\vvec_2\text{.}\) As \(k\) grows larger, \(0.8^k\) becomes less significant. Eventually, \(\xvec_k \approx 1.1^k\vvec_1= \twovec{1.1^k}{1.1^k}\text{.}\)

    20.2.6.8.

    Answer.
    1. \(\lambda_1=1\) with associated eigenvector \(\vvec_1=\twovec12\) and \(\lambda_2=0.1\) with associated eigenvector \(\vvec_2=\twovec{-1}{1}\text{.}\)
    2. \(\xvec_0=\frac13\vvec_1+\frac13\vvec_2\text{.}\)
    3. We have
      \begin{equation*} \begin{aligned} \xvec_1 \amp {}={} \frac13\vvec_1+0.1\frac13\vvec_2 \\ \xvec_2 \amp {}={} \frac13\vvec_1+0.1^2\frac13\vvec_2 \\ \xvec_3 \amp {}={} \frac13\vvec_1+0.1^3\frac13\vvec_2 \\ \end{aligned}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    4. \(\xvec_k \approx \twovec{\frac13}{\frac23}\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. We have eigenvalues \(\lambda_1=1\) with associated eigenvector \(\vvec_1=\twovec12\) and \(\lambda_2=0.1\) with associated eigenvector \(\vvec_2=\twovec{-1}{1}\text{.}\)
    2. After constructing an augmented matrix, we find \(\xvec_0=\frac13\vvec_1+\frac13\vvec_2\text{.}\)
    3. Since \(A(c_1\vvec_1+c_2\vvec_2) = c_1\vvec_1 + 0.1c_2\vvec_2\text{,}\) we have
      \begin{equation*} \begin{aligned} \xvec_1 \amp {}={} \frac13\vvec_1+0.1\frac13\vvec_2 \\ \xvec_2 \amp {}={} \frac13\vvec_1+0.1^2\frac13\vvec_2 \\ \xvec_3 \amp {}={} \frac13\vvec_1+0.1^3\frac13\vvec_2. \\ \end{aligned} \end{equation*}
    4. We have \(\xvec_k = \frac13\vvec_1+0.1^k\frac13\vvec_2\text{.}\) As \(k\) grows larger, \(0.1^k\) becomes less significant. Eventually, \(\xvec_k \approx \frac13\vvec_1= \twovec{\frac13}{\frac23}\text{.}\)

    20.3 Diagonalization, similarity, and powers of a matrix
    20.3.1 Diagonalization of matrices

    Activity 20.3.2.

    Solution.
    1. We have \(A\vvec_1=3\vvec_1\) and \(A\vvec_2 = -6\vvec_2\text{.}\)
    2. \(AP = \begin{bmatrix} A\vvec_1 \amp A\vvec_2 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 3\vvec_1 \amp -6\vvec_2 \end{bmatrix}\text{.}\)
    3. \(PD = \begin{bmatrix} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 3 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -6\\ \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 3\vvec_1 \amp -6\vvec_2 \end{bmatrix} \text{.}\) Comparing the result of this part of the activity to the previous, we see that \(AP = PD\text{.}\)
    4. Since the eigenvectors form a basis, the columns of \(P\) are linearly independent and their span is \(\real^2\text{.}\) This guarantees that \(P\) is invertible. Multiplying the equation \(AP=PD\) on the right by \(P^{-1}\) gives \(APP^{-1} = A = PDP^{-1}\text{.}\)
    The rest of the activity can be verified using Sage.

    Activity 20.3.3.

    Solution.
    1. We find that \(A\) has eigenvectors \(\vvec_1=\twovec11\) with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda_1=1\) and \(\vvec_2=\twovec{1}{3}\) with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda_2=-3\text{.}\) We then have \(P=\mattwo1113\) and \(D=\mattwo100{-3}\text{.}\)
    2. Yes. We know that the eigenvectors are \(\vvec_1=\twovec10\) with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda_1=2\) and \(\vvec_2=\twovec01\) with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda_2=-5\text{.}\) Therefore, \(P = \left[\begin{array}{rr}\vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \end{array}\right] = \mattwo1001=I\) and \(D=\mattwo200{-5}=A\text{.}\) This shows that the diagonalization is \(A=IAI^{-1}\text{;}\) that is, since \(A\) is already diagonal, it is diagonalized by the identity matrix.
    3. We find eigenvectors \(\vvec_1=\threevec112\text{,}\) \(\vvec_2=\threevec010\text{,}\) and \(\vvec_3=\threevec001\) with associated eigenvalues \(\lambda_1=-2\text{,}\) \(\lambda_2=-3\text{,}\) and \(\lambda_3=-3\text{.}\) Therefore, \(A = PDP^{-1}\) where
      \begin{equation*} P = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 2 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right], D = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} -2 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -3 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp -3 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{equation*}
    4. Once again, we see that \(\lambda=-2\) is an eigenvalue with multiplicity one and \(\lambda=-3\) is an eigenvalue with multiplicity two. However, \(\dim E_{-3} = 1\) so we are not able to find a basis for \(\real^3\) consisting of eigenvalues of \(A\text{.}\) Therefore, \(A\) is not diagonalizable.
    5. If \(A=PDP^{-1}\text{,}\)
      1. \(A\) is invertible since \(\det A = \det D = -3\text{.}\)
      2. We know that \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2\) are eigenvectors of \(A\) with associated eigenvalues \(\lambda_1=3\) and \(\lambda_2=-1\text{.}\) If \(\vvec\) is an eigenvector of \(A\) with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda\text{,}\) then \(\vvec\) is an eigenvector of \(A^{-1}\) with associated eigenvalue \(\frac1{\lambda}\text{.}\) Therefore, \(A^{-1} = PEP^{-1}\) where \(E = \mattwo{\frac13}00{-1}\text{.}\)
      3. We have \(A^3=PFP^{-1}\) where \(F=\mattwo{27}00{-1}\text{.}\)

    20.3.2 Powers of a diagonalizable matrix

    Activity 20.3.4.

    Solution.
    1. We have
      \begin{equation*} D^2=\mattwo4001, D^3=\mattwo800{-1}, \ldots, D^k=\mattwo{2^k}00{(-1)^k}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    2. We know that \(A^2\vvec = \lambda A\vvec = \lambda^2\vvec\) so that \(\vvec\) is also an eigenvector of \(A^2\) with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda^2\text{.}\)
    3. Since eigenvectors of \(A\) are also eigenvectors of \(A^2\text{,}\) we can use the matrix \(P\) to diagonalize \(A^2\text{.}\) The eigenvalues are squared, however, so we have \(A^2=PEP^{-1}\) where \(E=D^2=\mattwo4001\text{.}\)
    4. We can also see this by noting that
      \begin{equation*} \begin{aligned} A^2 \amp = (PDP^{-1})(PDP^{-1}) = PD(P^{-1}P)DP^{-1} \\ \amp = PDIDP^{-1} = PD^2P^{-1}\text{.}\\ \end{aligned} \end{equation*}
    5. \(A^3=PD^3P^{-1}\text{,}\) \(A^4=PD^4P^{-1}\text{,}\) and \(A^k=PD^kP^{-1}\text{.}\)
    6. We can write \(A=PDP^{-1}\) where \(D=\mattwo{0.5}00{0.1}\text{.}\) Therefore, \(A^k=PD^kP^{-1}\) where \(D^k=\mattwo{0.5^k}00{0.1^k}\text{.}\) As \(k\) becomes very large, \(0.5^k\) and \(0.1^k\) become very close to zero. Hence \(D^k\) and \(A^k\) become very close to the zero matrix.

    20.3.3 Similarity and complex eigenvalues

    Activity 20.3.5.

    Solution.
    1. The matrix \(S=\mattwo r00r\) has the geometric effect of scaling vectors uniformly by a factor of \(r\) while the matrix \(R=\mattwo{\cos\theta}{-\sin\theta}{\sin\theta}{\cos\theta}\) rotates vectors by \(\theta\text{.}\)
    2. We have \(a=b=1\) so we form the matrix \(C=\mattwo1{-1}11 = \mattwo{\sqrt{2}}00{\sqrt{2}} \mattwo{\cos(45^\circ)}{-\sin(45^\circ)} {\sin(45^\circ)}{\cos(45^\circ)}\text{.}\) This shows that \(C\) will scale vectors by a factor of \(\sqrt2\) while rotating them by \(45^\circ\text{.}\)
    3. Sage will verify this relationship.
    4. As we saw earlier, we have \(A^2 = (PCP^{-1})(PCP^{-1}) = PC^2P^{-1}\) and hence \(A^k = PC^kP^{-1}\text{.}\)
    5. We have \(a=1\) and \(b=-1\) so we form the matrix \(C'=\mattwo1{1}{-1}1 = \mattwo{\sqrt{2}}00{\sqrt{2}} \mattwo{\cos(-45^\circ)}{-\sin(-45^\circ)} {\sin(-45^\circ)}{\cos(-45^\circ)}\text{.}\) This shows that \(C\) will scale vectors by a factor of \(\sqrt2\) while rotating them by \(-45^\circ\text{.}\)

    20.3.5 Exercises

    20.3.5.1.

    Answer.
    1. \(P = \mattwo12{-1}1\) and \(D=\mattwo200{-3}\)
    2. \(A\) is not diagonalizable.
    3. \(A\) is not diagonalizable.
    4. \(P = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 9 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 6 \amp 6 \amp 0 \\ -2 \amp -1 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right]\) and \(D = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -2 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 4 \\ \end{array}\right]\)
    5. \(P = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp -1 \amp 0 \\ 1 \amp 0 \amp -1 \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right]\) and \(D = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 5 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp -1 \\ \end{array}\right]\)
    Solution.
    1. We find that \(\vvec_1=\twovec{1}{-2}\) is an eigenvector with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda_1=2\) as is \(\vvec_2=\twovec{2}{1}\) with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda_2=-3\text{.}\) Therefore, we have \(A=PDP^{-1}\) where
      \begin{equation*} P = \mattwo12{-1}1, D=\mattwo200{-3}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    2. We see that \(\lambda=-2\) is an eigenvalue having multiplicity two. However, \(\dim E_{-2} = 1\) so we cannot find a basis for \(\real^2\) consisting of eigenvectors of \(A\text{.}\) Therefore, \(A\) is not diagonalizable.
    3. We see that \(A\) has complex eigenvalues \(\lambda=1\pm 2i\) so it is not diagonalizable in the form \(A=PDP^{-1}\) for a diagonal matrix \(D\text{.}\)
    4. The matrix \(A\) has three distinct eigenvalues \(\lambda_1=1\text{,}\) \(\lambda_2=-2\text{,}\) and \(\lambda_3=4\) with associated eigenvectors \(\vvec_1=\threevec96{-2}\text{,}\) \(\vvec_2=\threevec06{-1}\text{,}\) and \(\vvec_3=\threevec001\text{.}\) This shows us that \(A=PDP^{-1}\) where
      \begin{equation*} P = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 9 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 6 \amp 6 \amp 0 \\ -2 \amp -1 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right], D = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -2 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 4 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.} \end{equation*}
    5. We have an eigenvalue \(\lambda=-1\) having multiplicity two, but its eigenspace has dimension two so \(A\) is diagonalizable. In particular, we choose
      \begin{equation*} P = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp -1 \amp 0 \\ 1 \amp 0 \amp -1 \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right], D = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 5 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp -1 \\ \end{array}\right] \end{equation*}
      and have \(A=PDP^{-1}\text{.}\)

    20.3.5.2.

    Answer.
    1. There are two real eigenvalues.
    2. There is a single real eigenvalue.
    3. \(C=\mattwo1{-2}21\) or \(C=\mattwo12{-2}1\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. We have two real eigenvalues \(\lambda=2, -3\text{.}\)
    2. We have a single real eigenvalue \(\lambda=-2\text{.}\)
    3. We have complex eigenvalues \(\lambda=1\pm2i\) so we can choose \(C=\mattwo1{-2}21\) or \(C=\mattwo12{-2}1\text{.}\)

    20.3.5.3.

    Answer.
    1. False
    2. True
    3. True
    4. True
    5. False
    Solution.
    1. False. A matrix can be invertible without us being able to form a basis consisting of eigenvectors. An example is \(\mattwo2102\text{.}\)
    2. True. If \(A\) and \(B\) are similar, then \(A=PBP^{-1}\) so that \(\det A = \det B\text{.}\) If \(A\) is invertible, we know that \(\det A \neq 0\text{,}\) which also tells us that \(\det B\neq 0\) and hence that \(B\) is invertible.
    3. True. If \(A=PDP^{-1}\text{,}\) then the columns of \(P\) are eigenvectors of \(A\) that form a basis for \(\real^n\text{.}\)
    4. True. If \(A=PDP^{-1}\text{,}\) then \(A^{10}=PD^{10}P^{-1}\text{.}\)
    5. False. It is possible that \(A\) has eigenvalue \(\lambda=0\text{,}\) which would imply that \(A\) is not invertible.

    20.3.5.4.

    Answer.
    1. Yes
    2. No
    3. Yes
    4. Only the identity
    5. \(A=\mattwo4004\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. Yes. If \(A\) has \(3\) real and distinct eigenvalues, then there is a basis of \(\real^3\) consisting of eigenvectors of \(A\text{.}\) Therefore, \(A\) is diagonalizable.
    2. No. We can write \(A=PCP^{-1}\) where \(C=\mattwo a{-b}ba\text{,}\) but \(A\) is not diagonalizable.
    3. Yes. Since \(B\) is diagonal and \(A=PBP^{-1}\text{,}\) then \(A\) is diagonalizable.
    4. Only the identity because \(A=PIP^{-1} = PP^{-1} = I\text{.}\)
    5. \(A=\mattwo4004\text{.}\) If we denote \(D=\mattwo4004=4I\text{,}\) then \(A=PDP^{-1}=P4IP^{-1} = 4I = D\text{.}\)

    20.3.5.5.

    Answer.
    1. Multiplying by \(A\) uniformly stretches vectors by a factor of \(2\text{.}\)
    2. This is a shear so that vectors are stretched and then pushed horizontally.
    3. We write \((a,b) = (3,6) = (r\cos\theta, r\sin\theta)\) where \(r=3\sqrt{5}\) and \(\theta = \arctan(2)\text{.}\) Therefore, \(A\) will stretch vectors by a factor of \(3\sqrt{5}\) and rotate them by \(\theta\approx 63.4^\circ\text{.}\)
    4. Vectors are stretched in the horizontal direction by a factor of \(4\) and stretched vertically by a factor of \(2\) before being reflected in the horizontal axis.
    5. This matrix has eigenvectors \(\vvec_1=\twovec11\) with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda_1=4\) and \(\vvec_2=\twovec{-1}{1}\) with \(\lambda_2=-2\text{.}\) Therefore, \(A\) stretches vectors by a factor of \(4\) in the direction of \(\vvec_1\) and a factor of \(2\) in the direction of \(\vvec_1\) before reflecting in the line defined by \(\vvec_1\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. Multiplying by \(A\) uniformly stretches vectors by a factor of \(2\text{.}\)
    2. This is a shear so that vectors are stretched and then pushed horizontally.
    3. We write \((a,b) = (3,6) = (r\cos\theta, r\sin\theta)\) where \(r=3\sqrt{5}\) and \(\theta = \arctan(2)\text{.}\) Therefore, \(A\) will stretch vectors by a factor of \(3\sqrt{5}\) and rotate them by \(\theta\approx 63.4^\circ\text{.}\)
    4. Vectors are stretched in the horizontal direction by a factor of \(4\) and stretched vertically by a factor of \(2\) before being reflected in the horizontal axis.
    5. This matrix has eigenvectors \(\vvec_1=\twovec11\) with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda_1=4\) and \(\vvec_2=\twovec{-1}{1}\) with \(\lambda_2=-2\text{.}\) Therefore, \(A\) stretches vectors by a factor of \(4\) in the direction of \(\vvec_1\) and a factor of \(2\) in the direction of \(\vvec_1\) before reflecting in the line defined by \(\vvec_1\text{.}\)

    20.3.5.6.

    Answer.
    1. If \(A=PBP^{-1}\text{,}\) then \(B=P^{-1}AP\text{.}\) If we call \(Q=P^{-1}\text{,}\) then \(B=QAQ^{-1}\text{,}\) which shows that \(B\) is similar to \(A\text{.}\)
    2. If \(A=PBP^{-1}\) and \(B=QCQ^{-1}\text{,}\) then \(A=PQCP^{-1}Q^{-1} = (PQ)C(PQ)^{-1}\text{,}\) which shows that \(A\) is similar to \(C\text{.}\)
    3. If \(B\) is diagonalizable, then it is similar to a diagonal matrix \(D\text{.}\) Since \(A\) is similar to \(B\) and \(B\) is similar to \(D\text{,}\) we know that \(A\) is also similar to \(D\) so that \(A\) is diagonalizable.
    4. If \(A=PBP^{-1}\text{,}\) then
      \begin{equation*} \begin{aligned} \det(A-\lambda I) \amp = \det(PBP^{-1}-\lambda PP^{-1}) \\ \amp = \det[P(B-\lambda I)P^{-1}] \\ \amp = \det(B-\lambda I)\text{.} \\ \end{aligned} \end{equation*}
    5. The eigenvalues of a matrix are the roots of its characteristic polynomial. If \(A\) and \(B\) are similar, then they have the same characteristic polynomial and hence the same eigenvalues.
    Solution.
    1. If \(A=PBP^{-1}\text{,}\) then \(B=P^{-1}AP\text{.}\) If we call \(Q=P^{-1}\text{,}\) then \(B=QAQ^{-1}\text{,}\) which shows that \(B\) is similar to \(A\text{.}\)
    2. If \(A=PBP^{-1}\) and \(B=QCQ^{-1}\text{,}\) then \(A=PQCP^{-1}Q^{-1} = (PQ)C(PQ)^{-1}\text{,}\) which shows that \(A\) is similar to \(C\text{.}\)
    3. If \(B\) is diagonalizable, then it is similar to a diagonal matrix \(D\text{.}\) Since \(A\) is similar to \(B\) and \(B\) is similar to \(D\text{,}\) we know that \(A\) is also similar to \(D\) so that \(A\) is diagonalizable.
    4. If \(A=PBP^{-1}\text{,}\) then
      \begin{equation*} \begin{aligned} \det(A-\lambda I) \amp = \det(PBP^{-1}-\lambda PP^{-1}) \\ \amp = \det[P(B-\lambda I)P^{-1}] \\ \amp = \det(B-\lambda I)\text{.} \\ \end{aligned} \end{equation*}
    5. The eigenvalues of a matrix are the roots of its characteristic polynomial. If \(A\) and \(B\) are similar, then they have the same characteristic polynomial and hence the same eigenvalues.

    20.3.5.7.

    Answer.
    1. The matrix \(D\) projects vectors onto the horizontal axis.
    2. \(A\) projects vectors onto the line defined by the eigenvector \(\twovec12\text{.}\)
    3. \(A^k=A\text{.}\)
    4. No
    Solution.
    1. The matrix \(D\) projects vectors onto the horizontal axis; that is, it produces the shadow of a vector on the horizontal axis from a flashlight shining down the vertical axis.
    2. \(A\) projects vectors onto the line defined by the eigenvector \(\twovec12\text{.}\)
    3. Since \(A=PDP^{-1}\) and \(D^2 = D\text{,}\) we have \(A^2 = PD^2P^{-1} = PDP^{-1} = A\text{.}\) That is, \(A^2 = A\) and \(A^k=A\text{.}\)
    4. \(A\) is not invertible because \(\lambda=0\) is an eigenvalue.

    20.3.5.8.

    Answer.
    1. \(\lambda = 3\pm i\text{.}\)
    2. If \(\lambda=3+i\text{,}\) then \(C=\mattwo3{-1}13\text{.}\)
    3. \(\displaystyle \vvec = \twovec{1-i}{1}\)
    4. \(\vvec_1=\twovec11\) and \(\vvec_2=\twovec{1}{0}\text{.}\)
    5. \(\displaystyle P = \mattwo1110\)
    Solution.
    1. The eigenvalues are \(\lambda = 3\pm i\text{.}\)
    2. We will choose \(\lambda=3+i\) so that \(C=\mattwo3{-1}13\text{.}\)
    3. Construct the matrix
      \begin{equation*} A-(3+i)I = \mattwo{-1-i}{2}{-1}{1-i} \sim \mattwo{1}{-1+i}00 \end{equation*}
      so that a basis vector for the null space is \(\vvec = \twovec{1-i}{1}\text{.}\)
    4. We have \(\vvec=\twovec{1-i}{1} = \twovec11-i\twovec{1}{0}\) giving \(\vvec_1=\twovec11\) and \(\vvec_2=\twovec{1}{0}\text{.}\)
    5. We let \(P = \mattwo1110\) and verify that \(A=PCP^{-1}\text{.}\)

    20.3.5.9.

    Answer.
    In each case, the vectors are rotated by \(90^\circ\text{.}\) Note that the figures below are draw at different scales.
    1. The vectors are stretched by a factor of 1.4.
    2. The vectors are stretched by a factor of 0.8.
    3. The length of the vectors is unchanged.
    4. For different values of \(r\text{,}\)
      1. The vectors are pulled into the origin as their lengths become increasingly small.
      2. The length of the vectors is unchanged.
      3. The vectors are pushed away from the origin as their lengths become increasingly large.
    Solution.
    In each case, the vectors are rotated by \(90^\circ\text{.}\) Note that the figures below are draw at different scales.
    1. The vectors are stretched by a factor of 1.4.
    2. The vectors are stretched by a factor of 0.8.
    3. The length of the vectors is unchanged.
    4. For different values of \(r\text{,}\)
      1. The vectors are pulled into the origin as their lengths become increasingly small.
      2. The length of the vectors is unchanged.
      3. The vectors are pushed away from the origin as their lengths become increasingly large.

    20.3.5.10.

    Answer.
    5. Vectors will be pulled into the origin.
    Solution.
    1. Vectors are expanded horizontally and compressed vertically.
    2. Vectors are compressed both horizontally and vertically.
    3. Vectors are expanded both horizontally and vertically.
    4. There are eigenvectors \(\vvec_1=\twovec11\) with \(\lambda_1 = 1.2\) and \(\vvec_2=\twovec{-1}1\) with \(\lambda_2=0.7\text{.}\) Vectors are expanded in the direction of \(\vvec_1\) and compressed in the direction of \(\vvec_2\text{.}\)
    5. Because both eigenvalues have an absolute value smaller than \(1\text{,}\) vectors will be compressed in the direction of both eigenvectors and hence be pulled into the origin.

    20.4 Dynamical systems
    20.4.1 A first example

    Activity 20.4.2.

    Solution.
    1. We find that \(A\vvec_1=\twovec{2.6}{1.3} = 1.3\vvec_1\) and \(A\vvec_2=\twovec{-1}{0.5}=0.5\vvec_2\text{.}\) This shows that \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2\) are eigenvectors with associated eigenvalues \(\lambda_1=1.3\) and \(\lambda_2=0.5\text{.}\)
    2. Solving for the weights of the linear combination of \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2\) that produces \(\xvec_0\text{,}\) we find that \(\xvec_0=2\vvec_1+\vvec_2\text{.}\)
    3. Each time we multiply by \(A\text{,}\) the eigenvectors are multiplied by their associated eigenvalues. This gives
      \begin{equation*} \begin{aligned} \xvec_1 = A\xvec_0 \amp = 2(1.3)\vvec_1 + 0.5\vvec_2 \\ \xvec_2 = A\xvec_1 \amp = 2(1.3)^2\vvec_1 + 0.5^2\vvec_2 \\ \xvec_3 = A\xvec_2 \amp = 2(1.3)^3\vvec_1 + 0.5^3\vvec_2\text{.} \\ \end{aligned} \end{equation*}
    4. After a long time \(0.5^k\approx 0\) so we have \(\xvec_k \approx 2(1.3)^k\vvec_1\text{.}\)
    5. More generally, we have \(\xvec_k=2(1.3)^k\vvec_1 + 0.5^k\vvec_2\text{.}\) As \(k\) grows large, \(0.5^k\) becomes insignificantly small so that \(\xvec_k\approx 2(1.3)^k\vvec_1\text{.}\) This means that \(R_k\approx 4(1.3)^k\) and \(S_k\approx2(1.3)^k\) so that the ratio \(R_k/S_k \approx 2\text{.}\)
    6. We see that \(\xvec_{k+1}\approx 1.3\xvec_k\) so that the populations both grow by a factor of approximately 1.3, which is a 30% growth rate.
    7. Now we have \(\xvec_0 = 3\vvec_1 + \vvec_2\text{.}\) In the same way, when \(k \) is very large, we have \(\xvec_k\approx 3(1.3)^k\vvec_1\) so that \(R_k\approx6(1.3)^k\) and \(S_k\approx3(1.3)^k\text{.}\) This gives the same ratio: \(R_k/S_k\approx 2\text{.}\)

    20.4.2 Classifying dynamical systems

    Activity 20.4.3.

    Solution.

    Activity 20.4.4.

    Solution.
    1. With this matrix \(A\text{,}\) we have
      \begin{equation*} \begin{aligned} R_{k+1} \amp = 0.7R_k \\ S_{k+1} \amp = 1.6S_k\text{.} \\ \end{aligned} \end{equation*}
      This shows that the population of one species does not depend on the other. This dynamical system is a saddle because we have the eigenvalues \(\lambda_1=0.7\) and \(\lambda_2=1.6\text{.}\) Eventually, species \(R\) will become extinct while species \(S\) grows by a factor of 1.6.
    2. Now we have
      \begin{equation*} \begin{alignedat}{3} R_{k+1} \amp {}={} \amp 0.7R_k \amp{}+{} \amp 0.3S_k\\ S_{k+1} \amp {}={} \amp \amp \amp 1.6S_k\text{.} \\ \end{alignedat} \end{equation*}
      The population of species \(S\) is not influenced by species \(R\text{.}\) However, we see that the population of species \(R\) grows in the presence of species \(S\text{.}\) In other words, species \(S\) helps species \(R\) to grow so we say that \(S\) is beneficial for \(R\text{.}\)
      Because the eigenvalues are \(\lambda_1=0.7\) and \(\lambda_2=1.6\text{,}\) this dynamical system is again a saddle. The associated eigenvectors are \(\vvec_1=\twovec10\) and \(\vvec_2=\twovec13\text{.}\) After a long time, the population vector \(\xvec_k\approx c_1(1.6)^k\vvec_2\) so both populations grow by a factor of 1.6 and with a ratio \(R_k/S_k=1/3.\)
    3. Here we have
      \begin{equation*} \begin{alignedat}{3} R_{k+1} \amp {}={} \amp 0.7R_k \amp{}+{} \amp 0.5S_k\\ S_{k+1} \amp {}={} \amp -0.4R_k \amp {}+{}\amp 1.6S_k\text{.} \\ \end{alignedat} \end{equation*}
      Species \(S\) helps species \(R\) to grow, while species \(R\) inhibits the growth of species \(S\text{.}\) One explanation for this is that species \(R\) preys on species \(S\) as a food source.
      We have eigenvectors \(\vvec_1=\twovec11\) with associated eigenvalue \(\lambda_1=1.2\) and \(\vvec_2=\twovec{5}{4}\) with \(\lambda_2=1.1\text{.}\) This dynamical system is a repellor so both species will grow arbitrarily large.
    4. This example is similar to the previous one, but the coefficients are slightly different. We see that the growth rate of both species is smaller. For instance, in the previous problem, we had \(R_{k+1}=0.7R_k+\ldots\) while we now have \(R_{k+1}=0.5R_k+\ldots\text{.}\) This says that the reproduction rate of species \(R\) has decreased from \(0.7\) to \(0.5\text{.}\) In the same way, that of species \(S\) has decreased from \(1.6\) to \(1.1\text{.}\) Also, \(R_{k+1}=\ldots + 0.2S_k\) so the presence of species \(S\) is less beneficial to species \(R\text{.}\)
      We now have the eigenvalues \(\lambda_1=0.9\) and \(\lambda_2=0.7\text{,}\) which means that this dynamical system is an attractor and that both species will become extinct.

    20.4.3 A \(3\times3\) system

    Activity 20.4.5.

    Solution.
    1. We have the relationships
      \begin{equation*} \begin{alignedat}{4} J_{k+1} \amp {}={} \amp \amp \amp \amp \amp 0.4 A_k \\ Y_{k+1} \amp {}={} \amp 0.8 J_k \\ A_{k+1} \amp {}={} \amp \amp \amp 0.9Y_k \amp {}+{} \amp 0.8A_k\text{.} \\ \end{alignedat} \end{equation*}
    2. The matrix \(A=\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 0 \amp 0 \amp 0.4 \\ 0.8 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0.9 \amp 0.8 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.}\)
    3.
