    6. If we choose a vector \(\nvec=\twovec{A}{B}\) that is perpendicular to the line and a point \(\pvec\) on the line, we have \(\nvec\cdot\xvec = Ax + By = \nvec\cdot\pvec = C\text{.}\)

    22.2 Orthogonal complements and the matrix transpose
    22.2.1 Orthogonal complements

    Activity 22.2.2.

    Answer.
    1. \(\wvec_1\cdot\xvec = x_1 - 2x_3 = 0\text{.}\)
    2. \(\wvec_2\cdot\xvec = x_1+x_2 - x_3 = 0\text{.}\)
    3. \(B = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp -1 \\ \end{bmatrix}\) so \(\xvec=x_3\threevec2{-1}1\text{.}\)
    4. By distributivity, \((c_1\wvec_1+c_2\wvec_2)\cdot\xvec= c_1\wvec_1\cdot\xvec + c_2\wvec_2\cdot\xvec = 0\text{.}\)
    5. A basis consists of \(\threevec1{-1}1\text{,}\) and \(W^\perp\) is one-dimensional.
    6. The orthogonal complement of \(W^\perp\) is \(W\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. We have the equation \(\wvec_1\cdot\xvec = x_1 - 2x_3 = 0\text{.}\)
    2. We have the equation \(\wvec_2\cdot\xvec = x_1+x_2 - x_3 = 0\text{.}\)
    3. These two equations give \(B\xvec=\zerovec\) where
      \begin{equation*} B = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp -1 \\ \end{bmatrix} \sim \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{,} \end{equation*}
      whose solutions have the parametric form \(\xvec=x_3\threevec2{-1}1\text{.}\)
    4. By distributivity, \((c_1\wvec_1+c_2\wvec_2)\cdot\xvec= c_1\wvec_1\cdot\xvec + c_2\wvec_2\cdot\xvec = 0\text{.}\)
    5. \(W^\perp\) is the solution space to the equation \(B\xvec=\zerovec\text{.}\) Therefore, a basis consists of the single vector \(\threevec1{-1}1\text{,}\) and \(W^\perp\) is one-dimensional.
    6. Since every vector in \(W^\perp\) is orthogonal to every vector in \(W\text{,}\) the orthogonal complement of \(W^\perp\) is \(W\text{.}\)

    22.2.2 The matrix transpose

    Activity 22.2.3.

    Answer.
    1. \(\displaystyle A^T = \begin{bmatrix} 3 \amp -1 \amp 0 \\ 4 \amp 2 \amp -2 \end{bmatrix}\)
    2. \(\vvec_1\cdot\wvec =-10\text{,}\) \(\vvec_2\cdot\wvec =6\text{.}\)
    3. \begin{equation*} A^T\wvec =\twovec{\vvec_1\cdot\wvec}{\vvec_2\cdot\wvec} \end{equation*}
    4. \(A^T\xvec = \zerovec\text{.}\)
    5. \(\xvec=x_3\threevec1{-3}1\text{.}\)
    6. \(A^T\xvec = \twovec{\vvec_1\cdot\xvec}{\vvec_2\cdot\xvec} = \twovec00\text{.}\)
    7. Apply the distributive property of dot products.
    Solution.
    1. \(\displaystyle A^T = \begin{bmatrix} 3 \amp -1 \amp 0 \\ 4 \amp 2 \amp -2 \end{bmatrix}\)
    2. \begin{align*} \vvec_1\cdot\wvec \amp{}={} 2(-2) + 0(2) + (-2)3 \amp{}={} -10\\ \vvec_2\cdot\wvec \amp{}={} 1(-2) + 1(2) + 2(3) \amp{}={} 6 \end{align*}
    3. \begin{equation*} A^T\wvec = \twovec{2(-2)+0(2)+(-2)3}{1(-2)+1(2)+2(3)} = \twovec{-10}{6} =\twovec{\vvec_1\cdot\wvec}{\vvec_2\cdot\wvec} \end{equation*}
    4. Both dot products are 0 so we have \(A^T\xvec = \zerovec\text{.}\)
    5. We need to solve the equation \(A^T\xvec = \zerovec\) so we find the reduced row echelon form
      \begin{equation*} A^T \sim \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 3\\ \end{bmatrix}\text{.} \end{equation*}
      The vectors orthogonal to both \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2\) have the form \(\xvec=x_3\threevec1{-3}1\text{.}\)
    6. \(A^T\xvec = \twovec{\vvec_1\cdot\xvec}{\vvec_2\cdot\xvec} = \twovec00\) tells us that \(\vvec_1\cdot\xvec=0\) and \(\vvec_2\cdot\xvec=0\text{.}\)
    7. Since \(\xvec\) is orthogonal to both \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2\text{,}\) we have
      \begin{equation*} (c_1\vvec_1+c_2\vvec_2)\cdot\xvec = c_1\vvec_1\cdot\xvec + c_2\vvec_2\cdot\xvec = 0 \end{equation*}

    22.2.3 Properties of the matrix transpose

    Activity 22.2.4.

    Answer.
    1. \((A+B)^T = A^T + B^T\text{.}\)
    2. \((A^T)^T = A\text{.}\)
    3. \(\displaystyle \det(C^T) = \det(C)\)
    4. \((AC)^T=C^TA^T\text{.}\)
    5. \(\displaystyle I^T=I\)
    6. \((D^T)^{-1} = (D^{-1})^T\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. \((A+B)^T = A^T + B^T\text{.}\)
    2. \((A^T)^T = A\text{.}\)
    3. \(\displaystyle \det(C^T) = \det(C)\)
      1. \(AC = \begin{bmatrix} -8 \amp -6 \amp -3 \\ 1 \amp 6 \amp -8 \end{bmatrix}\) and \((AC)^T = \begin{bmatrix} -8 \amp 1 \\ -6 \amp 6 \\ -3 \amp -8 \end{bmatrix}\)
      2. The product \(A^TC^T\) is not defined because \(A^T\) has two columns and \(C^T\) has three rows.
      3. \(\displaystyle (AC)^T=C^TA^T\)
    5. \(\displaystyle I^T=I\)
    6. We have \(DD^{-1} = I\) so \((DD^{-1})^T = (D^{-1})^TD^T = I^T=I\text{.}\) This means that \((D^T)^{-1} = (D^{-1})^T\text{.}\)

    Activity 22.2.5.

    Answer.
      1. \(\displaystyle 9\times 5\)
      2. \(\displaystyle 5\)
      3. \(\displaystyle 5\times 9\)
      4. \(\displaystyle 5\)
      5. \(\displaystyle 4\)
      6. \(\displaystyle 4\)
      7. \(\displaystyle \dim W + \dim W^\perp = 9 \)
      1. \(\displaystyle 2\)
      2. \(\fourvec1{-1}01\) and \(\fourvec0012\) .
      3. Verify by computing the four dot products.
    Solution.
      1. \(A\) is \(9\times 5\text{.}\)
      2. \(\rank(A) = 5\text{.}\)
      3. \(A^T\) is \(5\times 9\text{.}\)
      4. \(\displaystyle \rank(A^T) = 5\)
      5. \(\displaystyle \dim \nul(A^T) = 9 - 5 = 4\)
      6. \(\displaystyle \dim W^\perp = \dim\nul(A^T) = 4\)
      7. \(\dim W + \dim W^\perp = 9 \) since the subspaces live in \(\real^9\text{.}\)
      1. \(\dim W = 2\) so \(\dim W^\perp = 4-2=2\text{.}\)
      2. A basis is \(\vvec_1=\fourvec1{-1}01\) and \(\vvec_2=\fourvec0012\) .
      3. You can verify by computing the four dot products.

    22.2.5 Exercises

    22.2.5.1.

    Answer.
    1. \(\dim W = 2\) and \(\dim W^\perp = 2\text{.}\)
    2. \(\vvec_1 = \fourvec{-2}{-3}10\) and \(\vvec_2=\fourvec{-1}101\)
    3. Use the dot product.
    Solution.
    1. \(\dim W = 2\) and \(\dim W^\perp = 4-2 = 2\text{.}\)
    2. \(\vvec_1 = \fourvec{-2}{-3}10\) and \(\vvec_2=\fourvec{-1}101\)
    3. Verify that \(\wvec_i\cdot\vvec_j = 0\) for all \(i\) and \(j\text{.}\)

    22.2.5.2.

    Answer.
    1. \(\rank(A) = 2\) and a basis for \(\col(A)\) is \(\threevec{-1}12\) and \(\threevec{-2}31\)
    2. \(\dim\col(A)^\perp = 1\) with basis \(\threevec531\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. \(A\sim\begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \end{bmatrix}\) so \(\rank(A) = 2\) since there are two pivot positions. The reduced row echelon form shows that the third column is a linear combination of the first two so \(\threevec{-1}12\) and \(\threevec{-2}31\) form a basis for \(\col(A)\text{.}\)
    2. We know that \(\dim \col(A)^\perp = 3 - 2 = 1\text{.}\) To find a basis, solve the equation \(A^T\xvec = \zerovec\) to obtain \(\threevec531\text{.}\)

    22.2.5.3.

    Answer.
    1. \(\dim W = 3\text{,}\) \(\dim W^\perp = 1\text{.}\)
    2. \(\fourvec3100\text{,}\) \(\fourvec{-5}010\text{,}\) and \(\fourvec2001\text{.}\)
    3. \(\displaystyle \fourvec1{-3}5{-2}\)
    4. \(\displaystyle \fourvec ABCD\)
    Solution.
    1. \(W = \nul(B)\) where \(B = \begin{bmatrix}1 \amp -3 \amp 5 \amp -2 \end{bmatrix}\) so \(\dim W = 4 -1 =3\text{.}\) Therefore, \(\dim W^\perp = 4-3 = 1\text{.}\)
    2. A basis for \(W\) is \(\fourvec3100\text{,}\) \(\fourvec{-5}010\text{,}\) and \(\fourvec2001\text{.}\)
    3. Since every vector in \(W\) satisfies \(\fourvec1{-3}5{-2}\cdot\xvec = 0\text{,}\) a basis for \(W^\perp\) is \(\fourvec1{-3}5{-2}\)
    4. \(\displaystyle \fourvec ABCD\)

    22.2.5.4.

    Answer.
    1. True
    2. False
    3. True
    4. True
    5. False
    Solution.
    1. True, since \(A^T\xvec=\zerovec\text{,}\) \(\xvec\) is in \(\col(A)^\perp\text{.}\)
    2. False, \((AB)^T\) is a \(4\times2\) matrix, but it is given by \((AB)^T=B^TA^T\text{.}\)
    3. True, because the second component of \(A^T\xvec = \vvec_2\cdot\xvec=0\text{.}\)
    4. True, because \(\dim\col(A)^\perp = 4-\dim\col(A) = 4-3 = 1\text{.}\)
    5. False, \(\rank(A^T) = \rank(A) = 5\text{.}\)

    22.2.5.5.

    Answer.
    1. \(\displaystyle B^{-1}\)
    2. \(\displaystyle A^TA + B^TA + A^TB + B^TB\)
    3. \(\displaystyle AA^T+BA^T\)
    4. \(\displaystyle A^T+2I\)
    Solution.
    1. \(\displaystyle A^T(A^T)^{-1}B^{-1} = B^{-1}\)
    2. \(\displaystyle A^TA + B^TA + A^TB + B^TB\)
    3. \(\displaystyle (A+B)A^T = AA^T+BA^T\)
    4. \(\displaystyle A^T+2I\)

    22.2.5.6.

    Answer.
    1. They must have the same number of rows and columns.
      1. Yes
      2. No
      3. No
      4. Yes
    Solution.
    1. If \(A\) is an \(m\times n\) matrix, then \(A^T\) is \(n\times m\) If these matrices are the same, then \(m=n\text{.}\)
      1. If \(D\) is diagonal, then \(D^T = D\text{.}\)
      2. \((BAB^{-1})^T = (B^{-1})^TA^TB^T\) so this matrix need not be symmetric.
      3. \((AA^T)^T = (A^T)^TA^T = AA^T\) so this matrix is symmetric.
      4. \((BDB^T)^T = (B^T)^TD^TB^T = BDB^T\) so this matrix is symmetric.

    22.2.5.7.

    Answer.
    1. Use properties of the matrix transpose.
    2. Because they have the same characteristic polynomial.
    3. \(\displaystyle A^T = (P^T)^{-1} D P^T\)
    Solution.
    1. \((A-\lambda I)^T = A^T - \lambda I\) and therefore \(\det(A^T-\lambda I) = \det[(A-\lambda I)^T] = \det(A-\lambda I)\text{.}\)
    2. The eigenvalues of a matrix are given by the roots of its characteristic polynomial. Since \(A\) and \(A^T\) have the same characteristic polynomial, they have the same eigenvalues.
    3. \(\displaystyle A^T = (PDP^{-1})^T = (P^T)^{-1} D P^T\)

    22.2.5.8.

    Answer.
    1. \(\displaystyle \len{\vvec+\wvec}^2 = \vvec\cdot\vvec+\wvec\cdot\wvec\)
    2. Because \(\xvec\) and \(\yvec\) are orthogonal.
    Solution.
    1. \(\displaystyle \len{\vvec+\wvec}^2 = (\vvec+\wvec)\cdot(\vvec+\wvec) = \vvec\cdot\vvec+2\vvec\cdot\wvec+\wvec\cdot\wvec = \vvec\cdot\vvec+\wvec\cdot\wvec\)
    2. Because \(\xvec\) and \(\yvec\) are orthogonal.

    22.2.5.9.

    Answer.
    1. Use properties of the transpose.
    2. Compute the dot product of \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2\text{.}\)
    3. It follows that \((\lambda_1-\lambda_2)\vvec_1\cdot\vvec_2 = 0\)
    Solution.
    1. \(\xvec\cdot(A\yvec) = \xvec^TA\yvec = (A^T\xvec)^T\yvec = (A^T\xvec)\cdot\yvec\text{.}\)
    2. \(A^T = A\) and \(\vvec_1\cdot\vvec_2=0\text{.}\)
    3. \begin{align*} \vvec_1\cdot(A\vvec_2) \amp {}={} (A\vvec_1)\cdot\vvec_2\\ \lambda_2\vvec_1\cdot\vvec_2 \amp {}={} \lambda_1\vvec_1\cdot\vvec_2\\ (\lambda_1-\lambda_2)\vvec_1\cdot\vvec_2\amp{}={} 0 \end{align*}
      so \(\vvec_1\cdot\vvec_2=0\) since \(\lambda_1-\lambda_2\neq 0\text{.}\)

    22.2.5.10.

    Answer.
    1. \(\displaystyle p=15\)
    2. \(\displaystyle \row(A)^\perp = \ \nul(A)\)
    3. A basis for \(\row(A)\) are the three rows of \(A\text{.}\) A basis for \(\row(A)^\perp = \nul(A)\) is \(\fourvec{-2}100\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. Since \(A^T\) is \(15\times7\text{,}\) it follows that \(\row(A)=\col(A^T)\) is a subspace of \(\real^{15}\text{.}\)
    2. \(\displaystyle \row(A)^\perp = \col(A^T)^\perp = \nul((A^T)^T) = \nul(A)\)
    3. \(\rank(A) = 3\) so \(\rank(A^T)=\dim\col(A^T) = \dim\row(A) = 3\text{.}\) A basis for \(\row(A)\) are the three rows of \(A\text{.}\) \(\row(A)^\perp = \nul(A)\) is one-dimensional with basis \(\fourvec{-2}100\text{.}\)

    22.3 Orthogonal bases and projections
    22.3.1 Orthogonal sets

    Activity 22.3.2.

    Answer.
    1. We compute the dot products \(\wvec_1\cdot\wvec_2=0\text{,}\) \(\wvec_1\cdot\wvec_3=0\text{,}\) and \(\wvec_2\cdot\wvec_3=0\text{.}\)
    2. An orthogonal set of vectors is linearly independent.
    3. \(\bvec = -2\wvec_1 + 3\wvec_2 + \wvec_3\text{.}\)
    4. \(\displaystyle \uvec_1 = \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\wvec_1 = \threevec{1/\sqrt{3}}{-1/\sqrt{3}}{1/\sqrt{3}}\)
    5. We find that
      \begin{equation*} \uvec_2 = \threevec{1/\sqrt{2}}{1/\sqrt{2}}0,\hspace{24pt} \uvec_3 = \threevec{1/\sqrt{6}}{-1/\sqrt{6}}{-2/\sqrt{6}} \end{equation*}
    6. \(\displaystyle Q^TQ=I\)
    Solution.
    1. We compute the dot products \(\wvec_1\cdot\wvec_2=0\text{,}\) \(\wvec_1\cdot\wvec_3=0\text{,}\) and \(\wvec_2\cdot\wvec_3=0\text{.}\)
    2. We know that an orthogonal set of vectors is linearly independent. Therefore, we have a set of three linearly independent vectors in \(\real^3\) so they must form a basis for \(\real^3\text{.}\)
    3. We find that \(\bvec = -2\wvec_1 + 3\wvec_2 + \wvec_3\text{.}\)
    4. Since \(\len{\wvec_1} = \sqrt{3}\text{,}\) we find
      \begin{equation*} \uvec_1 = \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\wvec_1 = \threevec{1/\sqrt{3}}{-1/\sqrt{3}}{1/\sqrt{3}} \end{equation*}
    5. We find that
      \begin{equation*} \uvec_2 = \threevec{1/\sqrt{2}}{1/\sqrt{2}}0,\hspace{24pt} \uvec_3 = \threevec{1/\sqrt{6}}{-1/\sqrt{6}}{-2/\sqrt{6}} \end{equation*}
    6. We find \(Q^TQ=I\) since each entry in this matrix product is the dot product of two columns of \(Q\text{.}\)

    22.3.2 Orthogonal projections

    Activity 22.3.3.

    Answer.
      1. 0
      2. \(\bhat = \twovec{16/5}{8/5}\text{.}\)
      3. \(\displaystyle \bhat= \frac{\bvec\cdot\wvec}{\wvec\cdot\wvec}\wvec\)
      1. 0
      2. \(c_1= 2\)
        \(c_2=3\)
      3. \(\displaystyle \bhat = \threevec744\)
    3. We require that \(\bvec-\bhat\) be orthogonal to every vector \(\wvec_i\text{.}\)
    4. \(\displaystyle c_i=\frac{\bvec\cdot\uvec_i}{\uvec_i\cdot\uvec_i} = \bvec\cdot\uvec_i\)
    5. Use the fact that \(Q^T\bvec = \threevec{\bvec\cdot\uvec_1}{\vdots}{\bvec\cdot\uvec_n}\)
    Solution.
      1. This dot product should be 0 since the vectors are orthogonal.
      2. \(\bhat=\frac{b\cdot\wvec}{\wvec\cdot\wvec}\wvec = \twovec{16/5}{8/5}\text{.}\)
      3. As before, \(\bhat= \frac{\bvec\cdot\wvec}{\wvec\cdot\wvec}\wvec\)
      1. These dot products are 0.
      2. \(c_1=\frac{\bvec\cdot\wvec_1} {\wvec_1\cdot\wvec_1} = 2\)
        \(c_2=\frac{\bvec\cdot\wvec_2} {\wvec_2\cdot\wvec_2} = 3\)
      3. \(\displaystyle \bhat = \threevec744\)
    3. We know \(\bhat=c_1\wvec_1 + c_2\wvec_2 + \cdots + c_n\wvec_n\) and we can find \(c_i=\frac{\bvec\cdot\wvec_i}{\wvec_i\cdot\wvec_i}\) by requiring that \(\bvec-\bhat\) be orthogonal to every vector \(\wvec_i\text{.}\)
    4. The vectors \(\uvec_i\) form an orthogonal set and since \(\uvec_i\cdot\uvec_i = \len{\uvec_i}^2 = 1\text{,}\) the weights are \(c_i=\frac{\bvec\cdot\uvec_i}{\uvec_i\cdot\uvec_i} = \bvec\cdot\uvec_i\text{.}\)
    5. We have \(Q^T\bvec = \cthreevec{\bvec\cdot\uvec_1}{\vdots}{\bvec\cdot\uvec_n}\) so that
      \begin{equation*} QQ^T\bvec = (\bvec\cdot\uvec_1)~\uvec_1 + (\bvec\cdot\uvec_2)~\uvec_2 + \cdots + (\bvec\cdot\uvec_n)~\uvec_n=\bhat\text{.} \end{equation*}

    Activity 22.3.4.

    Answer.
      1. \(\displaystyle \uvec=\threevec{1/3}{2/3}{-2/3}\)
      2. \(\displaystyle QQ^T = \begin{bmatrix} 1/9 \amp 2/9 \amp -2/9 \\ 2/9 \amp 4/9 \amp -4/9 \\ -2/9 \amp -4/9 \amp 4/9 \end{bmatrix}\)
      3. \(\displaystyle \bhat=\threevec{1/9}{2/9}{-2/9}\)
      4. \(\displaystyle \rank(P)=1\)
      1. \(\displaystyle \bhat = \fourvec3235\)
      2. \(\displaystyle P = \begin{bmatrix} 1/4 \amp 1/4 \amp 1/4 \amp 1/4 \\ 1/4 \amp 5/12 \amp 5/12 \amp -1/12 \\ 1/4 \amp 5/12 \amp 5/12 \amp 1/12 \\ 1/4 \amp -1/12 \amp -1/12 \amp 11/12 \end{bmatrix}\)
      3. \(\displaystyle \rank(P)=2\)
      4. \(\vvec_1=\fourvec0{-1}10\) and \(\vvec_2=\fourvec{-3}{-2}01\)
      5. \(\displaystyle \bvec^\perp = \fourvec60{-4}{-2}\)
      6. \(\displaystyle Q^TQ = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \end{bmatrix}\)
    Solution.
      1. \(\displaystyle \uvec=\threevec{1/3}{2/3}{-2/3}\)
      2. \(\displaystyle QQ^T = \begin{bmatrix} 1/9 \amp 2/9 \amp -2/9 \\ 2/9 \amp 4/9 \amp -4/9 \\ -2/9 \amp -4/9 \amp 4/9 \end{bmatrix}\)
      3. \(\displaystyle \bhat=\threevec{1/9}{2/9}{-2/9}\)
      4. We find that \(\rank(P)\text{,}\) which makes sense because \(\col(P) = L\text{,}\) a 1-dimensional subspace of \(\real^3\text{.}\)
      1. \(\displaystyle \bhat = \fourvec3235\)
      2. \(\displaystyle P = \begin{bmatrix} 1/4 \amp 1/4 \amp 1/4 \amp 1/4 \\ 1/4 \amp 5/12 \amp 5/12 \amp -1/12 \\ 1/4 \amp 5/12 \amp 5/12 \amp 1/12 \\ 1/4 \amp -1/12 \amp -1/12 \amp 11/12 \end{bmatrix}\)
      3. \(\rank(P)=2\) since \(\col(P) = W\)
      4. Since \(W=\col(P)\text{,}\) then \(W^\perp = \nul(P)\text{,}\) which gives \(\vvec_1=\fourvec0{-1}10\) and \(\vvec_2=\fourvec{-3}{-2}01\)
      5. We can find \(\bvec^\perp = \bvec - \bhat = \fourvec60{-4}{-2}\)
      6. \(Q^TQ = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \end{bmatrix}\) since this product computes the dot products between the columns of \(Q\text{.}\)

    22.3.4 Exercises

    22.3.4.1.

    Answer.
    1. \(\wvec_1\cdot\wvec_2=0\text{.}\)
    2. \(\bhat = \threevec{1/2}1{1/2}\text{.}\)
    3. \(\uvec_1=\frac{1}{\len{\wvec_1}}\wvec_1 = \threevec{1/\sqrt{3}}{1/\sqrt{3}}{1/\sqrt{3}}\) and \(\uvec_2=\frac{1}{\len{\wvec_2}}\wvec_2 = \threevec{1/\sqrt{6}}{-2/\sqrt{6}}{1/\sqrt{6}}\)
    4. \(\displaystyle P=\begin{bmatrix} 1/2 \amp 0 \amp 1/2 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 1/2 \amp 0 \amp 1/2 \end{bmatrix}\)
    5. \(\displaystyle \rank(P) = 2\)
    Solution.
    1. Check that \(\wvec_1\cdot\wvec_2=0\text{.}\)
    2. Applying the Projection Formula gives \(\bhat = \threevec{1/2}1{1/2}\text{.}\)
    3. \(\uvec_1=\frac{1}{\len{\wvec_1}}\wvec_1 = \threevec{1/\sqrt{3}}{1/\sqrt{3}}{1/\sqrt{3}}\) and \(\uvec_2=\frac{1}{\len{\wvec_2}}\wvec_2 = \threevec{1/\sqrt{6}}{-2/\sqrt{6}}{1/\sqrt{6}}\)
    4. Form \(Q=\begin{bmatrix}\uvec_1 \amp \uvec_2 \end{bmatrix}\) so that \(P=QQ^T=\begin{bmatrix} 1/2 \amp 0 \amp 1/2 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 1/2 \amp 0 \amp 1/2 \end{bmatrix}\)
    5. Since \(\col(P)=W\text{,}\) we have \(\rank(P) = 2\)

    22.3.4.2.

    Answer.
    1. \(\wvec_1\cdot\wvec_1=0\text{,}\) \(\wvec_1\cdot\wvec_3=0\text{,}\) and \(\wvec_2\cdot\wvec_3=0\text{.}\)
    2. \(\displaystyle A^TA = \begin{bmatrix} 3 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 6 \end{bmatrix}\)
    3. \(\bvec=-2\wvec_1+3\wvec_2+2\wvec_3\text{.}\)
    4. \begin{equation*} \uvec_1=\threevec{1/\sqrt{3}}{1/\sqrt{3}} {1/\sqrt{3}},\hspace{24pt} \uvec_2=\threevec{-1/\sqrt{2}}0{1/\sqrt{2}}, \hspace{24pt} \uvec_3=\threevec{1/\sqrt{6}}{-2/\sqrt{6}} {1/\sqrt{6}},\hspace{24pt} \end{equation*}
    5. \(\displaystyle QQ^T=I\)
    Solution.
    1. Check that all three dot products \(\wvec_1\cdot\wvec_1=0\text{,}\) \(\wvec_1\cdot\wvec_3=0\text{,}\) and \(\wvec_2\cdot\wvec_3=0\text{.}\)
    2. \(A^TA = \begin{bmatrix} 3 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 6 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \wvec_1\cdot\wvec_1\amp \wvec_1\cdot\wvec_2\amp \wvec_1\cdot\wvec_3 \\ \wvec_2\cdot\wvec_1\amp \wvec_2\cdot\wvec_2\amp \wvec_2\cdot\wvec_3 \\ \wvec_3\cdot\wvec_1\amp \wvec_3\cdot\wvec_2\amp \wvec_3\cdot\wvec_3 \\ \end{bmatrix} \text{.}\) This matrix is diagonal because the vectors form an orthogonal set.
    3. We may find the weights of this linear combination by finding \(c_i=\frac{b\cdot\wvec_i}{\wvec_i\cdot\wvec_i}\) so that \(\bvec=-2\wvec_1+3\wvec_2+2\wvec_3\text{.}\)
    4. \begin{equation*} \uvec_1=\threevec{1/\sqrt{3}}{1/\sqrt{3}} {1/\sqrt{3}},\hspace{24pt} \uvec_2=\threevec{-1/\sqrt{2}}0{1/\sqrt{2}}, \hspace{24pt} \uvec_3=\threevec{1/\sqrt{6}}{-2/\sqrt{6}} {1/\sqrt{6}},\hspace{24pt} \end{equation*}
    5. The columns of \(Q\) form an orthonormal basis for \(\real^3\) so \(Q\) is orthogonal. Therefore, \(QQ^T=I\text{.}\)

    22.3.4.3.

    Answer.
    1. \(\displaystyle \bhat = \fourvec{-1}{-2}13\)
    2. \(\displaystyle \bvec^\perp = \fourvec{3}{1}{-7}4\)
    3. A basis for \(W^\perp\) is \(\vvec_1=\fourvec{-1}110\) and \(\vvec_2=\fourvec{-1}201\text{.}\) We then have \(\bvec^\perp = -7\vvec_1 + 4\vvec_2\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. Apply the Projection Formula to find \(\bhat = \fourvec{-1}{-2}13\text{.}\)
    2. \(\bvec^\perp = \fourvec{3}{1}{-7}4\text{.}\)
    3. Constructing a matrix \(A\) whose columns are \(\wvec_1\) and \(\wvec_2\) allows us to find a basis for \(W^\perp=\nul(A^T)\text{.}\) This gives the basis \(\vvec_1=\fourvec{-1}110\) and \(\vvec_2=\fourvec{-1}201\text{.}\) We then have \(\bvec^\perp = -7\vvec_1 + 4\vvec_2\text{.}\)

    22.3.4.4.

    Answer.
    1. \(\displaystyle \bhat_1 = \fourvec{-1}{-1}00\)
    2. \(\displaystyle \bhat_2 = \fourvec{-1}{-1}22\)
    3. \(\displaystyle \bhat_2\)
    Solution.
    1. Applying the Projection Formula gives \(\bhat_1 = \fourvec{-1}{-1}00\)
    2. Applying the Projection Formula gives \(\bhat_2 = \fourvec{-1}{-1}22\)
    3. \(\bhat_2\) is the closest vector in \(W\) to \(\bvec\text{.}\) Since \(L\) is contained in \(W\text{,}\) \(\bhat_1\) cannot be closer. Therefore, \(\bhat_2\) must be closer to \(\bvec\) than \(\bhat_1\text{.}\)

    22.3.4.5.

    Answer.
    1. \begin{equation*} \threevec{4/9}{-2/9}{4/9},\hspace{24pt} \threevec{-2/9}{1/9}{4/9},\hspace{24pt} \threevec{4/9}{-2/9}{4/9} \end{equation*}
    2. \(\displaystyle P=\begin{bmatrix} 4/9 \amp -2/9 \amp 4/9\\ -2/9 \amp 1/9 \amp -2/9\\ 4/9 \amp -2/9 \amp 4/9\\ \end{bmatrix}\)
    3. The columns of \(P\) are the results of projecting the standard basis vectors onto \(L\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. Applying the Projection Formula gives the projections
      \begin{equation*} \threevec{4/9}{-2/9}{4/9},\hspace{24pt} \threevec{-2/9}{1/9}{4/9},\hspace{24pt} \threevec{4/9}{-2/9}{4/9} \end{equation*}
    2. \(\displaystyle P=\begin{bmatrix} 4/9 \amp -2/9 \amp 4/9\\ -2/9 \amp 1/9 \amp -2/9\\ 4/9 \amp -2/9 \amp 4/9\\ \end{bmatrix}\)
    3. If \(\uvec = \frac{1}{\len{\wvec}}\wvec\text{,}\) then \(P=\uvec\uvec^T\text{,}\) which projects vectors orthogonally onto \(L\text{.}\) The columns of \(P\) are the results of projecting the standard basis vectors onto \(L\text{.}\)

    22.3.4.6.

    Answer.
    1. \(\displaystyle \threevec{-3}21\)
    2. \(\displaystyle \yvec = \threevec6{-4}{-2}\)
    3. \(\zvec = \threevec0{-2}4 = 2\vvec_1-\vvec_2\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. A basis vector is \(\threevec{-3}21\)
    2. \(\displaystyle \yvec = \threevec6{-4}{-2}\)
    3. \(\yvec\) is the orthogonal projection of \(\bvec\) onto \(W^\perp\) so \(\zvec=\bvec-\yvec\) must be orthogonal to \(W^\perp\text{,}\) which means that it is in \(W\text{.}\) We see that \(\zvec = \threevec0{-2}4 = 2\vvec_1-\vvec_2\text{.}\)

    22.3.4.7.

    Answer.
    1. True
    2. True
    3. False
    4. True
    5. True
    Solution.
    1. True, because \(\wvec\) is the closest vector in \(W\) to \(\wvec\text{.}\) Therefore, \(\widehat{\wvec} = QQ^T\wvec = \wvec\text{.}\)
    2. True, because the orthogonal set of vectors is linearly independent.
    3. False, \(QQ^T\) projects vectors orthogonally onto the 5-dimensional subspace \(\col(A)\text{.}\)
    4. True, because \(Q^TQ\) computes the dot products between the columns of \(Q\)
    5. True, because \(\bvec=\bhat+\bvec^\perp = \bvec^\perp\text{.}\) Therefore, \(\bvec\) is in \(W^\perp\text{.}\)

    22.3.4.8.

    Answer.
    1. \(Q\xvec\cdot(Q\yvec) = (Q\xvec)^T\cdot(Q\yvec) = \xvec^TQ^TQ\yvec = \xvec^T\yvec=\xvec\cdot\yvec\text{.}\)
    2. \(\displaystyle \len{Q\xvec}^2 = (Q\xvec)\cdot(Q\xvec) = \xvec\cdot\xvec = \len{\xvec}^2\)
    3. If \(Q\vvec = \lambda\vvec\text{,}\) then \(\len{Q\vvec} = |\lambda|\len{\vvec}=\len{\vvec}\) so \(|\lambda|=1\)
    Solution.
    1. \(Q\xvec\cdot(Q\yvec) = (Q\xvec)^T\cdot(Q\yvec) = \xvec^TQ^TQ\yvec = \xvec^T\yvec=\xvec\cdot\yvec\text{.}\)
    2. \(\displaystyle \len{Q\xvec}^2 = (Q\xvec)\cdot(Q\xvec) = \xvec\cdot\xvec = \len{\xvec}^2\)
    3. If \(Q\vvec = \lambda\vvec\text{,}\) then \(\len{Q\vvec} = |\lambda|\len{\vvec}=\len{\vvec}\) so \(|\lambda|=1\)

    22.3.4.9.

    Answer.
    1. Since \(Q^TQ=I\text{,}\) we have \(\det(Q^TQ)=\det(I)=1\text{.}\)
    2. The four columns of \(Q\) form a basis for the column space \(\col(QQ^T)\)
    3. If \(\bvec^\perp=\bvec-\bhat\text{,}\) then \(\bvec-\bperp = \bhat\) is in \(W\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. Since \(Q^TQ=I\text{,}\) we have \(\det(Q^TQ)=\det(Q^T)\det(Q)=(\det(Q))^2 = \det(I) = 1\)
    2. The columns of \(Q\) form an orthonormal basis for \(W\text{,}\) a 4-dimensional subspace of \(\real^8\text{.}\) Therefore, \(QQ^T\) projects vectors orthogonally onto \(W\) so \(\col(QQ^T)=W\) and \(\rank(QQ^T)=4\text{.}\)
    3. If \(\bvec^\perp=\bvec-\bhat\text{,}\) then \(\bvec-\bperp = \bhat\) is in \(W\text{,}\) the orthogonal complement of \(W^\perp\text{.}\) This means that \(\bperp\) is the orthogonal projection of \(\bvec\) onto \(W^\perp\text{.}\)

    22.3.4.10.

    Answer.
    1. \(Q^TQ=I\text{.}\)
    2. \(Q^TQ=I\text{.}\)
    3. \(\uvec_2=\twovec{-\sin\theta}{\cos\theta}\) or \(\twovec{\sin\theta}{-\cos\theta}\)
    4. The first column of \(Q\) has the form \(\uvec_1=\twovec{\cos\theta}{\sin\theta}\text{.}\) Now apply the result of the last part of this problem.
    Solution.
    1. If this matrix is \(Q\text{,}\) we have \(Q^TQ=I\text{.}\)
    2. If this matrix is \(Q\text{,}\) we have \(Q^TQ=I\text{.}\)
    3. \(\uvec_2=\twovec{-\sin\theta}{\cos\theta}\) or \(\twovec{\sin\theta}{-\cos\theta}\)
    4. If \(Q=\begin{bmatrix}\uvec_1\amp\uvec_2\end{bmatrix}\) is an orthogonal \(2\times2\) matrix, then \(\uvec_1\) is a unit vector and has the form \(\uvec_1=\twovec{\cos\theta}{\sin\theta}\) for some angle \(\theta\text{.}\) By the last part of this problem, there are only two choices for \(\uvec_2\text{,}\) one of which gives a rotation and one of which gives a reflection.

    22.4 Finding orthogonal bases
    22.4.1 Gram-Schmidt orthogonalization

    Activity 22.4.2.

    Answer.
    1. \(\widehat{\vvec}_2 = \fourvec2222\text{.}\)
    2. \(\displaystyle \wvec_2 = \fourvec{-1}100\)
    3. We have \(\vvec_1 = \wvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2 = \wvec_2 + 2\wvec_1\) so a linear combination of \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_1\) can be rewritten as a linear combination of \(\wvec_1\) and \(\wvec_2\text{.}\)
    4. \(\widehat{\vvec}_3 = \fourvec0{-4}{-2}{-2}\text{.}\)
    5. \(\displaystyle \wvec_3 = \fourvec11{-1}{-1}\)
    6. Since \(\vvec_i\) can be written in terms of \(\wvec_j\) and vice-versa, these new vectors form a basis for \(W\text{.}\)
    7. \begin{equation*} \uvec_1=\fourvec{1/2}{1/2}{1/2}{1/2},\hspace{24pt} \uvec_2=\fourvec{-1/\sqrt{2}}{1/\sqrt{2}}00,\hspace{24pt} \uvec_3=\fourvec{1/2}{1/2}{-1/2}{-1/2} \end{equation*}
    Solution.
    1. \(\widehat{\vvec}_2 = \frac{\vvec_2\cdot\wvec_1} {\wvec_1\cdot\wvec_1}\wvec_1=\fourvec2222\text{.}\)
    2. \(\displaystyle \wvec_2 = \fourvec{-1}100\)
    3. We have \(\vvec_1 = \wvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2 = \wvec_2 + 2\wvec_1\text{.}\) Therefore, a linear combination of \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_1\) can be rewritten as
      \begin{equation*} c_1\vvec_1+c_2\vvec_2 = c_1\wvec_1+c_2(\wvec_2+2\wvec_1) = (c_1+2c_2)\wvec_1 + c_2\wvec_2\text{.} \end{equation*}
      In the same way, \(\wvec_1=\vvec_1\) and \(\wvec_2 = \vvec_2-2\vvec_1\) so any linear combination of \(\wvec_1\) and \(\wvec_2\) can be rewritten as a linear combination of \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_1\text{.}\)
    4. By the Projection Formula, \(\widehat{\vvec}_3 = \fourvec0{-4}{-2}{-2}\text{.}\)
    5. \(\displaystyle \wvec_3 = \fourvec11{-1}{-1}\)
    6. We can check that \(\wvec_1\text{,}\) \(\wvec_2\text{,}\) and \(\wvec_3\) form an orthogonal set. Since \(\vvec_i\) can be written in terms of \(\wvec_j\) and vice-versa, these new vectors form a basis for \(W\text{.}\)
    7. \begin{equation*} \uvec_1=\fourvec{1/2}{1/2}{1/2}{1/2},\hspace{24pt} \uvec_2=\fourvec{-1/\sqrt{2}}{1/\sqrt{2}}00,\hspace{24pt} \uvec_3=\fourvec{1/2}{1/2}{-1/2}{-1/2} \end{equation*}

    Activity 22.4.3.

    Answer.
    1. \begin{equation*} \wvec_1=\fivevec{14}{-6}82{-6},\hspace{24pt} \wvec_2=\fivevec{-2}{0}02{-4},\hspace{24pt} \wvec_3=\fivevec130{-1}{-1} \end{equation*}
    2. \(\displaystyle \bhat=\fivevec{-4}9{-4}{-4}3\)
    3. \(\bhat=-\frac34\vvec_1+\frac12\vvec_2+2\vvec_3\text{.}\)
    4. \begin{equation*} \uvec_1=\fivevec{14/\sqrt{336}}{-6\sqrt{336}}{8/\sqrt{336}} {2/\sqrt{336}}{-6/\sqrt{336}},\hspace{24pt} \uvec_2=\fivevec{-2/\sqrt{24}}{0}0{2/\sqrt{24}} {-4/\sqrt{24}},\hspace{24pt} \uvec_3=\fivevec{1/\sqrt{12}}{3/\sqrt{12}}0 {-1/\sqrt{12}}{-1/\sqrt{12}} \end{equation*}
    5. \(\displaystyle Q^TQ=I\)
    6. \(\displaystyle P = QQ^T = \begin{bmatrix} 5/6 \amp 0 \amp 1/3 \amp -1/6 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 6/7 \amp -1/7 \amp -2/7 \amp -1/7 \\ 1/3 \amp -1/7 \amp 4/21 \amp 1/21 \amp -1/7 \\ -1/6 \amp -2/7 \amp 1/21 \amp 11/42 \amp -2/7 \\ 0 \amp -1/7 \amp -1/7 \amp -2/7 \amp 6/7 \end{bmatrix}\)
    Solution.
    1. \begin{equation*} \wvec_1=\fivevec{14}{-6}82{-6},\hspace{24pt} \wvec_2=\fivevec{-2}{0}02{-4},\hspace{24pt} \wvec_3=\fivevec130{-1}{-1} \end{equation*}
    2. \(\displaystyle \bhat=\fivevec{-4}9{-4}{-4}3\)
    3. We know that \(\bhat\) is in \(W\) and \(\vvec_1\text{,}\) \(\vvec_2\text{,}\) and \(\vvec_3\) is a basis for \(W\text{.}\) We find \(\bhat=-\frac34\vvec_1+\frac12\vvec_2+2\vvec_3\text{.}\)
    4. \begin{equation*} \uvec_1=\fivevec{14/\sqrt{336}}{-6\sqrt{336}}{8/\sqrt{336}} {2/\sqrt{336}}{-6/\sqrt{336}},\hspace{24pt} \uvec_2=\fivevec{-2/\sqrt{24}}{0}0{2/\sqrt{24}}{-4/\sqrt{24}},\hspace{24pt} \uvec_3=\fivevec{1/\sqrt{12}}{3/\sqrt{12}}0{-1/\sqrt{12}}{-1/\sqrt{12}} \end{equation*}
    5. \(Q^TQ=I\) since the matrix product computes the dot products of the columns of \(Q\text{.}\)
    6. \(\displaystyle P = QQ^T = \begin{bmatrix} 5/6 \amp 0 \amp 1/3 \amp -1/6 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 6/7 \amp -1/7 \amp -2/7 \amp -1/7 \\ 1/3 \amp -1/7 \amp 4/21 \amp 1/21 \amp -1/7 \\ -1/6 \amp -2/7 \amp 1/21 \amp 11/42 \amp -2/7 \\ 0 \amp -1/7 \amp -1/7 \amp -2/7 \amp 6/7 \end{bmatrix}\)

    22.4.2 \(QR\) factorizations

    Activity 22.4.4.

    Answer.
    1. \begin{equation*} \begin{aligned} \vvec_1 \amp = \wvec_1 \\ \vvec_2 \amp = 2\wvec_1 + \wvec_2 \\ \vvec_3 \amp = -2\wvec_1 - 2\wvec_2 + \wvec_3 \\ \end{aligned} \end{equation*}
    2. \begin{equation*} \begin{aligned} \vvec_1 \amp = 2\uvec_1 \\ \vvec_2 \amp = 4\uvec_1 + \sqrt{2}\uvec_2 \\ \vvec_3 \amp = -4\uvec_1 - 2\sqrt{2}\uvec_2 + 2\uvec_3 \\ \end{aligned} \end{equation*}
    3. \(\vvec_1 = Q\threevec{2}00\text{.}\)
    4. \(\vvec_2 = Q\threevec4{\sqrt{2}}0\) and \(\vvec_3=Q\threevec{-4}{-2\sqrt{2}}2\text{.}\)
    5. We have \(QR = \begin{bmatrix} Q\rvec_1 \amp Q\rvec_2 \amp Q\rvec_3 \end{bmatrix} = A\text{.}\)
    6. \(R\) is upper triangular.
    7. \(Q\) will be \(10\times6\) and \(R\) will be \(6\times 6\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. \begin{equation*} \begin{aligned} \wvec_1 \amp = \vvec_1 \\ \wvec_2 \amp = \vvec_2 - 2\wvec_1 \\ \wvec_3 \amp = \vvec_3 + 2\wvec_1 + 2\wvec_2 \\ \end{aligned} \end{equation*}
      Therefore,
      \begin{equation*} \begin{aligned} \vvec_1 \amp = \wvec_1 \\ \vvec_2 \amp = 2\wvec_1 + \wvec_2 \\ \vvec_3 \amp = -2\wvec_1 - 2\wvec_2 + \wvec_3 \\ \end{aligned} \end{equation*}
    2. \(\wvec_i = \len{\wvec_i}\uvec_i\) so we have
      \begin{equation*} \wvec_1 = 2\uvec_1,\hspace{24pt} \wvec_1 = \sqrt{2}\uvec_2,\hspace{24pt} \wvec_1 = 2\uvec_3\text{.} \end{equation*}
      This leads to
      \begin{equation*} \begin{aligned} \vvec_1 \amp = 2\uvec_1 \\ \vvec_2 \amp = 4\uvec_1 + \sqrt{2}\uvec_2 \\ \vvec_3 \amp = -4\uvec_1 - 2\sqrt{2}\uvec_2 + 2\uvec_3 \\ \end{aligned} \end{equation*}
    3. Since \(\vvec_1 = 2\uvec_1\text{,}\) we have \(\vvec_1 = Q\threevec{2}00\text{.}\)
    4. In the same way, we have \(\vvec_2 = Q\threevec4{\sqrt{2}}0\) and \(\vvec_3=Q\threevec{-4}{-2\sqrt{2}}2\text{.}\)
    5. We have \(QR = \begin{bmatrix} Q\rvec_1 \amp Q\rvec_2 \amp Q\rvec_3 \end{bmatrix} = A\text{.}\)
    6. \(R=\begin{bmatrix} 2 \amp 4 \amp -4 \\ 0 \amp \sqrt{2} \amp -2\sqrt{2} \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ \end{bmatrix}\) so \(R\) is upper triangular.
    7. \(Q\) will be \(10\times6\) and \(R\) will be a \(6\times 6\) upper triangular matrix.

    Activity 22.4.5.

    Answer.
    1. \(Q\) is \(4\times3\) and \(R\) is a \(3\times3\) upper triangular matrix.
    2. We see that
      \begin{equation*} Q=\begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{3} \amp -1/\sqrt{10} \amp -3/\sqrt{23} \\ 0 \amp 2/\sqrt{10} \amp -3/\sqrt{23} \\ 1/\sqrt{3} \amp -1/\sqrt{10} \amp 1/\sqrt{23} \\ 1/\sqrt{3} \amp 2/\sqrt{10} \amp 2/\sqrt{23} \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} R = \begin{bmatrix} \sqrt{3} \amp \sqrt{3} \amp \sqrt{3} \\ 0 \amp \sqrt{10} \amp \sqrt{10} \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp \sqrt{23} \end{bmatrix} \end{equation*}
    3. \(\displaystyle P=QQ^T = \begin{bmatrix} 569/690 \amp 22/115 \amp 209/690 \amp -44/345 \\ 22/115 \amp 91/115 \amp -38/115 \amp 16/115 \\ 209/690 \amp -38/115 \amp 329/690 \amp 76/345 \\ -44/345 \amp 16/115 \amp 76/345 \amp 313/345 \\ \end{bmatrix}\)
    4. \(\displaystyle \bhat = \fourvec{-7}{-5}5{14}\)
    5. \(\xvec = \threevec2{-1}3\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. \(Q\) is \(4\times3\) and \(R\) is a \(3\times3\) upper triangular matrix.
    2. We see that
      \begin{equation*} Q=\begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{3} \amp -1/\sqrt{10} \amp -3/\sqrt{23} \\ 0 \amp 2/\sqrt{10} \amp -3/\sqrt{23} \\ 1/\sqrt{3} \amp -1/\sqrt{10} \amp 1/\sqrt{23} \\ 1/\sqrt{3} \amp 2/\sqrt{10} \amp 2/\sqrt{23} \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} R = \begin{bmatrix} \sqrt{3} \amp \sqrt{3} \amp \sqrt{3} \\ 0 \amp \sqrt{10} \amp \sqrt{10} \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp \sqrt{23} \end{bmatrix} \end{equation*}
    3. \(\displaystyle P=QQ^T = \begin{bmatrix} 569/690 \amp 22/115 \amp 209/690 \amp -44/345 \\ 22/115 \amp 91/115 \amp -38/115 \amp 16/115 \\ 209/690 \amp -38/115 \amp 329/690 \amp 76/345 \\ -44/345 \amp 16/115 \amp 76/345 \amp 313/345 \\ \end{bmatrix}\)
    4. \(\displaystyle \bhat = QQ^T\bvec = \fourvec{-7}{-5}5{14}\)
    5. Since \(\bhat\) is in \(\col(A)\text{,}\) the system \(A\xvec=\bhat\) must be consistent. We find a solution by augmenting \(A\) by \(\bhat\) and row reducing: \(\xvec = \threevec2{-1}3\text{.}\)

    22.4.4 Exercises

    22.4.4.1.

    Answer.
    1. \(\wvec_1=\threevec111\) and \(\wvec_2 = \threevec2{-1}{-1}\)
    2. \(\uvec_1=\threevec{1/\sqrt{3}}{1/\sqrt{3}}{1/\sqrt{3}}\) and \(\uvec_2 = \threevec{2/\sqrt{6}}{-1/\sqrt{6}}{-1/\sqrt{6}}\)
    3. \(\displaystyle P = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1/2 \amp 1/2 \\ 0 \amp 1/2 \amp 1/2 \\ \end{bmatrix}\)
    4. \(\displaystyle \threevec311\)
    Solution.
    1. \(\wvec_1=\threevec111\) and \(\wvec_2 = \threevec2{-1}{-1}\)
    2. \(\uvec_1=\threevec{1/\sqrt{3}}{1/\sqrt{3}}{1/\sqrt{3}}\) and \(\uvec_2 = \threevec{2/\sqrt{6}}{-1/\sqrt{6}}{-1/\sqrt{6}}\)
    3. \(\displaystyle P = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1/2 \amp 1/2 \\ 0 \amp 1/2 \amp 1/2 \\ \end{bmatrix}\)
    4. \(\displaystyle \threevec311\)

    22.4.4.2.

    Answer.
    \(Q=\begin{bmatrix} 2/3 \amp 1/\sqrt{5} \\ -1/3 \amp 2/\sqrt{5} \\ 2/3 \amp 0 \end{bmatrix}\) and \(R = \begin{bmatrix} 6 \amp 6 \\ 0 \amp 3\sqrt{5} \end{bmatrix}\)
    Solution.
    Applying Gram-Schmidt, we have \(\wvec_1=\threevec4{-2}4\) and \(\wvec_2=\threevec360\text{,}\) which leads to \(\uvec_1=\threevec{2/3}{-1/3}{2/3}\) and \(\uvec_2=\threevec{1/\sqrt{5}}{2/\sqrt{5}}0\text{.}\) It therefore follows that \(\vvec_1 = 6\uvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2 = 6\uvec_1 + 3\sqrt{5}\uvec_2\text{.}\)
    This leads to \(A=QR\) where \(Q=\begin{bmatrix} 2/3 \amp 1/\sqrt{5} \\ -1/3 \amp 2/\sqrt{5} \\ 2/3 \amp 0 \end{bmatrix}\) and \(R = \begin{bmatrix} 6 \amp 6 \\ 0 \amp 3\sqrt{5} \end{bmatrix} \text{.}\)

    22.4.4.3.

    Answer.
    1. \begin{equation*} \uvec_1=\threevec{1/\sqrt{3}}{-1/\sqrt{3}}{1/\sqrt{3}}, \hspace{24pt} \uvec_2=\threevec{-1/\sqrt{2}}{-1/\sqrt{2}}{0}, \hspace{24pt} \uvec_3=\threevec{1/\sqrt{6}}{-1/\sqrt{6}}{-2/\sqrt{6}}, \end{equation*}
    2. \begin{equation*} Q = \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{3} \amp -1/\sqrt{2} \amp 1/\sqrt{6} \\ -1/\sqrt{3} \amp -1/\sqrt{2} \amp -1/\sqrt{6} \\ 1/\sqrt{3} \amp 0 \amp -2/\sqrt{6} \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} R = \begin{bmatrix} 2\sqrt{3} \amp \sqrt{3} \amp -\sqrt{3} \\ 0 \amp 2\sqrt{2} \amp -\sqrt{2} \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 2\sqrt{6} \end{bmatrix} \end{equation*}
      1. \(\yvec = Q^T\bvec\text{.}\)
      2. \(R\) is upper triangular
      3. \(\displaystyle \xvec = \threevec{-2}1{-2}\)
    Solution.
    1. We find that
      \begin{equation*} \uvec_1=\threevec{1/\sqrt{3}}{-1/\sqrt{3}}{1/\sqrt{3}}, \hspace{24pt} \uvec_2=\threevec{-1/\sqrt{2}}{-1/\sqrt{2}}{0}, \hspace{24pt} \uvec_3=\threevec{1/\sqrt{6}}{-1/\sqrt{6}}{-2/\sqrt{6}}, \end{equation*}
    2. \begin{equation*} Q = \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{3} \amp -1/\sqrt{2} \amp 1/\sqrt{6} \\ -1/\sqrt{3} \amp -1/\sqrt{2} \amp -1/\sqrt{6} \\ 1/\sqrt{3} \amp 0 \amp -2/\sqrt{6} \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} R = \begin{bmatrix} 2\sqrt{3} \amp \sqrt{3} \amp -\sqrt{3} \\ 0 \amp 2\sqrt{2} \amp -\sqrt{2} \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 2\sqrt{6} \end{bmatrix} \end{equation*}
      1. Since \(Q^TQ = I\text{,}\) we have \(\yvec = Q^T\bvec\text{.}\)
      2. \(R\) is upper triangular so this equation can be solved using back substitution.
      3. \(\displaystyle \xvec = \threevec{-2}1{-2}\)

    22.4.4.4.

    Answer.
    1. \begin{equation*} \wvec_1 =\fivevec1{-1}{-1}11,\hspace{24pt} \wvec_2 =\fivevec303{-3}3,\hspace{24pt} \wvec_3 =\fivevec2022{-2},\hspace{24pt} \end{equation*}
    2. \begin{equation*} \begin{bmatrix} 7/10 \amp -1/5 \amp 3/10 \amp 1/5 \amp 1/5 \\ -1/5 \amp 1/5 \amp 1/5 \amp -1/5\amp -1/5 \\ 3/10 \amp 1/5 \amp 7/10 \amp -1/5 \amp -1/5 \\ 1/5 \amp -1/5 \amp -1/5 \amp 7/10 \amp -3/10 \\ 1/5 \amp -1/5 \amp -1/5 \amp -3/10 \amp 7/10 \\ \end{bmatrix} \end{equation*}
    3. \(\displaystyle \bhat = \fivevec{-9}{-1}{-11}{7}{-5}\)
    4. \(\displaystyle \bhat = \vvec_1 - \frac83\vvec_2 -\vvec_3\)
    Solution.
    1. Applying Gram-Schmidt gives us
      \begin{equation*} \wvec_1 =\fivevec1{-1}{-1}11,\hspace{24pt} \wvec_2 =\fivevec303{-3}3,\hspace{24pt} \wvec_3 =\fivevec2022{-2},\hspace{24pt} \end{equation*}
    2. Let \(Q\) be the matrix whose columns are the orthonormal basis that results from Gram-Schmidt. Then
      \begin{equation*} QQ^T = \begin{bmatrix} 7/10 \amp -1/5 \amp 3/10 \amp 1/5 \amp 1/5 \\ -1/5 \amp 1/5 \amp 1/5 \amp -1/5\amp -1/5 \\ 3/10 \amp 1/5 \amp 7/10 \amp -1/5 \amp -1/5 \\ 1/5 \amp -1/5 \amp -1/5 \amp 7/10 \amp -3/10 \\ 1/5 \amp -1/5 \amp -1/5 \amp -3/10 \amp 7/10 \\ \end{bmatrix} \end{equation*}
    3. \(\displaystyle \bhat = QQ^T\bvec = \fivevec{-9}{-1}{-11}{7}{-5}\)
    4. \(\displaystyle \bhat = \vvec_1 - \frac83\vvec_2 -\vvec_3\)

    22.4.4.5.

    Answer.
    1. We find \(\wvec=\zerovec\text{.}\)
    2. This set of vectors is linearly dependent.
    Solution.
    1. We find
      \begin{equation*} \wvec_1 = \threevec211,\hspace{24pt} \wvec_2 = \threevec{-1}11,\hspace{24pt} \wvec_3 = \threevec000 \end{equation*}
      Since \(\wvec_3=\zerovec\text{,}\) this does not produce a basis for \(\real^3\text{.}\)
    2. The vector \(\vvec_3=2\vvec_1-\vvec_2\) so this set of vectors is linearly dependent. Since \(\vvec_3\) is in the span of \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2\text{,}\) projecting \(\vvec_3\) into that subspace gives \(\widehat{\vvec}_3 = \vvec_3\) so that \(\wvec_3 = \vvec_3 - \widehat{\vvec}_3 = \zerovec\text{.}\)

    22.4.4.6.

    Answer.
    1. True
    2. True
    3. False
    4. True
    5. True
    Solution.
    1. True. Since \(Q^TQ=I\text{,}\) we have \(Q^TA = Q^TQR = R\text{.}\)
    2. True. Since \(R\) is upper triangular and the diagonal entries of \(R\) are the lengths of the nonzero vectors \(\wvec_j\text{,}\) we have \(\det(R)\neq 0\text{,}\) which means that \(R\) is invertible.
    3. False, because \(Q^TQ=I\text{.}\)
    4. True. In fact, they are an orthonormal basis for \(\col(A)\text{.}\)
    5. True. If \(Q^T\xvec = \zerovec\text{,}\) then \(\uvec_i\cdot\xvec=0\) for every vector in an orthonormal basis of \(\col(A)\text{.}\) Therefore, \(\xvec\) is orthogonal to \(\col(A)\text{.}\)

    22.4.4.7.

    Answer.
    1. \(\displaystyle 7\times7\)
    2. \(\displaystyle 4\times4\)
    3. \(\displaystyle 4\times4\)
    4. They form an orthogonal set.
    Solution.
    1. \(QQ^T\) is \(7\times7\) and projects vectors orthogonally onto \(\col(A)\text{.}\)
    2. \(Q^TQ\) is the \(4\times4\) identity matrix because the product computes dot products between the columns of \(Q\text{.}\)
    3. \(R\) is a \(4\times4\) upper triangular matrix.
    4. The columns of \(A\) form an orthogonal set.

    22.4.4.8.

    Answer.
    1. \(\displaystyle \avec_i\cdot\avec_j\)
    2. \(\displaystyle \rvec_i\cdot\rvec_j\)
    3. \(\displaystyle A^TA = (QR)^T(QR) = R^TR\)
    4. This follows from the previous parts of this exercise.
    Solution.
    1. The entries of \(A^TA\) are the dot products \(\avec_i\cdot\avec_j\text{.}\)
    2. The entries of \(R^TR\) are the dot products \(\rvec_i\cdot\rvec_j\text{.}\)
    3. \(\displaystyle A^TA = (QR)^T(QR) = R^TQ^TQR = R^TIR = R^TR\)
    4. This follows from the previous parts of this exercise.

    22.5 Orthogonal least squares
    22.5.1 A first example

    Activity 22.5.2.

    Answer.
    1. Its not possible to draw a line through all three points.
    2. We have the equations
      \begin{align*} b + m \amp {}={} 1\\ b + 2m \amp {}={} 1\\ b + 3m \amp {}={} 3 \end{align*}
    3. We have \(A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 2 \\ 1 \amp 3 \\ \end{bmatrix}\) and \(\bvec=\threevec113\text{.}\)
    4. This linear system is inconsistent.
    5. \(\bhat=\threevec{2/3}{5/3}{8/3}\text{.}\)
    6. \(\xvec=\twovec{-1/3}1\text{.}\) This line is shown in Figure22.5.4.
    Solution.
    1. After plotting the points, we see that its not possible to draw a line through all three points.
    2. We have the equations
      \begin{align*} b + m \amp {}={} 1\\ b + 2m \amp {}={} 1\\ b + 3m \amp {}={} 3 \end{align*}
    3. We have \(A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 2 \\ 1 \amp 3 \\ \end{bmatrix}\) and \(\bvec=\threevec113\text{.}\)
    4. Finding the reduced row echelon form of the associated augmented matrix tells us this is an inconsistent system. Since a solution would describe a line passing through the three points, we should expect this.
    5. Applying Gram-Schmidt gives us the orthogonal basis \(\wvec_1=\threevec111\) and \(\wvec_2 = \threevec{-1}01\text{.}\) Projecting \(\bvec\) onto \(\col(A)\) gives \(\bhat=\threevec{2/3}{5/3}{8/3}\text{.}\)
    6. Solving the equation \(A\xvec = \bhat\) gives \(\xvec=\ctwovec{-1/3}1\text{,}\) which describes a line having vertical intercept \(b=-1/3\) and the slope \(=1\text{.}\) This line is shown in Figure22.5.3.

    22.5.2 Solving least-squares problems

    Activity 22.5.3.

    Answer.
    1. \(\beta_0 + 20.0\beta_1 = 88.6\text{.}\)
    2. \(A\) is the \(15\times2\) matrix whose first column consists only of 1s and whose second column is the vector of chirp rates. The vector \(\bvec\) is the vector of temperatures.
    3. \(A^TA=\begin{bmatrix} 15.0 \amp 248.5 \\ 248.5 \amp 4157.9 \\ \end{bmatrix}\) and \(A^T\bvec = \twovec{1190.2}{19857.7}\)
    4. \(\xhat = \twovec{\beta_0}{\beta_1} = \twovec{22.8}{3.4}\text{.}\)
    5. \(97.9\) degrees.
    Solution.
    1. We have the equation \(\beta_0 + 20.0\beta_1 = 88.6\text{.}\)
    2. \(A\) is the \(15\times2\) matrix whose first column consists only of 1s and whose second column is the vector of chirp rates. The vector \(\bvec\) is the vector of temperatures.
    3. \(A^TA=\begin{bmatrix} 15.0 \amp 248.5 \\ 248.5 \amp 4157.9 \\ \end{bmatrix}\) and \(A^T\bvec = \twovec{1190.2}{19857.7}\)
    4. \(\xhat = \twovec{\beta_0}{\beta_1} = \twovec{22.8}{3.4}\text{.}\)
    5. The predicted temperature is \(\beta_0 + 22\beta_1 = 97.9\) degrees.

    22.5.3 Using \(QR\) factorizations

    Activity 22.5.4.

    Answer.
    1. Use the fact that \(\bhat=QQ^T\bvec\text{.}\)
    2. Use the fact that \(Q^TQ=I\text{.}\)
    3. \(\displaystyle \beta_0 + 154\beta_1 + 68\beta_2 + 85\beta_3 + 17\beta_4 + 36\beta_5 = 13\)
    4. \(A\) is the \(10\times6\) matrix whose columns are a vector of all 1s followed by the vectors of weights, heights, abdominal, wrist, and neck measurements. The vector \(\bvec\) is the vector of BFI readings.
    5. \(Q\) is a \(10\times6\) matrix and \(R\) is a \(6\times6\) upper triangular matrix.
    6. We find that
      \begin{equation*} \beta_0 = 54.08, \beta_1 = 0.19, \beta_2 = -2.62, \beta_3 = 0.92, \beta_4 = 2.70, \beta_5 = -0.41 \end{equation*}
    7. \(\displaystyle R^2=0.95\)
    8. Evaluating \(\beta_0 + 190\beta_1 + 70\beta_2 + 90\beta_3 + 18\beta_4 + 35\beta_5 = 22.9\)
    Solution.
    1. The columns of \(Q\) form an orthonormal basis for \(\col(A)\) so that \(\bhat=QQ^T\bvec\text{.}\) The equation \(A\xhat=\bhat\) then becomes \(QR\xhat=QQ^T\bvec\text{.}\)
    2. Since \(Q^TQ=I\text{,}\) we have \(Q^TQR\xhat = Q^TQQ^T\bvec\text{,}\) which gives \(R\xhat = Q^T\bvec\text{.}\)
    3. \(\displaystyle \beta_0 + 154\beta_1 + 68\beta_2 + 85\beta_3 + 17\beta_4 + 36\beta_5 = 13\)
    4. \(A\) is the \(10\times6\) matrix whose columns are a vector of all 1s followed by the vectors of weights, heights, abdominal, wrist, and neck measurements. The vector \(\bvec\) is the vector of BFI readings.
    5. \(Q\) is a \(10\times6\) matrix and \(R\) is a \(6\times6\) upper triangular matrix.
    6. We find that
      \begin{equation*} \beta_0 = 54.08, \beta_1 = 0.19, \beta_2 = -2.62, \beta_3 = 0.92, \beta_4 = 2.70, \beta_5 = -0.41 \end{equation*}
    7. \(\displaystyle R^2=0.95\)
    8. Evaluating \(\beta_0 + 190\beta_1 + 70\beta_2 + 90\beta_3 + 18\beta_4 + 35\beta_5 = 22.9\)

    22.5.4 Polynomial Regression

    Activity 22.5.5.

    Answer.
    1. We have the equations
      \begin{align*} \beta_0 + 0\beta_1 + 0^2\beta_2 \amp {}={} 2\\ \beta_0 + 1\beta_1 + 1^2\beta_2 \amp {}={} 1\\ \beta_0 + 2\beta_1 + 2^2\beta_2 \amp {}={} 3\\ \beta_0 + 3\beta_1 + 3^2\beta_2 \amp {}={} 3 \end{align*}
    2. \(\displaystyle \xhat = \threevec{7/4}{-1/4}{1/4}\)
    3. \(\frac74 - \frac14 x + \frac14x^2 = y\text{.}\)
    4. \(1.9375\text{.}\)
    5. \(\displaystyle 0.54\)
    6. \(2-\frac{25}{6}x+4x^2-\frac56x^3 = y\text{.}\)
    7. \(\displaystyle R^2=1\)
    8. The graph of the cubic function passes through each data point.
    Solution.
    1. We have the equations
      \begin{align*} \beta_0 + 0\beta_1 + 0^2\beta_2 \amp {}={} 2\\ \beta_0 + 1\beta_1 + 1^2\beta_2 \amp {}={} 1\\ \beta_0 + 2\beta_1 + 2^2\beta_2 \amp {}={} 3\\ \beta_0 + 3\beta_1 + 3^2\beta_2 \amp {}={} 3 \end{align*}
    2. With \(A=\begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp 4 \\ 1 \amp 3 \amp 9 \\ \end{bmatrix}\) and \(\bvec=\fourvec2133\text{,}\) we find \(\xhat = \threevec{7/4}{-1/4}{1/4}\)
    3. The quadratic function is \(\frac74 - \frac14 x + \frac14x^2 = y\text{.}\)
    4. The predicted value is \(y=\frac74 - \frac14(1.5)+\frac14(1.5)^2 = 1.9375\text{.}\)
    5. \(\displaystyle R^2 = 0.54\)
    6. We find \(2-\frac{25}{6}x+4x^2-\frac56x^3 = y\text{.}\)
    7. \(R^2=1\text{,}\) which means that we have a perfect fit.
    8. The graph of the cubic function passes through each data point.

    Activity 22.5.6.

    Answer.
    1. \(\displaystyle \xhat = \begin{bmatrix} 17.4\\-7.1\\4.5\\-1.1\\0.1\\-0.003 \end{bmatrix}\)
    2. The fifth degree polynomial fits the data fairly well.
    3. \(\displaystyle R^2=0.99\)
    4. \(R^2=0.9997\text{.}\)
    5. \(\displaystyle R^2=1\)
    6. \(8.7\) million square kilometers of sea ice.
    Solution.
    1. \(\displaystyle \xhat = \begin{bmatrix} 17.4\\-7.1\\4.5\\-1.1\\0.1\\-0.003 \end{bmatrix}\)
    2. The fifth degree polynomial fits the data fairly well.
    3. \(\displaystyle R^2=0.99\)
    4. \(R^2=0.9997\text{.}\)
    5. \(\displaystyle R^2=1\)
    6. \(k=5\) seems like a good choice, and this gives the prediction of \(8.7\) million square kilometers of sea ice.

    22.5.6 Exercises

    22.5.6.1.

    Answer.
    1. \(\wvec_1=\threevec12{-1}\) and \(\wvec_2=\threevec012\)
    2. \(\bhat = \threevec21{-8}\text{.}\)
    3. \(\xvec=\twovec{-1}{-3}\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. Applying Gram-Schmidt gives the orthogonal basis
      \begin{equation*} \wvec_1=\threevec12{-1},\hspace{24pt} \wvec_2=\threevec012 \end{equation*}
    2. Applying the Projection Formula gives \(\bhat = \threevec21{-8}\text{.}\)
    3. Solving the linear system gives \(\xvec=\twovec{-1}{-3}\text{.}\)

    22.5.6.2.

    Answer.
    1. \(A=\begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 2 \\ 1 \amp 3 \\ 1 \amp 4 \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{,}\) \(\bvec=\fourvec1112\text{.}\)
    2. \(\displaystyle \begin{bmatrix} 4 \amp 10 \\ 10 \amp 30 \\ \end{bmatrix} \xhat = \twovec5{14}\)
    3. \(\displaystyle \xhat = \twovec{1/2}{3/10}\)
    4. \(1.55\text{.}\)
    5. \(\displaystyle R^2=0.6\)
    Solution.
    1. The matrix \(A=\begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 2 \\ 1 \amp 3 \\ 1 \amp 4 \\ \end{bmatrix}\) and the vector \(\bvec=\fourvec1112\text{.}\)
    2. \(\displaystyle \begin{bmatrix} 4 \amp 10 \\ 10 \amp 30 \\ \end{bmatrix} \xhat = \twovec5{14}\)
    3. \(\displaystyle \xhat = \twovec{1/2}{3/10}\)
    4. The predicted value is \(y=1/2 + 3/10*3.5 = 1.55\text{.}\)
    5. \(\displaystyle R^2=0.6\)

    22.5.6.3.

    Solution.
    1. We have the Vandermonde matrix \(A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp 4 \\ 1 \amp 3 \amp 9 \\ 1 \amp 4 \amp 16\\ \end{bmatrix}\) and vector \(\bvec=\fourvec1112\text{.}\)
    2. The quadratic function is \(1.75 - 0.95x + 0.25x^2\text{.}\)
    3. This gives the predicted value \(1.75 - 0.95(3.5) + 0.25(3.5)^2=1.488\text{.}\)
    4. \(\displaystyle R^2=0.93\)

    22.5.6.4.

    Answer.
    1. \(\displaystyle \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp 2 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp 2 \\ 1 \amp 3 \amp 2 \\ 1 \amp 3 \amp 3 \\ \end{bmatrix} \xvec = \begin{bmatrix} 4.2 \\ 3.3 \\ 5.9 \\ 5.1 \\ 7.5 \\ 6.3 \end{bmatrix}\)
    2. \(\displaystyle \xhat=\threevec{2.95}{2.00}{-0.85}\)
    3. \(2.95+2.00(2.4)-0.85(2.9) = 5.27\text{.}\)
    4. \(\displaystyle R^2=0.99\)
    Solution.
    1. \(\displaystyle \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp 2 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp 2 \\ 1 \amp 3 \amp 2 \\ 1 \amp 3 \amp 3 \\ \end{bmatrix} \xvec = \begin{bmatrix} 4.2 \\ 3.3 \\ 5.9 \\ 5.1 \\ 7.5 \\ 6.3 \end{bmatrix}\)
    2. \(\displaystyle \xhat=\threevec{2.95}{2.00}{-0.85}\)
    3. \(2.95+2.00(2.4)-0.85(2.9) = 5.27\text{.}\)
    4. \(\displaystyle R^2=0.99\)

    22.5.6.5.

    Answer.
    1. True
    2. True
    3. False
    4. True
    5. False
    Solution.
    1. True. If \(A\xvec=\bvec\text{,}\) then \(\bvec\) is in \(\col(A)\) so \(A\xhat = \bhat = \bvec\text{.}\)
    2. True. If \(R^2 = 1 - \frac{|A\xhat - \bvec|^2} {|\widetilde{\bvec}|^2} = 1\text{,}\) then \(|A\xhat-\bvec| = 0\text{.}\) Therefore, \(A\xhat = \bvec\text{.}\)
    3. False. The product \(Q^TQ = I\) rather than the matrix that projects vectors orthogonally onto \(\col(A)\text{.}\)
    4. True, numerical issues are more likely to arise when solving the normal equations.
    5. False. The normal equations \(A^TA\xhat = A^T\bvec\) gives the least-squares approximate solution.

    22.5.6.6.

    Answer.
    1. \(\bvec\) is in \(\col(A)^\perp = \nul(A^T)\text{.}\)
    2. \(\xhat = A^T\bvec\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. Since \(A\xhat = \bhat\) and \(\xhat = \zerovec\text{,}\) we know that \(\bhat=\zerovec\text{.}\) This says that \(\bvec\) is in \(\col(A)^\perp = \nul(A^T)\text{.}\)
    2. In this case, \(\bhat = AA^T\bvec\text{,}\) which means we have \(A\xhat = AA^T\bvec\text{.}\) If we multiply both sides by \(A^T\text{,}\) we have \(\xhat = A^T\bvec\text{.}\)

    22.5.6.7.

    Answer.
    1. The matrix \(A\) will be the \(27\times 2\) matrix whose first column is all 1s and whose second column is the vector of years. The vector \(\bvec\) is the vector that records the number of people.
    2. \(N = 3.88\times10^9 - 1.90\times10^6t\text{.}\)
    3. \(\displaystyle R^2=0.90\)
    4. \(1.14\times10^8\text{.}\)
    5. 2045
    Solution.
    1. The matrix \(A\) will be the \(27\times 2\) matrix whose first column is all 1s and whose second column is the vector of years. The vector \(\bvec\) is the vector that records the number of people.
    2. We obtain \(N = 3.88\times10^9 - 1.90\times10^6t\text{.}\)
    3. \(\displaystyle R^2=0.90\)
    4. \(3.88\times10^9 - 1.90\times10^6(1985) = 1.14\times10^8\text{.}\)
    5. Solve \(N = 3.88\times10^9 - 1.90\times10^6t=0\) to obtain 2045.

    22.5.6.8.

    Answer.
    1. The matrix \(A\) is the \(9\times2\) matrix whose first column is all 1s and whose second column is the vector of the logarithms of the semi-major axes. The vector \(\bvec\) is the vector that records the logarithms of the periods.
    2. \(C=0.996\) and \(r=1.50\text{.}\)
    3. \(\displaystyle R^2=1.000\)
    4. \(7.99\) years.
    5. \(17.9\) AU.
    Solution.
    1. The matrix \(A\) is the \(9\times2\) matrix whose first column is all 1s and whose second column is the vector of the logarithms of the semi-major axes. The vector \(\bvec\) is the vector that records the logarithms of the periods.
    2. We find \(\xhat=\twovec{\ln(C)}{r} = \twovec{-0.0036}{1.501}\) so that \(C=e^{-0.0036} = 0.996\) and \(r=1.50\text{.}\) This means that \(P = 0.996L^{1.5}\text{.}\)
    3. \(R^2=1.000\text{,}\) which means that we have a very good fit because this data reflects a physical law.
    4. \(P = 0.996(4.0)^{1.5}=7.99\) years.
    5. The expression \(\ln(P) = \ln(C) + r\ln(L)\) means that \(\ln(76) = \ln(C) + r\ln(L)\text{.}\) Solving for \(L = 17.9\) AU.

    22.5.6.9.

    Answer.
    1. The matrix \(A\) will be the Vandermonde matrix of degree \(k\) using the altitude readings while \(\bvec\) is the vector of temperatures.
    2. \(k=6\) appears to give a good fit without overfitting.
    3. We have
      \begin{equation*} 18.0-10.3x+0.35x^2+0.0003x^3-0.0001x^4+1.5\times10^{-6}x^5 -4.7\times 10^{-9}x^6\text{.} \end{equation*}
    4. A small value of \(k\) does not adequately track important features of the data. If we increase \(k\) too far, the graph tries too hard to match the data, and we see spurious features in the graph.
    5. We estimate the temperature to be \(-7\) degrees Celsius.
    Solution.
    1. The matrix \(A\) will be the Vandermonde matrix of degree \(k\) using the altitude readings while \(\bvec\) is the vector of temperatures.
    2. \(k=6\) appears to give a good fit without overfitting.
    3. We have
      \begin{equation*} 18.0-10.3x+0.35x^2+0.0003x^3-0.0001x^4+1.5\times10^{-6}x^5 -4.7\times 10^{-9}x^6\text{.} \end{equation*}
    4. A small value of \(k\) does not adequately track important features of the data. If we increase \(k\) too far, the graph tries too hard to match the data, and we see spurious features in the graph.
    5. \(k=6\) seems to work well. With this function, we estimate the temperature to be \(-7\) degrees Celsius.

    22.5.6.10.

    Answer.
    1. \(\displaystyle \xhat = \fourvec{\beta_0}{\beta_1}{\beta_2}{\beta_3} = \fourvec{20823}{84.7}{588.4}{-263.6}\)
    2. Increasing the living area or the lot size will cause the house price to increase, but an older house will cost less.
    3. A house thats one year older will cost about \(\$263.60\) less.
    4. \(\displaystyle R^2=0.59\)
    5. We estimate \(\$177966\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. \(\displaystyle \xhat = \fourvec{\beta_0}{\beta_1}{\beta_2}{\beta_3} = \fourvec{20823}{84.7}{588.4}{-263.6}\)
    2. \(\beta_1\) and \(\beta_2\) are positive, which means that increasing the living area or the lot size will cause the house price to increase. However, \(\beta_3\) is negative, which means that an older house will cost less.
    3. Because \(\beta_3=-263.6\text{,}\) we would expect a house thats one year older to cost \(\$263.60\) less.
    4. \(R^2=0.59\text{,}\) which is far from perfect without being terrible. There are other factors that are not included in the dataset that can also influence the house price, such as number of bedrooms and the location.
    5. We estimate \(\$177966\text{.}\)

    22.5.6.11.

    Answer.
    1. Use the fact that \(\xvec\cdot(A^TA\xvec)= (A\xvec)^T(A\xvec)\text{.}\)
    2. It must be true that \(\xvec=\zerovec\text{.}\)
    3. This follows from the previous two parts of this exercise.
    4. The columns of \(A^TA\) must be linearly independent.
    Solution.
    1. Starting with the assumption that \(A^TA\xvec = \zerovec\text{,}\) we dot both sides of the equation with \(\xvec\) to obtain \(\xvec \cdot A^TA\xvec = 0\text{.}\) From here, we write
      \begin{equation*} \begin{aligned} \xvec\cdot A^TA\xvec \amp = 0 \\ \xvec^TA^TA\xvec \amp = 0 \\ (A\xvec)^T(A\xvec) \amp = 0 \\ (A\xvec)\cdot (A\xvec) \amp = 0 \\ \len{A\xvec}^2 \amp = 0. \\ \end{aligned} \end{equation*}
      This says that the length of \(A\xvec\) must be zero, which tells us that \(A\xvec=\zerovec\text{.}\)
    2. If the columns of \(A\) are linearly independent, we know that the only solution to the homogeneous equation \(A\xvec = \zerovec\) is \(\xvec = \zerovec\text{.}\)
    3. The previous two parts of this exercise tell us that \(A^TA\xvec = \zerovec\) implies that \(A\xvec = \zerovec\text{,}\) which implies that \(\xvec = \zerovec\text{.}\)
    4. Since the only solution to the homogeneous equation \(A^TA\xvec = \zerovec\) is \(\xvec=\zerovec\text{,}\) the columns of \(A^TA\) are linearly independent, which means that \(A^TA\xhat=A^T\bvec\) has only one solution.

    22.5.6.12.

    Answer.
    1. \(\bvec\cdot\onevec\) simply sums the components of \(\bvec\text{.}\)
    2. \(\onevec\) is a column of \(A\text{.}\)
    3. \(\bperp\) is in \(\col(A)^\perp\text{.}\)
    4. Use the fact that \(\bhat\) and \(\bperp\) are orthogonal.
    5. This follows from \(\bvec = \bhat + \bperp\text{.}\)
    6. This follow from \(\var(\bvec) = \var(\bhat) + \var(\bperp)\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. \(\bvec\cdot\onevec\) simply sums the components of \(\bvec\text{.}\)
    2. The examples weve seen fit the data using functions that have a constant term such as \(y=\beta_0+\beta_1x\text{.}\) This means that \(\onevec\) will be a column of the matrix \(A\) and hence in \(\col(A)\text{.}\)
    3. Since \(\onevec\) is in \(\col(A)\text{,}\) any vector in \(\col(A)^\perp\text{,}\) such as \(\bperp\text{,}\) will be orthogonal to \(\onevec\text{.}\)
    4. Notice that
      \begin{equation*} \bvec\cdot\onevec = \bhat\cdot\onevec + \bperp\cdot\onevec = \bhat\cdot\onevec \end{equation*}
      which says that
      \begin{equation*} \widetilde{\bvec} = \widetilde{\bhat} + \bperp\text{.} \end{equation*}
      Since \(\bhat\) and \(\bperp\) are orthogonal, we have \(\widetilde{\bhat}\cdot\bperp = 0\text{.}\) This means that
      \begin{equation*} |\widetilde{\bvec}|^2 = (\widetilde{\bhat}+\bperp)\cdot (\widetilde{\bhat}+\bperp) = |\widetilde{\bhat}|^2 + |\bperp|^2 \end{equation*}
      so that \(\var(\bvec) = \var(\bhat)+\var(\bperp)\text{.}\)
    5. \(|\bvec-A\xhat|^2 = |\bvec-\bhat|^2 = |\bperp|^2\text{,}\) which explains why
      \begin{equation*} \frac{\len{\bvec - A\xhat}^2}{\len{\widetilde{\bvec}}^2} = \frac{\var(\bvec^\perp)}{\var(\bvec)}\text{.} \end{equation*}
      Then
      \begin{equation*} R^2 = 1 - \frac{\len{\bvec - A\xhat}^2}{\len{\widetilde{\bvec}}^2} = 1-\frac{\var(\bvec^\perp)}{\var(\bvec)} = \frac{\var(\bvec) - \var(\bperp)}{\var(\bvec)} = \frac{\var(\bhat)}{\var(\bvec)}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    6. The variances are nonnegative so we have \(R^2 \geq 0\text{.}\) Also,
      \begin{equation*} 1 = \frac{\var(\bvec)}{\var(\bvec)} = \frac{\var(\bhat)+\var(\bperp)}{\var(\bvec)} \geq \frac{\var(\bhat)}{\var(\bvec)}=R^2\text{.} \end{equation*}

    23 Singular value decompositions
    23.1 Symmetric matrices and variance
    23.1.1 Symmetric matrices and orthogonal diagonalization

    Activity 23.1.2.

    Answer.
      1. There is no such basis.
      2. There is no such basis.
      3. This matrix is diagonalizable with
        \begin{equation*} D = \begin{bmatrix} 2 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix}, \hspace{24pt} P = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{.} \end{equation*}
      4. This matrix is also diagonalizable with
        \begin{equation*} D = \begin{bmatrix} 10 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 5 \\ \end{bmatrix}, \hspace{24pt} P = \begin{bmatrix} 2 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp -2 \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    2. Only the last matrix.
    3. \(\displaystyle Q = \begin{bmatrix} 2/\sqrt{5} \amp 1/\sqrt{5} \\ 1/\sqrt{5} \amp -2/\sqrt{5} \\ \end{bmatrix}\)
    4. \(\displaystyle Q^{-1} = Q^T\)
    5. \(\displaystyle A=A^T\)
    Solution.
      1. The eigenvalues of this matrix are complex so there is no such basis.
      2. There is one eigenvalue \(\lambda=2\) with multiplicity two. The associated eigenspace \(E_2\) is one-dimensional so there is not a basis of \(\real^2\) consisting of eigenvectors.
      3. This matrix is diagonalizable with
        \begin{equation*} D = \begin{bmatrix} 2 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix}, \hspace{24pt} P = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{.} \end{equation*}
      4. This matrix is also diagonalizable with
        \begin{equation*} D = \begin{bmatrix} 10 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 5 \\ \end{bmatrix}, \hspace{24pt} P = \begin{bmatrix} 2 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp -2 \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    2. Only the last matrix \(A=\begin{bmatrix} 9 \amp 2 \\ 2 \amp 6 \end{bmatrix}\text{.}\)
    3. We form an orthonormal basis by scaling the eigenvectors to have length 1. This gives \(Q = \begin{bmatrix} 2/\sqrt{5} \amp 1/\sqrt{5} \\ 1/\sqrt{5} \amp -2/\sqrt{5} \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{,}\) which is orthogonal since the columns form an orthonormal basis of \(\real^2\text{.}\)
    4. Orthogonal matrices are invertible and have \(Q^{-1} = Q^T\)
    5. If \(A=QDQ^T\text{,}\) we have \(A^T=(QDQ^T)^T = (Q^T)^TD^TQ^T = QDQ^T = A\text{.}\) This means that the matrix is symmetric.

    Activity 23.1.3.

    Answer.
    1. \begin{equation*} D = \begin{bmatrix} 4 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -1 \\ \end{bmatrix}, \hspace{24pt} Q = \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{5} \amp 2/\sqrt{5} \\ 2/\sqrt{5} \amp -1/\sqrt{5} \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    2. \begin{equation*} D = \begin{bmatrix} 36 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 9 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp -9 \\ \end{bmatrix}, \hspace{24pt} Q = \begin{bmatrix} 1/3 \amp 2/3 \amp 2/3 \\ -2/3 \amp 2/3 \amp -1/3 \\ 2/3 \amp 1/3 \amp -2/3 \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    3. \begin{equation*} D = \begin{bmatrix} 10 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix}, \hspace{24pt} Q = \begin{bmatrix} 2/3 \amp 1/\sqrt{5} \amp -4/\sqrt{45} \\ 2/3 \amp 0 \amp 5/\sqrt{45} \\ 1/3 \amp -2/\sqrt{5} \amp -2/\sqrt{45} \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    4. \begin{equation*} D = \begin{bmatrix} 7 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 3 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix}, \hspace{24pt} Q = \begin{bmatrix} 2/\sqrt{14} \amp 2/\sqrt{6} \amp 1/\sqrt{21} \\ 1/\sqrt{14} \amp -1/\sqrt{6} \amp 4/\sqrt{21} \\ 3/\sqrt{14} \amp -1/\sqrt{6} \amp -2/\sqrt{21} \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    Solution.
    1. We have eigenvectors \(\vvec_1=\twovec12\) and \(\vvec_2 = \twovec{2}{-1}\) with associated eigenvalues \(\lambda_1 = 4\) and \(\lambda_2=-1\text{.}\) We form an orthonormal basis of eigenvectors, \(\uvec_1=\twovec{1/\sqrt{5}}{2/\sqrt{5}}\) and \(\uvec_2=\twovec{2/\sqrt{5}}{-1/\sqrt{5}}\text{.}\) This gives
      \begin{equation*} D = \begin{bmatrix} 4 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -1 \\ \end{bmatrix}, \hspace{24pt} Q = \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{5} \amp 2/\sqrt{5} \\ 2/\sqrt{5} \amp -1/\sqrt{5} \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    2. We find
      \begin{equation*} D = \begin{bmatrix} 36 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 9 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp -9 \\ \end{bmatrix}, \hspace{24pt} Q = \begin{bmatrix} 1/3 \amp 2/3 \amp 2/3 \\ -2/3 \amp 2/3 \amp -1/3 \\ 2/3 \amp 1/3 \amp -2/3 \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    3. We have eigenvalues \(\lambda_1=10\) with associated eigenvector \(\vvec_1=\threevec211\) and \(\lambda_2 = 1\) with associated eigenvectors \(\vvec_2=\threevec10{-2}\) and \(\vvec_3=\threevec01{-2}\text{.}\) Notice that \(\vvec_1\) is orthogonal to both \(\vvec_2\) and \(\vvec_3\text{,}\) but \(\vvec_2\) and \(\vvec_3\) are not orthogonal to one another. We can, however, apply Gram-Schmidt to create an orthogonal basis of the eigenspace \(E_1\text{.}\) We can then form an orthonormal basis so that
      \begin{equation*} D = \begin{bmatrix} 10 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix}, \hspace{24pt} Q = \begin{bmatrix} 2/3 \amp 1/\sqrt{5} \amp -4/\sqrt{45} \\ 2/3 \amp 0 \amp 5/\sqrt{45} \\ 1/3 \amp -2/\sqrt{5} \amp -2/\sqrt{45} \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    4. We have \(A^T = (B^TB)^T = B^T(B^T)^T=B^TB = A\) so \(A\) must be symmetric. Then we find the orthogonal diagonalization
      \begin{equation*} D = \begin{bmatrix} 7 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 3 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix}, \hspace{24pt} Q = \begin{bmatrix} 2/\sqrt{14} \amp 2/\sqrt{6} \amp 1/\sqrt{21} \\ 1/\sqrt{14} \amp -1/\sqrt{6} \amp 4/\sqrt{21} \\ 3/\sqrt{14} \amp -1/\sqrt{6} \amp -2/\sqrt{21} \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{.} \end{equation*}

    23.1.2 Variance

    Activity 23.1.4.

    Answer.
    1. \(\overline{d} = \twovec22\text{.}\)
    2. \begin{equation*} \dtil_1=\twovec{-1}{-1},\hspace{24pt} \dtil_2=\twovec{0}{-1},\hspace{24pt} \dtil_3=\twovec{1}{2}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    3. \(V=8/3\text{.}\)
    4. \(V_x = 2/3\) and \(V_y=2\)
    5. \(\displaystyle V=V_x+V_y\)
    6. \(V_{\vvec_1} = 7/3\)
      \(V_{\vvec_2} = 1/3\)
    7. \(\displaystyle V = V_{\vvec_1} + V_{\vvec_2}\)
    Solution.
    1. The centroid is \(\overline{d} = \twovec22\text{.}\)
    2. The demeaned data points are
      \begin{equation*} \dtil_1=\twovec{-1}{-1},\hspace{24pt} \dtil_2=\twovec{0}{-1},\hspace{24pt} \dtil_3=\twovec{1}{2}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    3. The total variance is \(V=8/3\text{.}\)
    4. We find \(V_x = 2/3\) and \(V_y=2\text{.}\) Notice that \(V_y\) is larger because the points are more spread out in the vertical direction.
    5. We have \(V=V_x+V_y\) due to the Pythagorean theorem.
    6. The points projected onto the line defined by \(\vvec_1\) are \(\twovec{-1}{-1}\text{,}\) \(\twovec{-1/2}{-1/2}\text{,}\) and \(\twovec{3/2}{3/2}\text{.}\) This gives the variance \(V_{\vvec_1} = 7/3\text{.}\)
      The points projected onto the line defined by \(\vvec_2\) are \(\twovec{0}{0}\text{,}\) \(\twovec{1/2}{-1/2}\text{,}\) and \(\twovec{-1/2}{1/2}\text{.}\) This gives the variance \(V_{\vvec_2} = 1/3\text{.}\)
    7. Once again, \(V = V_{\vvec_1} + V_{\vvec_2}\) because of the Pythagorean theorem.

    Activity 23.1.5.

    Answer.
    1. \(\displaystyle A^T\uvec=\threevec{\dtil_1\cdot\uvec} {\dtil_2\cdot\uvec} {\dtil_3\cdot\uvec}\)
    2. \begin{equation*} V_{\uvec} = \frac13\left((\dtil_1\cdot\uvec)^2 + (\dtil_2\cdot\uvec)^2 + (\dtil_3\cdot\uvec)^2\right) = \frac13|A^T\uvec|^2\text{.} \end{equation*}
    3. \begin{equation*} \frac13(A^T\uvec)\cdot(A^T\uvec) = \frac13\uvec\cdot(A^T)^TA^T\uvec = \uvec\cdot\left(\frac13AA^T\right)\uvec \end{equation*}
    4. \(\displaystyle C=\begin{bmatrix} 2/3 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 2 \end{bmatrix}\)
    5. \(\displaystyle V_{\uvec_1} = 38/15\)
    6. \(V_{\uvec_2} = 2/15\text{.}\)
    7. \(\displaystyle C^T = \left(\frac13 AA^T\right)^T = \frac13(A^T)^TA^T = \frac13 AA^T = C\)
    Solution.
    1. \(\displaystyle A^T\uvec=\threevec{\dtil_1\cdot\uvec} {\dtil_2\cdot\uvec} {\dtil_3\cdot\uvec}\)
    2. Projecting \(\dtil_j\) onto \(\uvec\) gives \((\dtil_j\cdot\uvec)\uvec\text{,}\) whose length squared is \((\dtil_j\cdot\uvec)^2\text{.}\) Then
      \begin{equation*} V_{\uvec} = \frac13\left((\dtil_1\cdot\uvec)^2 + (\dtil_2\cdot\uvec)^2 + (\dtil_3\cdot\uvec)^2\right) = \frac13|A^T\uvec|^2\text{.} \end{equation*}
    3. \begin{equation*} \frac13(A^T\uvec)\cdot(A^T\uvec) = \frac13\uvec\cdot(A^T)^TA^T\uvec = \uvec\cdot\left(\frac13AA^T\right)\uvec \end{equation*}
    4. \(\displaystyle C=\begin{bmatrix} 2/3 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 2 \end{bmatrix}\)
    5. \(\displaystyle V_{\uvec_1} = 38/15\)
    6. \(V_{\uvec_2} = 2/15\text{.}\) Then \(V_{\uvec_1}+V_{\uvec_2} = 8/3\text{,}\) which is the total variance.
    7. \(\displaystyle C^T = \left(\frac13 AA^T\right)^T = \frac13(A^T)^TA^T = \frac13 AA^T = C\)

    Activity 23.1.6.

    Answer.
    1. \(\displaystyle C=\begin{bmatrix} 1.38 \amp 0.70 \\ 0.70 \amp 0.37 \end{bmatrix}\)
    2. \(V_x = 1.38\) and \(V_y=0.37\)
    3. \(\displaystyle V=1.75\)
    4. If \(\uvec_1=\twovec{2/\sqrt{5}}{1/\sqrt{5}}\text{,}\) then \(V_{\uvec_1} = 1.74\text{.}\)
    5. If \(\uvec_2=\twovec{-1/\sqrt{5}}{2/\sqrt{5}}\text{,}\) then \(V_{\uvec_2} = 0.01\text{.}\)
    6. They are orthogonal to one another.
    Solution.
    1. \(C\) will be the \(2\times2\) matrix \(C=\begin{bmatrix} 1.38 \amp 0.70 \\ 0.70 \amp 0.37 \end{bmatrix}\)
    2. \(V_x = 1.38\) and \(V_y=0.37\text{,}\) which agrees with the fact that the data is more spread out in the horizontal than vertical direction.
    3. \(\displaystyle V=V_x+V_y=1.75\)
    4. It looks like the direction \(\twovec21\) defined by the unit vector \(\uvec_1=\twovec{2/\sqrt{5}}{1/\sqrt{5}}\text{.}\) We find that \(V_{\uvec_1} = 1.74\text{,}\) which is almost all of the total variance.
    5. It looks like the direction \(\twovec{-1}{2}\) defined by the unit vector \(\uvec_2=\twovec{-1/\sqrt{5}}{2/\sqrt{5}}\text{.}\) We find that \(V_{\uvec_2} = 0.01\text{.}\)
    6. They are orthogonal to one another. Since the total variance \(V=V_{\uvec_1}+V_{\uvec_2}\) when \(\uvec_1\) and \(\uvec_2\) are orthogonal, \(V_{\uvec_1}\) will be as large as possible when \(V_{\uvec_2}\) is as small as possible.

    23.1.4 Exercises

    23.1.4.1.

    Answer.
    1. Not diagonalizable
    2. \begin{equation*} D = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -1 \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} Q = \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{2} \amp 1/\sqrt{2} \\ 1/\sqrt{2} \amp -1/\sqrt{2} \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    3. Diagonalizable, but not orthogonally diagonalizable.
      \begin{equation*} D = \begin{bmatrix} 4 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} P = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \amp 9 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 6 \amp 6 \\ 1 \amp -2 \amp -1 \end{bmatrix}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    4. \begin{equation*} D = \begin{bmatrix} 6 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 3 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp -12 \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} Q = \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{2} \amp 1/\sqrt{3} \amp 1/\sqrt{6} \\ 0 \amp 1/\sqrt{3} \amp -2/\sqrt{6} \\ -1/\sqrt{2} \amp 1/\sqrt{3} \amp 1/\sqrt{6} \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    Solution.
    1. This matrix is not diagonalizable because there is not a basis of \(\real^2\) consisting of eigenvectors.
    2. This matrix is symmetric so it is orthogonally diagonalizable:
      \begin{equation*} D = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -1 \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} Q = \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{2} \amp 1/\sqrt{2} \\ 1/\sqrt{2} \amp -1/\sqrt{2} \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    3. This matrix is diagonalizable but not orthogonally diagonalizable.
      \begin{equation*} D = \begin{bmatrix} 4 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} P = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \amp 9 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 6 \amp 6 \\ 1 \amp -2 \amp -1 \end{bmatrix}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    4. This matrix is symmetric so its orthogonally diagonalizable.
      \begin{equation*} D = \begin{bmatrix} 6 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 3 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp -12 \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} Q = \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{2} \amp 1/\sqrt{3} \amp 1/\sqrt{6} \\ 0 \amp 1/\sqrt{3} \amp -2/\sqrt{6} \\ -1/\sqrt{2} \amp 1/\sqrt{3} \amp 1/\sqrt{6} \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{.} \end{equation*}

    23.1.4.2.

    Answer.
    1. Because of the Spectral Theorem
    2. \(\displaystyle \uvec_1=\threevec{1/\sqrt{3}}{1/\sqrt{3}}{1/\sqrt{3}}\)
    3. \(\vvec_1 = \threevec10{-1}\) and \(\vvec_2=\threevec01{-1}\)
    4. \(\uvec_2 = \threevec{1/\sqrt{2}}0{-1/\sqrt{2}}\) and \(\uvec_3 = \threevec{-1/\sqrt{6}}{2/\sqrt{6}}{-1/\sqrt{6}}\)
    5. \begin{equation*} D = \begin{bmatrix} 5 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp -1 \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} Q = \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{3} \amp 1/\sqrt{2} \amp -1/\sqrt{6} \\ 1/\sqrt{3} \amp 0 \amp 2/\sqrt{6} \\ 1/\sqrt{3} \amp -1/\sqrt{2} \amp -1/\sqrt{6} \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    Solution.
    1. Since the matrix is symmetric, the Spectral Theorem says it is orthogonally diagonalizable.
    2. \(\displaystyle \uvec_1=\threevec{1/\sqrt{3}}{1/\sqrt{3}}{1/\sqrt{3}}\)
    3. \(\vvec_1 = \threevec10{-1}\) and \(\vvec_2=\threevec01{-1}\)
    4. \(\uvec_2 = \threevec{1/\sqrt{2}}0{-1/\sqrt{2}}\) and \(\uvec_3 = \threevec{-1/\sqrt{6}}{2/\sqrt{6}}{-1/\sqrt{6}}\)
    5. \begin{equation*} D = \begin{bmatrix} 5 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp -1 \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} Q = \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{3} \amp 1/\sqrt{2} \amp -1/\sqrt{6} \\ 1/\sqrt{3} \amp 0 \amp 2/\sqrt{6} \\ 1/\sqrt{3} \amp -1/\sqrt{2} \amp -1/\sqrt{6} \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{.} \end{equation*}

    23.1.4.3.

    Answer.
    1. \begin{equation*} D = \begin{bmatrix} 21 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 9 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp -21 \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} Q = \begin{bmatrix} 2/3 \amp 2/3 \amp 1/3 \\ -1/3 \amp 2/3 \amp -2/3 \\ 2/3 \amp -1/3 \amp -2/3 \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    2. Not orthogonally diagonalizable
    3. \begin{equation*} D = \begin{bmatrix} 18 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 6 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 6 \amp 0\\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 6\\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} Q = \begin{bmatrix} 1/2 \amp 1/\sqrt{2} \amp -1/\sqrt{6} \amp -1/\sqrt{12} \\ 1/2 \amp 0 \amp 2/\sqrt{6} \amp -1/\sqrt{12} \\ 1/2 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 3/\sqrt{12} \\ 1/2 \amp -1/\sqrt{2} \amp -1/\sqrt{6} \amp -1/\sqrt{12} \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    Solution.
    1. \begin{equation*} D = \begin{bmatrix} 21 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 9 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp -21 \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} Q = \begin{bmatrix} 2/3 \amp 2/3 \amp 1/3 \\ -1/3 \amp 2/3 \amp -2/3 \\ 2/3 \amp -1/3 \amp -2/3 \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    2. This matrix is not symmetric so it is not orthogonally diagonalizable.
    3. \begin{equation*} D = \begin{bmatrix} 18 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 6 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 6 \amp 0\\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 6\\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} Q = \begin{bmatrix} 1/2 \amp 1/\sqrt{2} \amp -1/\sqrt{6} \amp -1/\sqrt{12} \\ 1/2 \amp 0 \amp 2/\sqrt{6} \amp -1/\sqrt{12} \\ 1/2 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 3/\sqrt{12} \\ 1/2 \amp -1/\sqrt{2} \amp -1/\sqrt{6} \amp -1/\sqrt{12} \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{.} \end{equation*}

    23.1.4.4.

    Answer.
    1. \(B\) is symmetric
    2. \(\displaystyle \vvec\cdot(A^TA\vvec) = (A\vvec)\cdot(A\vvec)\)
    3. \(\displaystyle |A\uvec|^2 = \lambda\)
    4. \(\lambda=|A\uvec|^2 \geq 0\text{.}\)
    5. \(\uvec\cdot(C\uvec) = \frac1N(A^T\uvec)\cdot(A^T\uvec) = \frac1N |A^T\uvec|^2\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. Because \(B^T = (A^TA)^T = A^TA = B\text{,}\) the matrix \(B\) is symmetric and hence orthogonally diagonalizable.
    2. \(\vvec\cdot(B\vvec) = \vvec\cdot(A^TA\vvec) = (A\vvec)\cdot(A\vvec) = |A\vvec|^2\text{.}\)
    3. \(\displaystyle |A\uvec|^2 = \uvec\cdot(B\uvec) = \lambda\uvec\cdot\uvec = \lambda\)
    4. Because \(\lambda=|A\uvec|^2 \geq 0\text{.}\)
    5. In the same way, \(C=\frac1N AA^T\) so that \(\uvec\cdot(C\uvec) = \frac1N(A^T\uvec)\cdot(A^T\uvec) = \frac1N |A^T\uvec|^2\text{.}\) Therefore, \(\lambda = \frac1N|A^T\uvec|^2\text{.}\)

    23.1.4.5.

    Answer.
    1. \begin{equation*} \twovec{-1}{-2},\twovec{-1}{1},\twovec1{-1},\twovec{0}{0}, \twovec12 \end{equation*}
    2. \(\displaystyle V = 14/5\)
    3. \(V_{\evec_1} = 4/5\) and \(V_{\evec_2} = 2\)
    4. \(\displaystyle 34/25\)
    5. \(\displaystyle 36/24\)
    6. The variances add to the toal variance.
    Solution.
    1. \begin{equation*} \twovec{-1}{-2},\twovec{-1}{1},\twovec1{-1},\twovec{0}{0}, \twovec12 \end{equation*}
    2. \(\displaystyle V = 14/5\)
    3. \(V_{\evec_1} = 4/5\) and \(V_{\evec_2} = 2\)
    4. Let \(\uvec_1\) be the unit vector parallel to \(\vvec_1\) so that \(V_{\uvec_1} = 34/25\text{.}\)
    5. Let \(\uvec_2\) be the unit vector parallel to \(\vvec_2\) so that \(V_{\uvec_2} = 36/25\text{.}\)
    6. The vectors are parallel so the variances add to the toal variance.

    23.1.4.6.

    Answer.
    1. \(\displaystyle A = \begin{bmatrix} -1 \amp -3 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ -2 \amp -3 \amp 0 \amp 2 \amp 1 \amp 2 \end{bmatrix}\)
    2. \(\displaystyle C=\begin{bmatrix} 8/3 \amp 5/2 \\ 5/2 \amp 11/3 \end{bmatrix}\)
    3. \begin{equation*} D = \begin{bmatrix} 5.72 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0.62 \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} Q = \begin{bmatrix} 0.63 \amp 0.77 \\ 0.77 \amp -0.63 \\ \end{bmatrix} \end{equation*}
    4. \(\uvec_1=\twovec{0.63}{0.77}\) and \(\uvec_2=\twovec{0.77}{-0.63}\text{.}\)
    5. \(V_{\uvec_1}=5.72\) and \(V_{\uvec_2} = 0.62\)
    Solution.
    1. \(\displaystyle A = \begin{bmatrix} -1 \amp -3 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ -2 \amp -3 \amp 0 \amp 2 \amp 1 \amp 2 \end{bmatrix}\)
    2. \(C=\begin{bmatrix} 8/3 \amp 5/2 \\ 5/2 \amp 11/3 \end{bmatrix}\) is orthonally diagonalizable because it is symmetric.
    3. \begin{equation*} D = \begin{bmatrix} 5.72 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0.62 \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} Q = \begin{bmatrix} 0.63 \amp 0.77 \\ 0.77 \amp -0.63 \\ \end{bmatrix} \end{equation*}
    4. Sketch the lines defined by \(\twovec{0.63}{0.77}\) and \(\twovec{0.77}{-0.63}\text{.}\)
    5. The variances are the eigenvalues \(\lambda_1=5.72\) and \(\lambda_2 = 0.62\)

    23.1.4.7.

    Answer.
    1. \(V_{\uvec} = \uvec\cdot(C\uvec) = \lambda\uvec\cdot\uvec = \lambda\text{.}\)
    2. \(\displaystyle V_{\uvec_2} = 0\)
    3. \(\displaystyle V_{\uvec_1}+V_{\uvec_2} = \lambda_1+\lambda_2\)
    Solution.
    1. The variance is \(V_{\uvec} = \uvec\cdot(C\uvec) = \lambda\uvec\cdot\uvec = \lambda\text{.}\)
    2. \(\displaystyle V_{\uvec_2} = 0\)
    3. \(\displaystyle V=V_{\uvec_1}+V_{\uvec_2} = \lambda_1+\lambda_2\)

    23.1.4.8.

    Answer.
    1. True.
    2. True.
    3. False.
    4. True.
    5. False.
    Solution.
    1. True. If \(A=QDQ^T\) is invertible, then the eigenvalues are nonzero, which means that \(D\) is invertible. Therefore, \(A^{-1} = (Q^T)^{-1}D^{-1}Q^{-1} = QD^{-1}Q^T\text{,}\) which says that \(A^{-1}\) is orthogonally diagonalizable.
    2. True. In this case, there cannot be a basis for \(\real^m\) consisting of eigenvalues of \(A\) so \(A\) is not diagonalizable.
    3. False. This condition implies that \(A\) is diagonalizable, but it may not be orthogonally diagonalizable.
    4. True. The eigenvectors of a symmetric matrix associated to different eigenvalues are orthogonal.
    5. False. This is only true if \(A\) is symmetric.

    23.1.4.9.

    Answer.
    \begin{equation*} D = \begin{bmatrix} 20 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -4 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} Q = \begin{bmatrix} 2/3 \amp 1/\sqrt{18} \amp -1/\sqrt{2} \\ -1/3 \amp 4/\sqrt{18} \amp 0 \\ 2/3 \amp 1/\sqrt{18} \amp 1/\sqrt{2} \\ \end{bmatrix} \end{equation*}
    Solution.
    Since \(A\) is not invertible, the third eigenvalue must be zero: \(\lambda_3=0\text{.}\) Also, an eigenvector associated to \(\lambda_3\) must be orthogonal to both \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2\text{.}\) We can find such a vector by finding \(\nul(B^T)\) where \(B=\begin{bmatrix}\vvec_1\amp\vvec_2\end{bmatrix}\text{.}\) This leads to
    \begin{equation*} D = \begin{bmatrix} 20 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -4 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} Q = \begin{bmatrix} 2/3 \amp 1/\sqrt{18} \amp -1/\sqrt{2} \\ -1/3 \amp 4/\sqrt{18} \amp 0 \\ 2/3 \amp 1/\sqrt{18} \amp 1/\sqrt{2} \\ \end{bmatrix} \end{equation*}

    23.1.4.10.

    Answer.
    1. \(P\) is symmetric
    2. 0 or 1
    3. The eigenspaces \(E_1=W\) and \(E_0=W^{\perp}\)
    Solution.
    1. If \(Q\) is a \(3\times2\) matrix whose columns are an orthonormal basis for \(W\text{,}\) then \(P=QQ^T\text{.}\) This means that \(P^T=(Q^T)^TQ^T = QQ^T = P\) so \(P\) is symmetric and hence orthogonally diagonalizable.
    2. If \(\vvec\) is in \(W\text{,}\) then \(P\vvec=\vvec\) and if \(\vvec\) is in \(W^\perp\text{,}\) then \(P\vvec=0\text{.}\) This means that the eigenvalues of \(P\) are either 0 or 1.
    3. The eigenspaces \(E_1=W\) and \(E_0=W^{\perp}\)

    23.2 Quadratic forms
    23.2.1 Quadratic forms

    Activity 23.2.2.

    Answer.
    1. \(q_D(\xvec) = 3x_1^2 - x_2^2\) and \(q_D\left(\twovec2{-4}\right) = -4\)
    2. \(q_A(\xvec) = 2x_1^2 + 10x_1x_2-3x_2^2\) and \(q_A\left(\twovec2{-1}\right) = -15\)
