    3. \(\displaystyle A=\begin{bmatrix} 3 \amp -2 \\ -2 \amp 4 \\ \end{bmatrix}\)
    4. \(q(2\xvec) = 12\text{,}\) \(q(-\xvec) = 3\) and \(q(10\xvec)=300\)
    5. \(\displaystyle q_A(\xvec) = -196\)
    Solution.
    1. \(q_D(\xvec) = 3x_1^2 - x_2^2\) and \(q_D\left(\twovec2{-4}\right) = -4\)
    2. \(q_A(\xvec) = 2x_1^2 + 10x_1x_2-3x_2^2\) and \(q_A\left(\twovec2{-1}\right) = -15\)
    3. \(\displaystyle A=\begin{bmatrix} 3 \amp -2 \\ -2 \amp 4 \\ \end{bmatrix}\)
    4. Notice that \(q(2\xvec) = (2\xvec)\cdot(A(2\xvec)) = 4\xvec\cdot(A\xvec) = 4q(\xvec)\text{.}\) In the same way, we have \(q(-\xvec) = q(\xvec)\) and \(q(10\xvec) = 100q(\xvec)\text{.}\)
    5. \(\displaystyle q_A(\xvec) = \xvec\cdot(A\xvec) = -4\xvec\cdot\xvec = -4(49) = -196\)

    Activity 23.2.3.

    Answer.
    1. The maximum appears to occur in the direction of \(\twovec10\) and the minimum appears to occur in the direction of \(\twovec01\text{.}\)
    2. \(q_D(\xvec) = 3x_1^2 - x_2^2\) so that \(q_D\left(\twovec10\right) = 3\) and \(q_D\left(\twovec01\right) = -1\text{.}\)
    3. The maximum value of \(q_D(\uvec)\) is \(3\) in the direction \(\twovec10\text{.}\)
    4. The minimum value of \(q_D(\uvec)\) is \(-1\) in the direction \(\twovec01\text{.}\)
    5. The maximum appears to occur in the direction \(\twovec11\) and the minimum in the direction \(\twovec{-1}1\text{.}\)
    6. Use the fact that \(QQ^T=I\)
    7. The maximum of \(q_A(\uvec)\) is \(3\text{,}\) which occurs when \(\uvec= \twovec{1/\sqrt{2}}{1/\sqrt{2}}\text{.}\)
      The maximum of \(q_A(\uvec)\) is \(-1\text{,}\) which occurs when \(\uvec= \twovec{-1/\sqrt{2}}{1/\sqrt{2}}\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. The maximum appears to occur in the direction of \(\twovec10\) and the minimum appears to occur in the direction of \(\twovec01\text{.}\)
    2. \(q_D(\xvec) = 3x_1^2 - x_2^2\) so that \(q_D\left(\twovec10\right) = 3\) and \(q_D\left(\twovec01\right) = -1\text{.}\)
    3. We have \(q_D(\uvec) = 3u_1^2 - u_2^2 = 3 - 4u_2^2\) so that the quadratic form only depends on \(u_2\text{.}\) The graph of this function of \(u_2\) is a parabola that has a maximum of \(3\) when \(u_2=0\text{.}\) Since \(u_1^2 = 1-u_2^2\text{,}\) this means that the maximum occurs when \(u_1=\pm 1\text{.}\) We therefore see that the maximum value of \(q_D(\uvec)\) is \(3\) in the direction \(\twovec10\) as we saw from the graph.
    4. Now \(q_D(\uvec) = -1 + 4u_1^2\text{,}\) which has a minimum value of \(-1\) when \(u_1=0\text{.}\) Therefore, the minimum value of \(q_D(\uvec)\) is \(-1\) in the direction \(\twovec01\text{.}\)
    5. The graph of \(q_A\) appears to be similar to the graph of \(q_D\) only rotated by \(45^\circ\text{.}\) This means the maximum appears to occur in the direction \(\twovec11\) and the minimum in the direction \(\twovec{-1}1\text{.}\)
    6. Since \(Q\) is orthogonal, we have \(QQ^T=I\) so that
      \begin{equation*} |\vvec|^2 = (Q^T\uvec)\cdot(Q^T\uvec) = \uvec\cdot(QQ^T\uvec) = \uvec\cdot\uvec = |\uvec|^2 = 1\text{.} \end{equation*}
    7. Since \(q_A(\uvec) = q_D(\vvec)\text{,}\) the maximum of \(q_A(\uvec)\) is \(3\text{,}\) which occurs when \(\vvec = Q^T\uvec = \twovec10\text{.}\) This means that \(\uvec=Q\twovec10 = \twovec{1/\sqrt{2}}{1/\sqrt{2}}\text{,}\) the eigenvector of \(A\) associated to \(\lambda=3\text{.}\)
      In the same way, the minimum value of \(q_A(\uvec)\) is \(-1\text{,}\) which occurs when \(\uvec=\twovec{1/\sqrt{2}}{1/\sqrt{2}}\text{,}\) the eigenvector of \(A\) associated to \(\lambda=-1\text{.}\)

    23.2.2 Definite symmetric matrices

    Activity 23.2.4.

    Answer.
    1. \(q_D(\xvec) = 4x_1^2 + 2x_2^2\) so \(D\) is positive definite.
    2. \(q_D(\xvec) = 4x_1^2\) so \(D\) is positive semidefinite.
      1. They are all positive.
      2. They are all nonnegative.
      3. They are all negative.
      4. They are all nonpositive.
      5. They are some positive eigenvalues and some negative ones .
    4. \(A\) is positive definite.
    5. \(A\) is positive semidefinite.
    6. They will be the same as before.
    Solution.
    1. \(q_D(\xvec) = 4x_1^2 + 2x_2^2\text{.}\) Both addends are nonnegative, and one of them is positive if \(\xvec\) is nonzero. This means that \(q_D(\xvec) \gt 0\) when \(\xvec\) is nonzero and so \(D\) is positive definite.
    2. \(q_D(\xvec) = 4x_1^2\text{,}\) which is always nonnegative. However, \(q_D\left(\twovec01\right) = 0\) so \(D\) is positive semidefinite.
      1. They are all positive.
      2. They are all nonnegative.
      3. They are all negative.
      4. They are all nonpositive.
      5. They are some positive eigenvalues and some negative ones .
    4. Since we know that \(q_D(\yvec) \gt 0\) when \(\yvec\) is nonzero, we know that \(q_A(\xvec) \gt 0\) when \(\xvec\) is nonzero. Therefore, \(A\) is positive definite.
    5. It will be positive semidefinite.
    6. They will be the same as before.

    Activity 23.2.5.

    Answer.
    1. We have
      \begin{align*} f_x \amp {}={} 6x^2 - 6y = 0\\ f_y \amp {}={} -6x + 6y = 0 \end{align*}
    2. We have
      \begin{equation*} f_{xx} = 12x, \hspace{24pt} f_{xy} = -6, \hspace{24pt} f_{yy} = 6 \end{equation*}
    3. This gives
      \begin{equation*} f(x,y)\approx -1 + \frac12 12(x-1)^2 -6(x-1)(y-1) + \frac12 6(y-1)^2 \end{equation*}
    4. \(A = \begin{bmatrix} 6 \amp -3 \\ -3 \amp 3 \end{bmatrix} \text{.}\)
    5. \(A\) is positive definite.
    6. \(f(x,y) \approx f(1,1) + q_A(\wvec) \gt f(1,1)\) for points \((x,y)\) near to \((1,1)\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. We have
      \begin{align*} f_x \amp {}={} 6x^2 - 6y = 0\\ f_y \amp {}={} -6x + 6y = 0 \end{align*}
    2. We have
      \begin{equation*} f_{xx} = 12x, \hspace{24pt} f_{xy} = -6, \hspace{24pt} f_{yy} = 6 \end{equation*}
    3. This gives
      \begin{equation*} f(x,y)\approx -1 + \frac12 12(x-1)^2 -6(x-1)(y-1) + \frac12 6(y-1)^2 \end{equation*}
    4. The matrix is \(A = \begin{bmatrix} 6 \amp -3 \\ -3 \amp 3 \end{bmatrix} \text{.}\)
    5. The eigenvalues are \(\lambda_1=7.85\) and \(\lambda_2=1.15\text{,}\) both of which are positive, which means that \(A\) is positive definite.
    6. We have \(q_A(\wvec) \gt 0\) if \(\wvec\) is nonzero so
      \begin{equation*} f(x,y) \approx f(1,1) + q_A(\wvec) \gt f(1,1) \end{equation*}
      for points \((x,y)\) near to \((1,1)\text{.}\)

    23.2.4 Exercises

    23.2.4.1.

    Answer.
    1. \(A = QDQ^T\) where
      \begin{equation*} D=\begin{bmatrix} 8 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 3 \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} Q=\begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{5} \amp 2/\sqrt{5} \\ 2/\sqrt{5} \amp -1/\sqrt{5} \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    2. \(\displaystyle 15\)
    3. The maximum value is \(8\) in the direction \(\twovec{1/\sqrt{5}}{2/\sqrt{5}}\text{.}\)
    4. The minimum value is \(3\) in the direction \(\twovec{2/\sqrt{5}}{-1/\sqrt{5}}\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. \(A = QDQ^T\) where
      \begin{equation*} D=\begin{bmatrix} 8 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 3 \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} Q=\begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{5} \amp 2/\sqrt{5} \\ 2/\sqrt{5} \amp -1/\sqrt{5} \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    2. \(\displaystyle q_A\left(\twovec11\right) = \twovec11\cdot\left(A\twovec11\right) = 15\)
    3. The maximum value is \(8\) in the direction \(\twovec{1/\sqrt{5}}{2/\sqrt{5}}\text{.}\)
    4. The minimum value is \(3\) in the direction \(\twovec{2/\sqrt{5}}{-1/\sqrt{5}}\text{.}\)

    23.2.4.2.

    Answer.
    1. \(\displaystyle A = \begin{bmatrix} 3 \amp -2 \\ -2 \amp 6 \\ \end{bmatrix} \)
    2. The maximum value is \(7\) in the direction \(\twovec{1/\sqrt{5}}{-2/\sqrt{5}}\text{.}\) The minimum value is \(2\) in the direction \(\twovec{2/\sqrt{5}}{1/\sqrt{5}}\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. \(\displaystyle A = \begin{bmatrix} 3 \amp -2 \\ -2 \amp 6 \\ \end{bmatrix} \)
    2. The maximum value is \(7\) in the direction \(\twovec{1/\sqrt{5}}{-2/\sqrt{5}}\text{.}\) The minimum value is \(2\) in the direction \(\twovec{2/\sqrt{5}}{1/\sqrt{5}}\text{.}\)

    23.2.4.3.

    Answer.
    1. \(\displaystyle \begin{bmatrix} 3/2 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 1 \end{bmatrix}\)
    2. \(\displaystyle 9/4\)
    3. \(5/2\text{.}\)
    4. In the direction \(\uvec=\twovec{0.79}{0.62}\) where \(V_{\uvec}=2.28\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. \(\displaystyle C = \frac14 AA^T = \begin{bmatrix} 3/2 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 1 \end{bmatrix}\)
    2. \(\displaystyle V_{\uvec} = \uvec\cdot(C\uvec) = 9/4\)
    3. The total variance is \(V_x+V_y = 3/2+1=5/2\text{.}\)
    4. The variance is greatest in the direction \(\uvec=\twovec{0.79}{0.62}\) where \(V_{\uvec}=2.28\text{.}\)

    23.2.4.4.

    Answer.
    1. \begin{equation*} D = \begin{bmatrix} 7 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 7 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} Q = \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{2} \amp -1/\sqrt{6} \amp 1/\sqrt{3} \\ 0 \amp 2/\sqrt{6} \amp 1/\sqrt{3} \\ -1/\sqrt{2} \amp -1/\sqrt{6} \amp 1/\sqrt{3} \\ \end{bmatrix} \end{equation*}
    2. The maximum is 7 and the minimum is -2.
    3. The minimum occurs in the direction of \(\threevec{1/\sqrt{3}}{1/\sqrt{3}}{1/\sqrt{3}}\text{.}\) The maximum occurs along a circle defined by \(c_1\uvec_1+c_2\uvec_2\) where \(c_1^2+c_2^2=1\) and \(\uvec_1\) and \(\uvec_2\) are the first two columns of \(Q\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. \begin{equation*} D = \begin{bmatrix} 7 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 7 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} Q = \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{2} \amp -1/\sqrt{6} \amp 1/\sqrt{3} \\ 0 \amp 2/\sqrt{6} \amp 1/\sqrt{3} \\ -1/\sqrt{2} \amp -1/\sqrt{6} \amp 1/\sqrt{3} \\ \end{bmatrix} \end{equation*}
    2. The maximum is 7 and the minimum is -2.
    3. The minimum occurs in the direction of \(\threevec{1/\sqrt{3}}{1/\sqrt{3}}{1/\sqrt{3}}\text{.}\) The maximum occurs along a circle defined by \(c_1\uvec_1+c_2\uvec_2\) where \(c_1^2+c_2^2=1\) and \(\uvec_1\) and \(\uvec_2\) are the first two columns of \(Q\text{.}\)

    23.2.4.5.

    Answer.
    1. \(A = B^TB=\begin{bmatrix} 24 \amp -12 \\ -12 \amp 6 \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{.}\)
    2. The maximum value is \(30\) in the direction \(\twovec{2/\sqrt{5}}{-1/\sqrt{5}}\) and the minimum value is \(0\) in the direction \(\twovec{1/\sqrt{5}}{2/\sqrt{5}}\text{.}\)
    3. The columns of \(B\) are linearly dependent.
    Solution.
    1. \(q(\xvec) = |B\xvec|^2 = (B\xvec)\cdot(B\xvec) = \xvec\cdot(B^TB\xvec)\) so \(A = B^TB=\begin{bmatrix} 24 \amp -12 \\ -12 \amp 6 \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{.}\)
    2. The maximum value is \(30\) in the direction \(\twovec{2/\sqrt{5}}{-1/\sqrt{5}}\) and the minimum value is \(0\) in the direction \(\twovec{1/\sqrt{5}}{2/\sqrt{5}}\text{.}\)
    3. The minimum value of \(0\) says there is a vector such that \(q(\uvec) = |B\uvec|^2 = 0\text{,}\) which means that \(B\uvec=0\text{.}\) So there is a nonzero vector that is a solution to the homogeneous equations, which implies that the columns of \(B\) are linearly dependent.

    23.2.4.6.

    Answer.
    1. \(A\) is positive definite.
    2. \(Q=\begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{2} \amp 1/\sqrt{3} \amp 1/\sqrt{6} \\ 0 \amp -1/\sqrt{3} \amp 2/\sqrt{6} \\ -1/\sqrt{2} \amp 1/\sqrt{3} \amp 1/\sqrt{6} \\ \end{bmatrix}\) and \(q_A(\xvec) = 9y_1^2 + 6y_2^2 + 3y_3^2\)
    3. The maximum value is \(9\) and the minimum value is \(3\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. The matrix \(A = \begin{bmatrix} 7 \amp -1 \amp -2 \\ -1 \amp 4 \amp -1 \\ -2 \amp -1 \amp 7 \end{bmatrix}\) has eigenvalues \(3\text{,}\) \(6\text{,}\) and \(9\) so \(A\) is positive definite.
    2. \(Q=\begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{2} \amp 1/\sqrt{3} \amp 1/\sqrt{6} \\ 0 \amp -1/\sqrt{3} \amp 2/\sqrt{6} \\ -1/\sqrt{2} \amp 1/\sqrt{3} \amp 1/\sqrt{6} \\ \end{bmatrix} \text{.}\) If \(\yvec=Q^T\xvec\text{,}\) then
      \begin{equation*} q_A(\xvec) = 9y_1^2 + 6y_2^2 + 3y_3^2\text{.} \end{equation*}
    3. The maximum value is \(9\) and the minimum value is \(3\text{.}\)

    23.2.4.7.

    Answer.
    1. \(q(\uvec) = |B\uvec|^2 = \lambda \geq 0\text{.}\)
    2. \(q_{A+B}(\xvec) = q_A(\xvec) + q_B(\xvec) \gt 0\text{.}\)
    3. The eigenvalues of \(A^{-1}\) are the reciprocals of the eigenvalues of \(A\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. The matrix is symmetric because \((B^TB)^T = B^T(B^T)^T = B^TB\text{.}\) If \(\uvec\) is an eigenvector having unit length, then \(q(\uvec) = \uvec\cdot(B^TB\uvec) = \lambda\) and \(q(\uvec) = \uvec\cdot(B^TB\uvec) = (B\uvec)\cdot(B\uvec) = |B\uvec|^2 = \lambda \geq 0\text{.}\)
    2. If \(\xvec\) is a nonzero vector, then \(q_{A+B}(\xvec) = \xvec\cdot((A+B)\xvec) = \xvec\cdot(A\xvec) + \xvec\cdot(B\xvec) = q_A(\xvec) + q_B(\xvec) \gt 0\text{.}\)
    3. In this case, we know that the eigenvalues of \(A\) are all positive. If \(\lambda\) is an eigenvalue of \(A\text{,}\) then \(1/\lambda\) is an eigenvalue of \(A^{-1}\) so \(A^{-1}\) is also positive definite.

    23.2.4.8.

    Answer.
    1. False
    2. True
    3. True
    4. True
    5. True
    Solution.
    1. False. We know that it is neither positive nor negative definite.
    2. True. This implies that \(q_A(\uvec) \geq 3\) for all unit vectors \(\uvec\text{.}\) Then for any other vector \(q_A(\xvec) =q_A(|\xvec|\uvec)= |\xvec|^2 q_A(\uvec) \gt 0\text{.}\)
    3. True. If \(\lambda\) is an eigenvalue with associated unit eigenvector \(\uvec\text{,}\) then
      \begin{equation*} q_C(\uvec) = \uvec\cdot(C\uvec) = \frac1N\uvec\cdot(AA^T\uvec) = \frac1N(A^T\uvec)\cdot(A^T\uvec) = \frac1N|A^T\uvec|^2 \geq 0\text{.} \end{equation*}
    4. True. The matrix \(Q=\begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix}\) is the identity so \(A = QDQ^T = D\text{.}\)
    5. True. In this case, \(A\) and \(B\) are similar so they have the same eigenvalues, all of which are negative.

    23.2.4.9.

    Answer.
    1. \((\sqrt[3]{2}, \sqrt[3]{2})\) is neither a local maximum nor minimum.
    2. \((0,0)\) is neither a local maximum nor minimum. Both \((1,1)\) and \((-1,-1)\) are local minima.
    Solution.
    1. \begin{align*} f_x \amp {}={} y - \frac2{x^2} = 0\\ f_y \amp {}={} x - \frac2{y^2} = 0 \end{align*}
      Also, \(f_{xx} = \frac4{x^3}\text{,}\) \(f_{xy} = 1\text{,}\) and \(f_{yy} = \frac4{y^3}\) so that the Hessian matrix is \(\begin{bmatrix} 1/2 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 1/2 \end{bmatrix}\text{.}\) The eigenvalues are \(-1/2\) and \(3/2\) so this matrix is indefinite and the critical point is neither a local maximum nor minimum.
    2. \begin{align*} f_x \amp {}={} 4x^3 - 4y = 0\\ f_y \amp {}={} 4y^3 - 4x = 0 \end{align*}
      so \(x=y^3\) and \(y=x^3\text{.}\) Therefore, \(x=x^9\) so \(x=y=0\text{,}\) \(1\text{,}\) or \(-1\text{.}\)
      Also, \(f_{xx} = 12{x^2}\text{,}\) \(f_{xy} = -4\text{,}\) and \(f_{yy} = 12{y^2}\) so that the Hessian matrix is \(\begin{bmatrix} 12x^2 \amp -4 \\ -4 \amp 12y^2 \end{bmatrix}\text{.}\)
      At \((0,0)\text{,}\) the Hessian is indefinite so this critical point is neither a local maximum nor minimum. At both \((1,1)\) and \((-1,-1)\text{,}\) it is positive definite so the critical points are local minima.

    23.2.4.10.

    Answer.
    1. The Hessian matrix at that point is \(H=\begin{bmatrix} 12 \amp 4 \amp -4 \\ 4 \amp 12 \amp 4 \\ -4 \amp 4 \amp 12 \end{bmatrix} \)
    2. \(H\) is positive definite.
    3. The critical point is a local minimum.
    Solution.
    1. \begin{align*} f_x \amp {}={} 4x^3 - 4yz = 0\\ f_y \amp {}={} 4y^3 - 4xz = 0\\ f_z \amp {}={} 4z^3 - 4xy = 0 \end{align*}
      and all three equations are satisfied at the point \((-1,1,-1)\text{.}\)
      The Hessian matrix at that point is \(H=\begin{bmatrix} 12 \amp 4 \amp -4 \\ 4 \amp 12 \amp 4 \\ -4 \amp 4 \amp 12 \end{bmatrix} \)
    2. The eigenvalues are \(4\text{,}\) \(16\text{,}\) and \(16\) so \(H\) is positive definite
    3. This implies that the critical point is a local minimum.

    23.3 Principal Component Analysis
    23.3.1 Principal Component Analysis

    Activity 23.3.2.

    Answer.
    1. \(\displaystyle 10\)
    2. \(0\text{,}\) which tells us every data point is in the orthogonal complement of \(\uvec_4\text{.}\)
    3. \(\displaystyle 25\)
    4. \(92\%\) of the variance
    5. \(100\%\) of the variance.
    6. All of the data lies in the \(3\)-dimensional subspace spanned by \(\uvec_1\text{,}\) \(\uvec_1\text{,}\) and \(\uvec_1\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. \(\displaystyle V_{\uvec_2} = \lambda_2 = 10\)
    2. \(V_{\uvec_4} = \lambda_4 = 0\text{,}\) which tells us there is no variance in the \(\uvec_4\) direction. Therefore, when we project onto the line defined by \(\uvec_4\text{,}\) every data point projects to \(\zerovec\) so every data point is in the orthogonal complement of \(\uvec_4\text{.}\)
    3. \(V = V_{\uvec_1} + V_{\uvec_2} + V_{\uvec_3} + V_{\uvec_4} + V_{\uvec_5} = 13+10+2+0+0 = 25\text{.}\)
    4. The variance of the data projected onto this subspace is \(13+10=23\text{,}\) which represents \(23/25=92\%\) of the variance.
    5. Projecting onto this 3-dimensional subspace retains all of the variance.
    6. All of the data lies in the \(3\)-dimensional subspace spanned by \(\uvec_1\text{,}\) \(\uvec_1\text{,}\) and \(\uvec_1\text{.}\)

    Activity 23.3.3.

    Answer.
    1. \(\displaystyle V_{\uvec} = 7885\)
    2. \(\displaystyle V=12195\)
    3. If \(P\) is the matrix of eigenvectors, evaluate \(P^TP\text{.}\)
    4. \(W_1\) retains \(83\%\) of the total variance, and \(W_2\) retains \(98\%\text{.}\)
    5. \(\displaystyle Q=\begin{bmatrix}\uvec_1\amp\uvec_2\end{bmatrix}\)
    6. Because the variance in the \(\uvec_1\) direction is greater than the variance in the \(\uvec_2\) direction.
    Solution.
    1. After constructing the covariance matrix \(C = \frac{1}{100}AA^T\text{,}\) we find that \(V_{\uvec} = \uvec\cdot(C\uvec) = 7885\text{.}\)
    2. The total variance \(V\) is the sum of the eigenvalues of \(C\) so we obtain \(V=12195\text{.}\)
    3. If we obtain \(P\text{,}\) the matrix of eigenvectors, from Sage, computing \(P^TP\) evaluates the dot products between the columns. Since \(P^TP=I\text{,}\) the basis provided by Sage is orthonormal.
    4. Projecting onto \(W_1\text{,}\) we see that \(\lambda_1/V = 0.83\) so \(W_1\) retains about \(83\%\) of the total variance. The subspace \(W_2\) retains \((\lambda_1+\lambda_2)/V=0.98\) or \(98\%\) of the total variance. If we project onto \(W_2\) we lose less than \(2\%\) of the variance.
    5. \(\displaystyle Q=\begin{bmatrix}\uvec_1\amp\uvec_2\end{bmatrix}\)
    6. The plot is wider because the variance in the \(\uvec_1\) direction, which corresponds to the horizontal coordinate, is greater than the variance in the \(\uvec_2\) direction.

    23.3.2 Using Principal Component Analysis

    Activity 23.3.4.

    Answer.
    1. \(\displaystyle 57.5\)
    2. \(78805\text{,}\) \(33946\text{,}\) and \(4093\)
    3. \(\displaystyle 67\%\)
    4. The coordinates are
    5. \(\displaystyle 96\%\)
    6. The coordinates are
    7. Northern Ireland appears to be significantly different from the other three nations.
    8. The average consumption of Alcoholic Drinks will be less than the mean.
    Solution.
    1. Beverages is the second category so this would be the second component of the data_mean vector, which is \(57.5\text{.}\)
    2. The three nonzero eigenvalues are \(78805\text{,}\) \(33946\text{,}\) and \(4093\text{.}\)
    3. The total variance \(V=116844\) is the sum of the eigenvalues so the first principal component accounts for \(\lambda_1/V = 67\%\) of the total variance.
    4. The coordinates are
    5. The first two principal components account for \(96\%\) of the total variance.
    6. The coordinates are
    7. Northern Ireland appears to be significantly different from the other three nations. There are several possible reasons for this, both historical and geographical, that we might explore.
    8. The first component of \(\uvec_1\) is negative. Therefore, if a nation is on the right side of this plot, the average consumption of Alcoholic Drinks will be less than the mean. This can be confirmed by looking at the original data.

    Activity 23.3.5.

    Answer.
    1. \(3.05\text{.}\)
    2. \(4.20\text{,}\) \(0.24\text{,}\) \(0.08\text{,}\) \(0.02\text{.}\)
    3. \(\displaystyle 97.8\%\)
    4. The columns of \(Q\) are for the first two principal components.
    5. Iris setosa and the vector of measurements is \(\fourvec{5.43}{3.81}{1.49}{0.25}\text{.}\)
    6. The petal length is \(3.99\) and the petal width is \(1.29\text{.}\)
    7. The sepal length is \(7.23\) and the petal length is \(6.15\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. The second component of data_mean, which is the one corresponding to sepal width, is \(3.05\text{.}\)
    2. The eigenvalues are \(4.20\text{,}\) \(0.24\text{,}\) \(0.08\text{,}\) and \(0.02\text{.}\)
    3. The first two principal components account for \(97.8\%\) of the variance.
    4. If \(P\) is the matrix whose columns are an orthonormal basis of eigenvectors, then \(Q\) is formed from the first two columns of \(P\text{.}\)
    5. This would most likely belong to Iris setosa. To find its measurements, we evaluate \(-2.5\uvec_1 - 0.75\uvec_2 + \mvec\) where \(\mvec\) is the vector of means. This is the same as \(Q\twovec{-2.5}{-0.75} + \mvec\text{,}\) which gives the vector of measurements \(\fourvec{5.43}{3.81}{1.49}{0.25}\text{.}\)
    6. Subtracting the mean sepal length and sepal width, we have \((-0.19, -0.30)\text{.}\) Then the first two components of \(c_1\uvec_1+c_2\uvec_2 = Q\twovec{c_1}{c_2} = \twovec{-0.19}{-0.30}\text{.}\) This gives \((c_1, c_2) = (0.18, 0.40)\text{.}\) This looks like an Iris versicolor. As in the previous part, we can now find the petal length to be \(3.99\) and the petal width to be \(1.29\text{.}\)
    7. Using the same approach as the last part, we find \((c_1,c_2)=(2.90, -0.53)\text{,}\) which gives a sepal length of \(7.23\) and a petal length of \(6.15\text{.}\) Most likely, this flower belongs to Iris virginica.

    23.3.4 Exercises

    23.3.4.1.

    Answer.
    1. \(149\) for the first dataset and \(101\) for the second
    2. \(50.3\%\) and \(99.0\%\)
    3. The points in the second set are clustered very close to a line.
    Solution.
    1. For the first dataset, the total variance is \(75+75 = 149\) while the second dataset has a total variance of \(100+1=101\text{.}\)
    2. In the first dataset, the first principal component represents \(75/149=50.3\%\) of the variance compared to \(100/101=99.0\%\) in the second dataset.
    3. The points in the first dataset are scattered almost uniformly around the origin. In the second dataset, they are clustered very close to the line defined by the vector \(\twovec{-1/\sqrt{2}}{1/\sqrt{2}}\text{.}\)

    23.3.4.2.

    Answer.
    1. \(\displaystyle 97\%\)
    2. \(\twovec{25.4}{8.16}\text{.}\)
    3. \(\threevec{9.7}{-22.3}{3.7}\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. The eigenvalues are \(732\text{,}\) \(114\text{,}\) and \(24\) so the fraction of variance represented by the first two principal components is \((732+114)/(732+114+24) = 97\%\)
    2. Suppose \(\xvec\) is this data point and \(\mvec\) the vector of means. If \(Q\) is the \(2\times3\) matrix whose columns are the first two principal components, then we find \(Q.T(\xvec-\mvec) = \twovec{25.4}{8.16}\text{.}\)
    3. We find \(Q\twovec{12}{-25} + \mvec = \threevec{9.7}{-22.3}{3.7}\text{.}\)

    23.3.4.3.

    Answer.
    1. The variances are \(V_{\uvec_1} = 1.62\) and \(V_{\uvec_2} = 0\text{.}\)
    2. \(\displaystyle 1.62\)
    3. All of the data lies on a line
    Solution.
    1. We find that \(\uvec_1 = \twovec{-0.45}{-0.89}\) and \(\uvec_2=\twovec{-0.89}{0.44}\text{.}\) The variances are \(V_{\uvec_1} = 1.62\) and \(V_{\uvec_2} = 0\text{.}\)
    2. The total variance is \(1.62\text{.}\)
    3. All of the data lies on the line defined by \(\uvec_1\text{.}\)

    23.3.4.4.

    Answer.
    1. True
    2. False
    3. False
    Solution.
    1. True. The variance of the projected data points is \(V_{\uvec_3} = \uvec_3\cdot(C\uvec_3) = \lambda_3\text{.}\)
    2. False. If we project onto a subspace that retains less than all the variance, then we are losing information about the data in the directions orthogonal to the subspace.
    3. False. They will lie on the plane spanned by the first two principal components.

    23.3.4.5.

    Answer.
    1. The petal length is the most signficant and the sepal width is the least.
    2. Iris setosa has a below average petal length and appears overall smaller.
    3. Iris versicolor
    Solution.
    1. The first principal component is \(\uvec_1 = \fourvec{0.36}{-0.08}{0.85}{0.36}\text{.}\) If we move in the \(\uvec_1\) direction, each component describes how we move away from the mean of that measurement. The most important component is the third one, which corresponds to petal length, while the second component, corresponding to sepal width, is least signficant. Of the four measurements, there is the most variance in petal length.
    2. To reach an Iris setosa sample, we multiply \(\uvec_1\) by a negative number. This says that the petal length, the most signficant component of \(\uvec_1\) will be below the mean for Iris setosa. The sepal length and petal width will also be below the mean. Basically, the Iris setosa would appear to be smaller overall.
    3. Iris versicolor would appear to be closest to average since the points are closest to the origin in the \(\uvec_1\)-\(\uvec_2\) plane.

    23.3.4.6.

    Answer.
    1. \(2.7\text{,}\) \(0.8\text{,}\) \(0.4\text{,}\) \(0.1\text{.}\)
    2. \(\displaystyle 88\%\)
    3. \(B=Q^TA\) where the columns of \(Q\) are the first two principal components.
    4. Gentoo penguins have a larger body mass.
    5. These measurements seem larger for the Chinstrap penguins.
    6. The male Gentoo have a higher body mass.
    Solution.
    1. The eigenvalues are \(2.7\text{,}\) \(0.8\text{,}\) \(0.4\text{,}\) and \(0.1\text{.}\)
    2. The first two principal components retain \(88\%\) of the total variance.
    3. \(B=Q^TA\) where the columns of \(Q\) are the first two principal components.
    4. Gentoo penguins have a larger body mass because the fourth component, which corresponds to body mass, of \(\uvec_1\) is negative and the Gentoo penguins are represented by \(c_1\uvec_1\) where \(c_1\) is negative.
    5. These measurements seem larger for the Chinstrap penguins because the first two components of \(\uvec_2\) are positive.
    6. The male Gentoo lie further to the left, which means they have a higher body mass.

    23.4 Singular Value Decompositions
    23.4.1 Finding singular value decompositions

    Activity 23.4.2.

    Answer.
    1. \(\sigma_1=3\text{,}\) \(\vvec_1 = \twovec{1/\sqrt{2}}{1/\sqrt{2}}\)
    2. \(\sigma_2=1\text{,}\) \(\vvec_1 = \twovec{1/\sqrt{2}}{-1/\sqrt{2}}\)
    3. The maximum value of \(q_G(\xvec)\) is \(9\text{,}\) which occurs in the direction \(\twovec{1/\sqrt{2}}{1/\sqrt{2}}\text{.}\) The minimum value of \(q_G(\xvec)\) is \(1\text{,}\) which occurs in the direction \(\twovec{1/\sqrt{2}}{-1/\sqrt{2}}\text{.}\)
    4. \(\sigma_1 = \sqrt{9} = 3\) and \(\sigma_2 = \sqrt{1} = 1\)
    5. \(\vvec_1\) agrees with the direction in which \(q_G(\xvec)\) has its maximum value. The corresponding fact is true for \(\vvec_2\text{.}\)
    6. \(\uvec_1=\twovec{1/\sqrt{2}}{-1/\sqrt{2}}\) and \(\uvec_2 = \twovec{-1/\sqrt{2}}{-1/\sqrt{2}}\)
    7. \(AV = \begin{bmatrix} A\vvec_1 \amp A\vvec_2 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \sigma_1\uvec_1 \amp \sigma_2\uvec_2 \end{bmatrix} = U\Sigma\text{.}\)
    8. Since \(V\) is an orthogonal matrix, we have \(A = AVV^T = U\Sigma V^T\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. The maximum value of \(l_A(\xvec)\) is \(\sigma_1=3\text{,}\) which occurs at \(\vvec_1 = \twovec{1/\sqrt{2}}{1/\sqrt{2}}\text{.}\)
    2. The minimum value of \(l_A(\xvec)\) is \(\sigma_2=1\text{,}\) which occurs at \(\vvec_1 = \twovec{1/\sqrt{2}}{-1/\sqrt{2}}\text{.}\)
    3. \(G = \begin{bmatrix} 5 \amp 4 \\ 4 \amp 5 \\ \end{bmatrix} = QDQ^T\) where
      \begin{equation*} D = \begin{bmatrix} 9 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} Q = \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{2} \amp 1/\sqrt{2} \\ 1/\sqrt{2} \amp -1/\sqrt{2} \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{.} \end{equation*}
      The maximum value of \(q_G(\xvec)\) is therefore \(\lambda_1=9\text{,}\) which occurs in the direction \(\twovec{1/\sqrt{2}}{1/\sqrt{2}}\text{.}\) The minimum value of \(q_G(\xvec)\) is \(\lambda_2=1\text{,}\) which occurs in the direction \(\twovec{1/\sqrt{2}}{-1/\sqrt{2}}\text{.}\)
    4. We see that \(\sigma_1 = \sqrt{\lambda_1} = \sqrt{9} = 3\) and \(\sigma_2 = \sqrt{\lambda_2} = \sqrt{1} = 1\text{.}\)
    5. We also see that \(\vvec_1\text{,}\) the first right singular vector, agrees with the direction in which \(q_G(\xvec)\) has its maximum value. The corresponding fact is true for \(\vvec_2\text{.}\)
    6. We find that \(\uvec_1=\twovec{1/\sqrt{2}}{-1/\sqrt{2}}\) and \(\uvec_2 = \twovec{-1/\sqrt{2}}{-1/\sqrt{2}}\text{.}\)
    7. \(AV = \begin{bmatrix} A\vvec_1 \amp A\vvec_2 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \sigma_1\uvec_1 \amp \sigma_2\uvec_2 \end{bmatrix} = U\Sigma\text{.}\)
    8. Since \(V\) is an orthogonal matrix, we have \(A = AVV^T = U\Sigma V^T\text{.}\)

    Activity 23.4.3.

    Answer.
    1. \(G\) can be orthogonally diagaonalized with
      \begin{equation*} D = \begin{bmatrix} 3 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} Q = \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{3} \amp 1/\sqrt{2} \amp 1/\sqrt{6} \\ 1/\sqrt{3} \amp 0 \amp -2/\sqrt{6} \\ 1/\sqrt{3} \amp -1/\sqrt{2} \amp 1/\sqrt{6} \end{bmatrix}. \end{equation*}
    2. \(\sigma_1 = \sqrt{3}\text{,}\) \(\sigma_2 = \sqrt{2}\text{,}\) and \(\sigma_3 = 0\text{.}\) The three right singular vectors \(\vvec_i\) are the columns of \(Q\text{.}\)
    3. \(\uvec_1 = \twovec01\) and \(\uvec_2 = \twovec10\)
    4. We have
      \begin{equation*} U = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} V = \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{3} \amp 1/\sqrt{2} \amp 1/\sqrt{6} \\ 1/\sqrt{3} \amp 0 \amp -2/\sqrt{6} \\ 1/\sqrt{3} \amp -1/\sqrt{2} \amp 1/\sqrt{6} \end{bmatrix}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    5. With \(\Sigma = \begin{bmatrix} \sqrt{3} \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp \sqrt{2} \amp 0 \end{bmatrix}\text{,}\) we see that \(A=U\Sigma V^T\text{.}\)
    6. \(A^T=(U\Sigma V^T)^T = V\Sigma^T U^T\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. Constructing the Gram matrix of \(A\) gives the \(3\times3\) matrix
      \begin{equation*} G = \begin{bmatrix} 2 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 2 \end{bmatrix}\text{,} \end{equation*}
      which can be orthogonally diagaonalized with
      \begin{equation*} D = \begin{bmatrix} 3 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} Q = \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{3} \amp 1/\sqrt{2} \amp 1/\sqrt{6} \\ 1/\sqrt{3} \amp 0 \amp -2/\sqrt{6} \\ 1/\sqrt{3} \amp -1/\sqrt{2} \amp 1/\sqrt{6} \end{bmatrix}. \end{equation*}
    2. This tells us that \(\sigma_1 = \sqrt{3}\text{,}\) \(\sigma_2 = \sqrt{2}\text{,}\) and \(\sigma_3 = 0\text{.}\) The three right singular vectors \(\vvec_i\) are the columns of \(Q\text{.}\) Since these vectors are 3-dimensional, it follows that the matrix \(V\) will be \(3\times3\text{.}\)
    3. We have
      \begin{align*} A\vvec_1 \amp = \twovec{0}{\sqrt{3}} = \sqrt{3} \twovec01\\ A\vvec_2 \amp = \twovec{\sqrt{2}}0 = \sqrt{2} \twovec10 \end{align*}
      showing that
      \begin{equation*} \uvec_1 = \twovec01, \hspace{24pt} \uvec_2 = \twovec10. \end{equation*}
      Notice that \(A\vvec_3 = \zerovec\) so it is not possible to find a vector \(\uvec_3\) in this way.
      The left singular vectors are 2-dimensional so \(U\) will be a \(2\times2\) matrix.
    4. We have
      \begin{equation*} U = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} V = \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{3} \amp 1/\sqrt{2} \amp 1/\sqrt{6} \\ 1/\sqrt{3} \amp 0 \amp -2/\sqrt{6} \\ 1/\sqrt{3} \amp -1/\sqrt{2} \amp 1/\sqrt{6} \end{bmatrix}\text{.} \end{equation*}
      The matrix \(U\) is \(2\times2\) since there are two rows in \(A\) and \(V\) is \(3\times3\) since there are three columns in \(A\)
    5. With \(\Sigma = \begin{bmatrix} \sqrt{3} \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp \sqrt{2} \amp 0 \end{bmatrix}\text{,}\) we see that \(A=U\Sigma V^T\text{.}\)
    6. If \(A = U\Sigma V^T\text{,}\) then \(A^T=(U\Sigma V^T)^T = V\Sigma^T U^T\text{.}\)

    23.4.2 The structure of singular value decompositions

    Activity 23.4.4.

    Answer.
    1. \(A\) is \(4\times3\)
    2. \(c_1 = 2\text{,}\) \(c_2 = 4\text{,}\) and there is no condition on \(c_3\)
    3. \(c_1 = 0\text{,}\) \(c_2 = 0\text{,}\) and there is no condition on \(c_3\)
    4. \(\vvec_3\) forms a basis for \(\nul(A)\text{.}\)
    5. \(\uvec_1\) and \(\uvec_2\) form a basis for \(\col(A)\text{.}\)
    6. \(\rank(A) = 2\text{,}\) which is the number of nonzero singular values.
    Solution.
    1. The shape of \(A\) is the same as \(\Sigma\) so \(A\) is \(4\times3\text{;}\) that is, \(A\) has \(4\) rows and \(3\) columns.
    2. We have \(A\xvec=20c_1\uvec_1 + 5c_2\uvec_2 = 40\uvec_1 + 20\uvec_2\text{.}\) This means that \(c_1 = 2\text{,}\) \(c_2 = 4\text{,}\) and \(c_3\) could be anything. Since there is no condition on \(c_3\text{,}\) there are infinitely many solutions.
    3. We have \(A\xvec=20c_1\uvec_1 + 5c_2\uvec_2 = \zerovec\text{,}\) which says that \(c_1 = 0\text{,}\) \(c_2 = 0\text{,}\) and \(c_3\) could be anything.
    4. Any vector \(\xvec\) in \(\nul(A)\) satisfies \(A\xvec = \zerovec\) and must have the form \(\xvec = c_3\vvec_3\text{.}\) Therefore, \(\vvec_3\) forms a basis for \(\nul(A)\text{.}\)
    5. The vector \(\bvec\) is in \(\col(A)\) only if \(\bvec\) is a linear combination of \(\uvec_1\) and \(\uvec_2\text{.}\) Therefore, \(\uvec_1\) and \(\uvec_2\) form a basis for \(\col(A)\text{.}\)
    6. \(\rank(A) = 2\text{,}\) which is the number of nonzero singular values.

    23.4.3 Reduced singular value decompositions

    Activity 23.4.5.

    Answer.
    1. \(A\) is a \(4\times3\) matrix and \(\rank(A) = 2\)
    2. \(\uvec_1\) and \(\uvec_2\) form an orthonormal basis for \(\col(A)\text{,}\) and \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2\) form an orthonormal basis for \(\nul(A)\text{.}\)
    3. Notice that
      \begin{equation*} U\Sigma = \begin{bmatrix} \uvec_1 \amp \uvec_2 \amp \uvec_3 \amp \uvec_4 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 18 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 4 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 18\uvec_1 \amp 4\uvec_2 \amp \zerovec \end{bmatrix} \end{equation*}
    4. Notice that
      \begin{equation*} \begin{bmatrix} 18 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 4 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix}V^T = \begin{bmatrix} 18 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 4 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} \vvec_1^T \\ \vvec_2^T \\ \vvec_3^T \end{bmatrix} \end{equation*}
    5. Put together the previous parts to see that \(A=U_r\Sigma_rV_r^T\) where
      \begin{equation*} U_r = \begin{bmatrix} \uvec_1 \amp \uvec_2 \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} \Sigma_r = \begin{bmatrix} 18 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 4 \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} V_r = \begin{bmatrix} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \end{bmatrix}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    Solution.
    1. \(A\) is a \(4\times3\) matrix and \(\rank(A) = 2\) because there are two nonzero singular values.
    2. \(\uvec_1\) and \(\uvec_2\) form an orthonormal basis for \(\col(A)\text{,}\) and \(\vvec_1\) and \(\vvec_2\) form an orthonormal basis for \(\nul(A)\text{.}\)
    3. Notice that
      \begin{equation*} U\Sigma = \begin{bmatrix} \uvec_1 \amp \uvec_2 \amp \uvec_3 \amp \uvec_4 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 18 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 4 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 18\uvec_1 \amp 4\uvec_2 \amp \zerovec \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \uvec_1 \amp \uvec_2 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 18 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 4 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    4. Notice that
      \begin{equation*} \begin{bmatrix} 18 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 4 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix}V^T = \begin{bmatrix} 18 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 4 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} \vvec_1^T \\ \vvec_2^T \\ \vvec_3^T \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 18 \vvec_1^T \\ 4 \vvec_2^T \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 18 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 4 \\ \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \end{bmatrix}^T\text{.} \end{equation*}
    5. Put together the previous parts to see that \(A=U_r\Sigma_rV_r^T\) where
      \begin{equation*} U_r = \begin{bmatrix} \uvec_1 \amp \uvec_2 \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} \Sigma_r = \begin{bmatrix} 18 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 4 \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} V_r = \begin{bmatrix} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \end{bmatrix}\text{.} \end{equation*}

    23.4.5 Exercises

    23.4.5.1.

    Answer.
    1. \(G = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 2 \amp 1 \\ 2 \amp 5 \amp 0 \\ 1 \amp 0 \amp 5 \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{,}\) which has
      \begin{equation*} D=\begin{bmatrix} 6 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 5 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} Q = \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{6} \amp 0 \amp 5/\sqrt{30} \\ 2/\sqrt{6} \amp 1/\sqrt{5} \amp -2/\sqrt{30} \\ 1/\sqrt{6} \amp -2/\sqrt{5} \amp -1/\sqrt{30} \\ \end{bmatrix} \end{equation*}
      \(\sigma_1 = \sqrt{6}\) and \(\sigma_2=\sqrt{5}\text{.}\) The right singular vectors are the columns of \(Q\text{.}\)
    2. \(\uvec_1 = \twovec10\) and \(\uvec_2=\twovec0{-1}\text{.}\)
    3. \begin{equation*} U=\begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -1 \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} \Sigma = \begin{bmatrix} \sqrt{6} \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp \sqrt{5} \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} V = \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{6} \amp 0 \amp 5/\sqrt{30} \\ 2/\sqrt{6} \amp 1/\sqrt{5} \amp -2/\sqrt{30} \\ 1/\sqrt{6} \amp -2/\sqrt{5} \amp -1/\sqrt{30} \\ \end{bmatrix} \end{equation*}
    4. \(\rank(A)=2\) and \(\col(A)=\real^2\text{.}\)
    5. \(\displaystyle \vvec_3 = \threevec{5/\sqrt{30}}{-2/\sqrt{30}}{-1/\sqrt{30}}\)
    Solution.
    1. \(G = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 2 \amp 1 \\ 2 \amp 5 \amp 0 \\ 1 \amp 0 \amp 5 \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{,}\) which has
      \begin{equation*} D=\begin{bmatrix} 6 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 5 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} Q = \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{6} \amp 0 \amp 5/\sqrt{30} \\ 2/\sqrt{6} \amp 1/\sqrt{5} \amp -2/\sqrt{30} \\ 1/\sqrt{6} \amp -2/\sqrt{5} \amp -1/\sqrt{30} \\ \end{bmatrix} \end{equation*}
      This says that \(\sigma_1 = \sqrt{6}\) and \(\sigma_2=\sqrt{5}\text{.}\) The right singular vectors are the columns of \(Q\text{.}\)
    2. \(\uvec_1 = \twovec10\) and \(\uvec_2=\twovec0{-1}\text{.}\)
    3. \begin{equation*} U=\begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -1 \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} \Sigma = \begin{bmatrix} \sqrt{6} \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp \sqrt{5} \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} V = \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{6} \amp 0 \amp 5/\sqrt{30} \\ 2/\sqrt{6} \amp 1/\sqrt{5} \amp -2/\sqrt{30} \\ 1/\sqrt{6} \amp -2/\sqrt{5} \amp -1/\sqrt{30} \\ \end{bmatrix} \end{equation*}
    4. \(\rank(A)=2\) because there are two nonzero singular values. Therefore, \(\col(A)\) is 2-dimensional and so \(\col(A)=\real^2\text{.}\)
    5. \(\displaystyle \vvec_3 = \threevec{5/\sqrt{30}}{-2/\sqrt{30}}{-1/\sqrt{30}}\)

    23.4.5.2.

    Answer.
    1. \(\displaystyle \begin{bmatrix} 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -8 \\ \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \amp 1 \\ -1 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 8 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix}^T\)
    2. \(\displaystyle \begin{bmatrix} 2 \amp 3 \\ 0 \amp 2 \\ \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 2/\sqrt{5} \amp 1/\sqrt{5} \\ 1/\sqrt{5} \amp -2/\sqrt{5} \\ \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 4 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{5} \amp 2/\sqrt{5} \\ 2/\sqrt{5} \amp -1/\sqrt{5} \\ \end{bmatrix}^T\)
    3. \(\displaystyle \begin{bmatrix} 4 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 4 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix}^T\)
    4. \(\displaystyle \begin{bmatrix} 4 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 2 \\ \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 4 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix}^T\)
    Solution.
    1. \(\displaystyle \begin{bmatrix} 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -8 \\ \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \amp 1 \\ -1 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 8 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix}^T\)
    2. \(\displaystyle \begin{bmatrix} 2 \amp 3 \\ 0 \amp 2 \\ \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 2/\sqrt{5} \amp 1/\sqrt{5} \\ 1/\sqrt{5} \amp -2/\sqrt{5} \\ \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 4 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{5} \amp 2/\sqrt{5} \\ 2/\sqrt{5} \amp -1/\sqrt{5} \\ \end{bmatrix}^T\)
    3. \(\displaystyle \begin{bmatrix} 4 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 4 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix}^T\)
    4. \(\displaystyle \begin{bmatrix} 4 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 2 \\ \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 4 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix}^T\)

    23.4.5.3.

    Answer.
    1. \(\displaystyle \begin{bmatrix} 2 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 2 \\ \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{2} \amp 1/\sqrt{2} \\ 1/\sqrt{2} \amp -1/\sqrt{2} \\ \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 3 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{2} \amp 1/\sqrt{2} \\ 1/\sqrt{2} \amp -1/\sqrt{2} \\ \end{bmatrix}^T\)
    2. The singular values \(\sigma_i = \lambda_i\text{,}\) the eigenvalues of \(A\) and the right singular vectors are eigenvectors of \(A\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. \(\begin{bmatrix} 2 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 2 \\ \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{2} \amp 1/\sqrt{2} \\ 1/\sqrt{2} \amp -1/\sqrt{2} \\ \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 3 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{2} \amp 1/\sqrt{2} \\ 1/\sqrt{2} \amp -1/\sqrt{2} \\ \end{bmatrix}^T\)
      Since \(U=V\text{,}\) this is an orthogonal diagonalization.
    2. In this case, \(G=A^TA = A^2\text{.}\) If \(\lambda_i\geq 0\) are the eigenvalues of \(A\) and \(\vvec_i\) the associated eigenvectors, then \(\lambda_i^2\) is an eigenvalue of \(G\) with associated eigenvector \(\vvec_i\text{.}\) Therefore, \(\sigma_i = \sqrt{\lambda_i^2} = \lambda_i\) and the right singular vectors are \(\vvec_i\text{.}\)
      The left singular vectors are \(A\vvec_i = \sigma_i\uvec_i = \lambda_i\vvec_i\) so the left singular vectors are the same as the right singular vectors.

    23.4.5.4.

    Answer.
    1. \(\displaystyle 4\times 3\)
    2. \(\displaystyle 2\)
    3. A basis for \(\col(A)\) is formed by the first two columns of \(U\text{.}\) A basis for \(\nul(A^T)\) is formed by the last two columns of \(U\text{.}\) A basis for \(\col(A^T)\) is formed by the first two columns of \(V\text{.}\) A basis for \(\nul(A)\) is formed by the last column of \(V\text{.}\)
    4. \(\fourvec{1.20}{0.16}{0.95}{-1.49}\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. \(A\) is \(4\times 3\)
    2. \(\displaystyle \rank(A) = 2\)
    3. A basis for \(\col(A)\) is formed by the first two columns of \(U\text{.}\) A basis for \(\nul(A^T)\) is formed by the last two columns of \(U\text{.}\) A basis for \(\col(A^T)\) is formed by the first two columns of \(V\text{.}\) A basis for \(\nul(A)\) is formed by the last column of \(V\text{.}\)
    4. Form \(Q = \begin{bmatrix} \uvec_1 \amp \uvec_2\end{bmatrix}\) and find \(QQ^T\bvec = \fourvec{1.20}{0.16}{0.95}{-1.49}\text{.}\)

    23.4.5.5.

    Answer.
    1. \(\Sigma = \begin{bmatrix} 3 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp \sqrt{7} \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix}\) and \(V = \begin{bmatrix} 2/\sqrt{6} \amp 0 \amp 1/\sqrt{3} \\ 1/\sqrt{6} \amp 1/\sqrt{2} \amp -1/\sqrt{3} \\ -1/\sqrt{6} \amp 1/\sqrt{2} \amp 1/\sqrt{3} \\ \end{bmatrix}\)
    2. \(\displaystyle \rank(A)=2\)
    3. \(\uvec_1 =\threevec{1/\sqrt{6}}{2/\sqrt{6}}{-1/\sqrt{6}}\) and \(\uvec_1 =\threevec{-1/\sqrt{14}}{2/\sqrt{14}}{3/\sqrt{14}}\)
    4. \(\displaystyle U=\begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{6} \amp -1/\sqrt{14} \amp 4/\sqrt{21} \\ 2/\sqrt{6} \amp 2/\sqrt{14} \amp -1/\sqrt{21} \\ -1/\sqrt{6} \amp 3/\sqrt{14} \amp 2/\sqrt{21} \\ \end{bmatrix}\)
    5. The third column of \(V\) forms a basis for \(\nul(A)\) while the first two columns of \(U\) form a basis for \(\col(A)\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. \(\Sigma = \begin{bmatrix} 3 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp \sqrt{7} \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix}\) and \(V = \begin{bmatrix} 2/\sqrt{6} \amp 0 \amp 1/\sqrt{3} \\ 1/\sqrt{6} \amp 1/\sqrt{2} \amp -1/\sqrt{3} \\ -1/\sqrt{6} \amp 1/\sqrt{2} \amp 1/\sqrt{3} \\ \end{bmatrix}\)
    2. \(\displaystyle \rank(A)=2\)
    3. \(\uvec_1 =\threevec{1/\sqrt{6}}{2/\sqrt{6}}{-1/\sqrt{6}}\) and \(\uvec_1 =\threevec{-1/\sqrt{14}}{2/\sqrt{14}}{3/\sqrt{14}}\)
    4. \(\uvec_3 = \threevec{4/\sqrt{21}}{-1/\sqrt{21}}{2/\sqrt{21}} \) so that \(U=\begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{6} \amp -1/\sqrt{14} \amp 4/\sqrt{21} \\ 2/\sqrt{6} \amp 2/\sqrt{14} \amp -1/\sqrt{21} \\ -1/\sqrt{6} \amp 3/\sqrt{14} \amp 2/\sqrt{21} \\ \end{bmatrix}\)
    5. The third column of \(V\) forms a basis for \(\nul(A)\) while the first two columns of \(U\) form a basis for \(\col(A)\text{.}\)

    23.4.5.6.

    Answer.
    1. From the previous problem, we have
      \begin{equation*} U=\begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{6} \amp 0 \amp 5/\sqrt{30} \\ 2/\sqrt{6} \amp 1/\sqrt{5} \amp -2/\sqrt{30} \\ 1/\sqrt{6} \amp -2/\sqrt{5} \amp -1/\sqrt{30} \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} \Sigma = \begin{bmatrix} \sqrt{6} \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp \sqrt{5} \\ 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} V = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -1 \\ \end{bmatrix} \end{equation*}
    2. \(\displaystyle \rank(B)=2\)
    3. \(\displaystyle \bhat = \threevec226\)
    4. \(\xhat =\twovec22\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. From the previous problem, we have
      \begin{equation*} U=\begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{6} \amp 0 \amp 5/\sqrt{30} \\ 2/\sqrt{6} \amp 1/\sqrt{5} \amp -2/\sqrt{30} \\ 1/\sqrt{6} \amp -2/\sqrt{5} \amp -1/\sqrt{30} \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} \Sigma = \begin{bmatrix} \sqrt{6} \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp \sqrt{5} \\ 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} V = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -1 \\ \end{bmatrix} \end{equation*}
    2. \(\rank(B)=2\text{.}\) A basis for \(\col(B)\) consists of the first two columns of \(U\) and a basis for \(\col(A)^\perp\) consists of the third column of \(U\text{.}\)
    3. If \(Q\) is the matrix consisting of the first two columns of \(U\text{,}\) then \(\bhat = QQ^T\bvec = \threevec226\text{.}\) Then \(\bperp = \bvec - \bhat = \threevec{-5}21\text{.}\)
    4. We solve the equation \(B\xvec = \bhat = \threevec226\) to find \(\xhat =\twovec22\text{.}\)

    23.4.5.7.

    Answer.
    1. \(\displaystyle A^{-1} = V\Sigma^{-1}U^T\)
    2. All the singular values are nonzero.
    3. They are reciprocals of one another.
    4. The left singular vectors of \(A\) are the right singular vectors of \(A^{-1}\) and vice versa.
    Solution.
    1. \(\displaystyle A^{-1} = (U\Sigma^{-1}V^T)^{-1} = V\Sigma^{-1}U^T\)
    2. We need \(\rank(A)=m\) so all the singular values are nonzero. This means that the square matrix \(\Sigma\) is invertible.
    3. If \(\sigma_i\) are the singular values for \(A\text{,}\) then \(1/\sigma_i\) are the singular values for \(A^{-1}\text{.}\)
    4. The left singular vectors of \(A\) are the right singular vectors of \(A^{-1}\) and vice versa.

    23.4.5.8.

    Answer.
    1. \(\displaystyle \det(Q^TQ) = \det(Q^T)\det(Q)=\det(I) \)
    2. \(\displaystyle |\det(A) = |\det(U)|~|\det(\Sigma)|~|\det(V^T)|\)
    3. All the singular values are nonzero.
    Solution.
    1. \(\det(Q^TQ) = \det(Q^T)\det(Q)=(\det(Q))^2 = \det(I) = 1\) so \(\det(Q) = \pm 1\text{.}\)
    2. \(|\det(A) = |\det(U)|~|\det(\Sigma)|~|\det(V^T)| = |\det(\Sigma)|\text{,}\) which equals the product of the singular values.
    3. If \(A\) is invertible, then \(\det(A) \neq 0\text{,}\) which says that all the singular values are nonzero.

    23.4.5.9.

    Answer.
    1. If \(\vvec\) is an eigenvector of \(G\) with eigenvalue \(\lambda\text{,}\) then \(\vvec\cdot(G\vvec) = \lambda\vvec\cdot\vvec\)
    2. If \(A\) is symmetric, then \(G=A^TA = A^2\text{.}\)
    3. If \(\lambda\) is an eigenvalue of \(A\text{,}\) then \(\sigma^2 = \lambda^2\) is an eigenvalue of \(G\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. If \(\vvec\) is an eigenvector of \(G\) with eigenvalue \(\lambda\text{,}\) then \(\vvec\cdot(G\vvec) = \lambda\vvec\cdot\vvec= \lambda|\vvec|^2 = |A\vvec|^2\) so \(\lambda\geq0\text{.}\)
    2. If \(A\) is symmetric, then \(G=A^TA = A^2\text{.}\) Then if \(A\vvec=\lambda \vvec\text{,}\) it follows that \(G\vvec = \lambda^2\vvec\text{.}\)
    3. If \(\lambda\) is an eigenvalue of \(A\text{,}\) then \(\sigma^2 = \lambda^2\) is an eigenvalue of \(G\text{.}\) Then \(\sigma = |\lambda|\text{.}\)

    23.4.5.10.

    Answer.
    1. True
    2. False
    3. False
    4. True
    5. True
    Solution.
    1. True. Remembering that \(U\) is orthogonal, we have \(G = A^TA=(U\Sigma V^T)^T(U\Sigma V^T) = V\Sigma^T U^T U \Sigma V^T = V (\Sigma^T\Sigma)V^T\text{.}\) Since \(\Sigma^T\Sigma\) is diagonal and \(V\) is orthogonal, this is an orthogonal diagonalization.
    2. False. They form a basis for \(\col(A^T)\text{.}\)
    3. False. The singular values are always nonnegative whereas the eigenvalues can take on any sign.
    4. True. This would say that \(\nul(A) = \{\zerovec\}\text{,}\) which implies that the columns are linearly independent.
    5. True. The Gram matrix is always symmetric and hence orthogonally diagonalizable.

    23.4.5.11.

    Answer.
    1. Every column of \(\Sigma\) has a nonzero singular value.
    2. Every row of \(\Sigma\) has a nonzero singular value.
    3. Then \(\Sigma\) is a square matrix and every singular value is nonzero.
    Solution.
    1. If the columns are linearly independent, then \(\nul(A)=\{\zerovec\}\text{,}\) which means that the rank equals the number of columns. Therefore, every column of \(\Sigma\) has a nonzero singular value.
    2. In the columns span \(\real^m\text{,}\) then \(\col(A)=\real^m\text{,}\) which says that the rank equals the number of rows. Therefore, every row of \(\Sigma\) has a nonzero singular value.
    3. Then \(\Sigma\) is a square matrix and every singular value is nonzero.

    23.5 Using Singular Value Decompositions
    23.5.1 Least-squares problems

    Activity 23.5.2.

    Answer.
    1. \(\sigma_1 = 2.67\) and \(\sigma_2 = 0.92\text{.}\)
    2. \(\rank(A) = 2\) and the first two columns of \(U\) form an orthonormal basis for \(\col(A)\text{.}\)
    3. We have
      \begin{equation*} U_r = \begin{bmatrix} -0.22 \amp 0.89 \\ -0.52 \amp 0.25 \\ -0.83 \amp -0.39 \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} \Sigma_r = \begin{bmatrix} 2.7 \amp 0.00 \\ 0.00 \amp 0.92 \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} V_r = \begin{bmatrix} -0.58 \amp 0.81 \\ -0.81 \amp -0.58 \end{bmatrix}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    4. The columns of \(U_r\) form an orthonormal basis for \(\col(A)\text{.}\)
    5. \(\displaystyle \bhat=U_rU_r^T\bvec\)
    6. \(\displaystyle V_r^TV_r = I\)
    7. \(\displaystyle \xhat=\twovec{-0.83}{3.50}\)
    Solution.
    1. The singular values are \(\sigma_1 = 2.67\) and \(\sigma_2 = 0.92\text{.}\)
    2. There are two nonzero singular values so \(\rank(A) = 2\text{.}\) The first two columns of \(U\) form an orthonormal basis for \(\col(A)\text{.}\)
    3. We have
      \begin{equation*} U_r = \begin{bmatrix} -0.22 \amp 0.89 \\ -0.52 \amp 0.25 \\ -0.83 \amp -0.39 \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} \Sigma_r = \begin{bmatrix} 2.7 \amp 0.00 \\ 0.00 \amp 0.92 \end{bmatrix},\hspace{24pt} V_r = \begin{bmatrix} -0.58 \amp 0.81 \\ -0.81 \amp -0.58 \end{bmatrix}\text{.} \end{equation*}
    4. The columns of \(U_r\) form an orthonormal basis for \(\col(A)\text{.}\)
    5. Since \(\bhat=U_rU_r^T\bvec\text{,}\) we obtain the equation \(A\xhat = U_rU_r^T\bvec\text{.}\)
    6. \(V_r^TV_r = I\) since this product computes the dot products of the columns.
    7. We have the equation \(A\xhat = U_rU_r^T\bvec\text{,}\) which gives
      \begin{equation*} \begin{aligned} A\xhat \amp = U_rU_r^T\bvec \\ U_r\Sigma_rV_r^T\xhat \amp = U_rU_r^T\bvec \\ \Sigma_rV_r^T\xhat \amp = U_r^T\bvec \\ V_r^T\xhat \amp = \Sigma_r^{-1}U_r^T\bvec \\ \xhat \amp = V_r\Sigma_r^{-1}U_r^T\bvec \\ \end{aligned} \end{equation*}

    23.5.2 Rank \(k\) approximations

    Activity 23.5.3.

    Answer.
    1. \(A = \begin{bmatrix} 156 \amp 96 \amp -144 \amp -104 \\ 144 \amp 104 \amp -156 \amp -96 \\ 104 \amp 144 \amp -96 \amp -156 \\ 96 \amp 156 \amp -104 \amp -144 \end{bmatrix}\text{.}\)
    2. \(A_1=\begin{bmatrix} 125 \amp 125 \amp -125 \amp -125 \\ 125 \amp 125 \amp -125 \amp -125 \\ 125 \amp 125 \amp -125 \amp -125 \\ 125 \amp 125 \amp -125 \amp -125 \end{bmatrix}\text{.}\)
    3. \(\displaystyle A-A_1 = \begin{bmatrix} 31 \amp -29 \amp -19 \amp 21 \\ 19 \amp -21 \amp -31 \amp 29 \\ -21 \amp 19 \amp 29 \amp -31 \\ -29 \amp 31 \amp 21 \amp -19 \end{bmatrix}\)
    4. \(A_2 = \begin{bmatrix} 150 \amp 100 \amp -150 \amp -100 \\ 150 \amp 100 \amp -150 \amp -100 \\ 100 \amp 150 \amp -100 \amp -150 \\ 100 \amp 150 \amp -100 \amp -150 \end{bmatrix}\) and \(A-A_2 = \begin{bmatrix} 6 \amp -4 \amp 6 \amp -4 \\ -6 \amp 4 \amp -6 \amp 4 \\ 4 \amp -6 \amp 4 \amp -6 \\ -4 \amp 6 \amp -4 \amp 6 \end{bmatrix}\text{.}\)
    5. \(A_3 = \begin{bmatrix} 155 \amp 95 \amp -145 \amp -105 \\ 145 \amp 105 \amp -155 \amp -95 \\ 105 \amp 145 \amp -95 \amp -155 \\ 95 \amp 155 \amp -105 \amp -145 \end{bmatrix}\) and \(A-A_3 = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ -1 \amp -1 \amp -1 \amp -1 \\ -1 \amp -1 \amp -1 \amp -1 \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp 1 \end{bmatrix}\text{.}\)
    6. \(\displaystyle A_4=A\)
    7. The entries get closer to \(0\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. We find that \(A\) is the rank \(4\) matrix: \(\begin{bmatrix} 156 \amp 96 \amp -144 \amp -104 \\ 144 \amp 104 \amp -156 \amp -96 \\ 104 \amp 144 \amp -96 \amp -156 \\ 96 \amp 156 \amp -104 \amp -144 \end{bmatrix}\text{.}\)
    2. Because it has one nonzero singular value, \(A_1\) has rank \(1\) and has the form: \(A_1=\begin{bmatrix} 125 \amp 125 \amp -125 \amp -125 \\ 125 \amp 125 \amp -125 \amp -125 \\ 125 \amp 125 \amp -125 \amp -125 \\ 125 \amp 125 \amp -125 \amp -125 \end{bmatrix}\text{.}\)
    3. \(\displaystyle A-A_1 = \begin{bmatrix} 31 \amp -29 \amp -19 \amp 21 \\ 19 \amp -21 \amp -31 \amp 29 \\ -21 \amp 19 \amp 29 \amp -31 \\ -29 \amp 31 \amp 21 \amp -19 \end{bmatrix}\)
    4. \(A_2\) is the rank \(2\) matrix \(\begin{bmatrix} 150 \amp 100 \amp -150 \amp -100 \\ 150 \amp 100 \amp -150 \amp -100 \\ 100 \amp 150 \amp -100 \amp -150 \\ 100 \amp 150 \amp -100 \amp -150 \end{bmatrix}\) and \(A-A_2 = \begin{bmatrix} 6 \amp -4 \amp 6 \amp -4 \\ -6 \amp 4 \amp -6 \amp 4 \\ 4 \amp -6 \amp 4 \amp -6 \\ -4 \amp 6 \amp -4 \amp 6 \end{bmatrix}\text{.}\)
    5. \(A_3\) is the rank \(3\) matrix \(\begin{bmatrix} 155 \amp 95 \amp -145 \amp -105 \\ 145 \amp 105 \amp -155 \amp -95 \\ 105 \amp 145 \amp -95 \amp -155 \\ 95 \amp 155 \amp -105 \amp -145 \end{bmatrix}\) with \(A-A_3 = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ -1 \amp -1 \amp -1 \amp -1 \\ -1 \amp -1 \amp -1 \amp -1 \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp 1 \end{bmatrix}\text{.}\)
    6. \(A_4=A\) since \(A\) is a rank \(4\) matrix.
    7. As \(k\) increases, the entries in the \(A-A_k\) get closer to \(0\text{.}\) This means that our approximations \(A\approx A_k\) are improving.

    23.5.3 Principal component analysis

    Activity 23.5.4.

    Answer.
    1. The fraction of the total variance represented by the first two principal components is \(97.8\%\text{.}\)
    2. If \(\xvec = c_1\uvec_1+c_2\uvec_2+c_3\uvec_3+c_4\uvec_4\text{,}\) then \(\fourvec{c_1}{c_2}{c_3}{c_4}\) is the corresponding column of \(U^TA\text{.}\)
    3. We just need the first two components of the corresponding column of \(\Gamma\text{.}\)
    4. \(\twovec{c_1}{c_2}\) is the corresponding column of \(U_2^TA\text{.}\)
    5. We can construct \(\Gamma_2=\Sigma_2 V_2^T\) or just pull out the first two rows of \(\Gamma=\Sigma V^T\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. The singular values are \(\sigma_1=25.1\text{,}\) \(\sigma_2 = 6.0\text{,}\) \(\sigma_3=3.4\) and \(\sigma_4 = 1.9\text{.}\) Since \(V_{\uvec_i} = \frac{1}{150} \sigma_i^2\text{,}\) the variances are \(4.20\text{,}\) \(0.24\text{,}\) \(0.08\text{,}\) and \(0.02\text{.}\) The fraction of the total variance represented by the first two principal components is \(97.8\%\text{.}\)
    2. If \(\xvec\) is the \(100^{th}\) column of \(A\text{,}\) then \(\fourvec{c_1}{c_2}{c_3}{c_4}\) is the \(100^{th}\) column of \(U^TA = U^T(U\Sigma V^T) = \Sigma V^T = \Gamma\text{.}\)
    3. The projected data point is \(\xhat = c_1\uvec_1 + c_2\uvec_2\) since \(c_3\uvec_3+c_4\uvec_4\) is orthogonal to the subspace spanned by the first two principal components. Therefore, the coordinates of the projected data point are the first two components of the corresponding column of \(\Gamma\text{.}\) The coordinates of all the projected data points are given by the first two rows of \(\Gamma\text{.}\)
    4. Once again, suppose that \(\xvec=c_1\uvec_1+c_2\uvec_2+c_3\uvec_3+c_4\uvec_4\) is a column of \(A\) and that \(U_2 = \begin{bmatrix}\uvec_1 \amp \uvec_2 \end{bmatrix}\text{.}\) Then \(\twovec{c_1}{c_2}\) is the corresponding column of \(U_2^TA = U_2(U\Sigma V^T) = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix}\Sigma V^T = \Sigma_2 V_2^T=\Gamma_2\text{.}\)
    5. We can construct \(\Gamma_2=\Sigma_2 V_2^T\) or just pull out the first two rows of \(\Gamma=\Sigma V^T\text{.}\)

    23.5.4 Image compressing and denoising

    Activity 23.5.5.

    Answer.
      1. \(\displaystyle \rank(A) = 3\)
      2. \(\displaystyle \rank(A) = 3\)
      3. \(\displaystyle k=3\)
      4. \(\displaystyle 123\)
      5. The compression ratio is \(375/123=3.0\)
      1. The singular values fall off steeply but never reach \(0\text{.}\)
      2. When \(k=50\text{,}\) the compression ratio is about \(3.1\text{.}\) When \(k=100\text{,}\) the compression ratio is about \(1.6\text{.}\)
      1. The singular values are similar, but they never reach \(0\text{.}\)
      2. \(k=3\) seems like a natural approximation
    Solution.
      1. \(\rank(A) = 3\) because there are three distinct columns represented by the first, third, and sixth columns.
      2. There are three nonzero singular values so \(\rank(A) =3\) as we suspected.
      3. The smallest value is \(k=3\) since \(\rank(A) = 3\text{.}\)
      4. The left singular vectors are \(25\)-dimensional and the right singular vectors are \(15\)-dimensional. If we keep three singular values, left singular vectors, and right singular vectors, we have \(3(1+25+15) = 123\text{.}\)
      5. The compression ratio is \(375/123=3.0\) so the data is compressed by a factor of \(3\text{.}\)
      1. The singular values fall off steeply but never reach \(0\text{.}\)
      2. When \(k=50\text{,}\) the compression ratio is about \(3.1\text{.}\) When \(k=100\text{,}\) the compression ratio is about \(1.6\text{.}\)
      1. The singular values are similar, but they never reach \(0\text{.}\)
      2. \(k=3\) seems like a natural approximation since thats the place where the singular values become almost \(0\text{.}\)

    23.5.5 Analyzing Supreme Court cases

    Activity 23.5.6.

    Answer.
    1. The first two singular values contribute most significantly.
    2. \(\Gamma\) is a \(9\times911\) matrix that expresses the cases as linear combinations of the left singular vectors.
    3. This is a unanimous decision.
    4. \(\uvec_1\) represents a unanimous decision.
    5. This is a 5-4 decision with the 5 conservative justices voting in the majority.
    6. \(\uvec_2\) represents a 5-4 decision.
    7. The most frequently occurring decisions are unanimous and the second most frequently occurring are 5-4.
    8. \(\uvec_1\) represents a case where the five conservative justices are voting together.
    9. The second left singular vector \(\uvec_2\) essentially records the vote of Sandra Day OConnor.
    10. Sandra Day OConnor
    Solution.
    1. The first two singular values contribute most significantly.
    2. \(\Gamma\) is a \(9\times911\) matrix that expresses the cases as linear combinations of the left singular vectors.
    3. This is a unanimous decision.
    4. The unanimous decision is essentially represented as \(-\uvec_1\) so \(\uvec_1\) represents a unanimous decision.
    5. This is a 5-4 decision with the 5 conservative justices voting in the majority.
    6. This 5-4 decision is essentially represented as \(\uvec_2\text{,}\) the second most important left singular vector.
    7. We see that the most decisions are unanimous, which is why \(\uvec_1\) represents unanimous decisions. The second most frequently occurring decisions is a 5-4 decision, which is why \(\uvec_2\) represents a 5-4 decision that leans to the conservative justices.
    8. The first singular vector \(\uvec_1\) represents a case where the five conservative justices are voting together. From this we conclude that the court leans toward the conservatives.
    9. The second left singular vector \(\uvec_2\) essentially records the vote of Sandra Day OConnor and shows how her vote has the power to swing a 5-4 decision from a conservative majority to a progressive majority.
    10. Sandra Day OConnor would be the swing vote.

    23.5.7 Exercises

    23.5.7.1.

    Answer.
    1. \(\rank(A) = 4\text{.}\)
    2. \(A_1=\begin{bmatrix} 1.3 \amp -1.2 \amp -1.2 \amp 3.8 \\ -0.58 \amp 0.56 \amp 0.56 \amp -1.7 \\ 0.92 \amp -0.90 \amp -0.89 \amp 2.7 \\ -0.84 \amp 0.83 \amp 0.82 \amp -2.5 \end{bmatrix}\text{,}\) \(A_2=\begin{bmatrix} 1.5 \amp -2.0 \amp -1.2 \amp 3.4 \\ -1.3 \amp 2.8 \amp 0.43 \amp -0.77 \\ -0.32 \amp 2.8 \amp -1.1 \amp 4.3 \\ -1.3 \amp 2.1 \amp 0.75 \amp -2.0 \end{bmatrix}\text{,}\)\
      \(A_3=\begin{bmatrix} 2.2 \amp -1.9 \amp 0.048 \amp 3.7 \\ -1.2 \amp 2.9 \amp 0.72 \amp -0.72 \\ -0.51 \amp 2.8 \amp -1.4 \amp 4.2 \\ -0.60 \amp 2.3 \amp 2.0 \amp -1.7 \end{bmatrix}\text{,}\) \(A_4=A\)
    Solution.
    1. The singular values are \(6.4\text{,}\) \(5.2\text{,}\) \(2.1\text{,}\) and \(0.5\) so we have \(\rank(A) = 4\text{.}\)
    2. \(A_1=\begin{bmatrix} 1.3 \amp -1.2 \amp -1.2 \amp 3.8 \\ -0.58 \amp 0.56 \amp 0.56 \amp -1.7 \\ 0.92 \amp -0.90 \amp -0.89 \amp 2.7 \\ -0.84 \amp 0.83 \amp 0.82 \amp -2.5 \end{bmatrix}\text{,}\) \(A_2=\begin{bmatrix} 1.5 \amp -2.0 \amp -1.2 \amp 3.4 \\ -1.3 \amp 2.8 \amp 0.43 \amp -0.77 \\ -0.32 \amp 2.8 \amp -1.1 \amp 4.3 \\ -1.3 \amp 2.1 \amp 0.75 \amp -2.0 \end{bmatrix}\text{,}\)
      \(A_3=\begin{bmatrix} 2.2 \amp -1.9 \amp 0.048 \amp 3.7 \\ -1.2 \amp 2.9 \amp 0.72 \amp -0.72 \\ -0.51 \amp 2.8 \amp -1.4 \amp 4.2 \\ -0.60 \amp 2.3 \amp 2.0 \amp -1.7 \end{bmatrix}\text{,}\) \(A_4=A\)

    23.5.7.2.

    Answer.
    1. The linear system is
      \begin{equation*} \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp 4 \\ 1 \amp 3 \amp 9 \\ 1 \amp 4 \amp 16 \\ \end{bmatrix} \xvec = \fivevec10{1.5}48 \end{equation*}
    2. \(U\) is a \(5\times5\) matrix, \(\Sigma\) is \(5\times3\text{,}\) and \(V\) is \(3\times3\)
    3. \(\displaystyle \xhat=\threevec{0.87}{-1.34}{0.79}\)
    Solution.
    1. The linear system is
      \begin{equation*} \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp 4 \\ 1 \amp 3 \amp 9 \\ 1 \amp 4 \amp 16 \\ \end{bmatrix} \xvec = \fivevec10{1.5}48 \end{equation*}
    2. \(U\) is a \(5\times5\) matrix, \(\Sigma\) is \(5\times3\text{,}\) and \(V\) is \(3\times3\)
    3. The rank of \(A\) is 3 so well form the reduced singular value decomposition \(A=U_3\Sigma_3V_3^T\text{.}\) Then \(\xhat = V_3\Sigma_3^{-1}U_3^T\bvec = \threevec{0.87}{-1.34}{0.79}\)

    23.5.7.3.

    Answer.
    1. \(\displaystyle \uvec~\vvec^T = \begin{bmatrix} 4 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ -6 \amp 0 \amp -3 \end{bmatrix}\)
    2. The rank is \(1\) and \(\uvec\) forms a basis.
    3. This matrix projects vectors orthogonally onto the line defined by \(\uvec\text{.}\)
    Solution.
    1. \(\displaystyle \uvec~\vvec^T = \begin{bmatrix} 2\uvec \amp 0\uvec \amp \uvec \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 4 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ -6 \amp 0 \amp -3 \end{bmatrix}\)
    2. Since each column of \(\uvec~\vvec^T\) is a scalar multiple of \(\uvec\text{,}\) the rank of the matrix is \(1\) and \(\uvec\) forms a basis.
    3. This matrix projects vectors orthogonally onto the line defined by \(\uvec\text{.}\)

    23.5.7.4.

    Answer.
    1. The variances are \(1.96\text{,}\) \(1.01\text{,}\) \(0.79\text{,}\) and \(0.24\text{.}\)
    2. \(\displaystyle 74\%\)
    3. The matrix \(B\) is formed from the first two rows of the product \(\Sigma V^T\text{.}\)
    4. Left
    5. Houses on the left have larger living area, lot sizes, and prices and are newer. Houses near the top have larger lot sizes and ages.
    Solution.
    1. The singular values \(\sigma_i\) are \(45.5\text{,}\) \(32.6\text{,}\) \(28.9\text{,}\) and \(15.9\text{.}\) Therefore, the variances in the direction of the principal components are given by \(\frac{1}{1057}\sigma_i^2\) and are \(1.96\text{,}\) \(1.01\text{,}\) \(0.79\text{,}\) and \(0.24\text{.}\)
    2. The first two principal components retain \(74\%\) of the total variance.
    3. The matrix \(B\) is formed from the first two rows of the product \(\Sigma V^T\text{.}\)
    4. The fourth components, the ones that correspond to house prices, of \(\uvec_1\) and \(\uvec_2\) are \(-0.65\) and \(-0.03\) respectively. This shows us that \(\uvec_2\) doesnt contribute much to the house price. Moving in the negative \(\uvec_1\) direction causes the house price to go up so the more expensive homes are on the left.
    5. The first principal component is \(\uvec_1 = \fourvec{-0.64}{-0.20}{0.36}{-0.65}\text{.}\) If we move to the left, this vector is multiplied by a negative number so the living area, lot size, and price go up while the age of the house decreases.
      The second principal component is \(\uvec_2=\fourvec{0.05}{0.86}{0.51}{-0.03}\text{.}\) If we move up, this is multiplied by a positive number so the lot size and the age of the house increase.

    23.5.7.5.

    Answer.
    1. For each justice, it tells us the number of times that justice voted with the majority minus the number of times they voted in the minority.
    2. The justice that most often votes with the majority could be a swing vote.
    3. The first five justices usually vote in the majority.
    4. A second justice voted with the majority 84 times more than with the minority.
    5. Anthony Kennedy
    Solution.
    1. \(A\vvec\) is a 9-dimensional vector. For each justice, it tells us the number of times that justice voted with the majority minus the number of times they voted in the minority.
    2. Out of 188 cases, the fifth justice Sandra Day OConnor voted with the majority 94 more times than with the minority. Since a swing vote will often vote in the majority, this gives additional evidence that Sandra Day OConnor is a swing vote.
    3. The first five justices more often vote with the majority and the last four more often with the minority. This means the court leans toward the first five justices, who are the more conservative ones.
    4. The fourth justice Anthony Kennedy voted with the majority 84 times more than with the minority. He is a potential swing vote.
    5. The third singular vector \(\uvec_3\) effectively records his vote and not the votes of the other justices. This lends support to the claim that Anthony Kennedy is a second, somewhat less influential, swing vote.

    23.5.7.6.

    Answer.
    1. The matrix is symmetric.
    2. \(A_2\) should be a good approximation to \(A\text{.}\)
    3. \(\displaystyle U=V\)
    4. John Paul Stevens, is the least agreeable.
    5. The fourth and fifth justices, Anthony Kennedy and Sandra Day OConnor are less inclined to agree with the others.
    Solution.
    1. The matrix is symmetric because the number of times Justice A votes with Justice B is the same as the number of times Justice B votes with Justice A.
    2. The first two singular values appear to be most important so \(A_2\) should be a good approximation to \(A\text{.}\)
    3. \(U=V\) since \(A\) is a positive definite, symmetric matrix.
    4. The sixth justice, John Paul Stevens, is the least agreeable.
    5. The fourth and fifth justices, Anthony Kennedy and Sandra Day OConnor are less inclined to agree with the others so they form swing votes.

    23.5.7.7.

    Answer.
    1. Find the number of columns of \(U_r^T\) and the number of rows of \(V_r\text{.}\)
    2. If \(A\) is invertible, then \(A\) is an \(m\times m\) matrix whose rank is \(m\text{.}\)
    3. \(\displaystyle AA^{+} = (U_r\Sigma_rV_r^T)(V_r\Sigma^{-1}U_r^T) = U_rU_r^T\)
    4. \(\displaystyle AA^{+} = (V_r\Sigma^{-1}U_r^T)(U_r\Sigma_rV_r^T) V_rV_r^T\)
    Solution.
    1. The number of columns of \(A^+\) is the number of columns of \(U_r^T\text{,}\) which is \(m\text{,}\) and the number of rows is the number of rows of \(V_r\text{,}\) which is \(n\text{.}\)
    2. If \(A\) is invertible, then \(A\) is an \(m\times m\) matrix whose rank is \(m\text{.}\) The reduced singular value decomposition is therefore \(A=U\Sigma V^T\) so that \(A^+=V\Sigma^{-1}U^T = (U\Sigma V^T)^{-1}=A^{-1}\text{.}\)
    3. \(AA^{+} = (U_r\Sigma_rV_r^T)(V_r\Sigma^{-1}U_r^T) = U_rU_r^T\text{,}\) which projects vectors orthogonal onto \(\col(A)\) since the columns of \(U_r\) are an orthonormal basis for \(\col(A)\text{.}\)
    4. \(AA^{+} = (V_r\Sigma^{-1}U_r^T)(U_r\Sigma_rV_r^T) V_rV_r^T\text{,}\) which projects vectors orthogonal onto \(\col(A^T)\) since the columns of \(V_r\) are an orthonormal basis for \(\col(A^T)\text{.}\)

    23.5.7.8.

    Answer.
    1. The condition number is \(40,000\)
      1. \(\displaystyle A^{-1}\bvec = \twovec{-14142.5}{14142.5}\)
      2. \(\displaystyle A^{-1}\bvec = \twovec{-14142.8}{14142.8}\)
      1. \(\displaystyle A^{-1}\bvec = \twovec{-14142.5}{14142.5}\)
      2. \(\displaystyle A^{-1}\bvec = \twovec{-28284.6}{28285.3}\)
    4. \(\displaystyle c_2=\frac{d_2}{\sigma_2}\)
    Solution.
    1. The singular values of \(A\) are \(2\) and \(5\times10^{-5}\text{,}\) which means the condition number is \(40,000\text{.}\)
      1. \(\displaystyle A^{-1}\bvec = \twovec{-14142.5}{14142.5}\)
      2. \(\displaystyle A^{-1}\bvec = \twovec{-14142.8}{14142.8}\)
      1. \(\displaystyle A^{-1}\bvec = \twovec{-14142.5}{14142.5}\)
      2. \(\displaystyle A^{-1}\bvec = \twovec{-28284.6}{28285.3}\)
    4. We have \(d_i = \sigma_ic_i\) so \(c_i=\frac{d_i}{\sigma_i}\text{.}\) Since \(\sigma_2\) is so much smaller than \(\sigma_1\text{,}\) even small changes in \(d_2\) can lead to relatively large changes in \(c_2\text{.}\)
    PrevTopNext
